story:
Who We Are

Fruitcake Theatre Company has been a passion project since our sophomore year. Just last year, we mounted a production of All My Sons by Arthur Miller and we sold out all four performances. This year, we are planning to do The Elephant Man by Bernard Pomerance and bring his work to life. With your help, we can create the vision we have for this play into a reality.

What We Need 

A set

Costumes

Food for actors/crew

What You Get

Free tickets

Signed program

Signed poster

Reserved seats

THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!

story:
Introduction and background:

The DUENDE School of Ensemble Physical Theatre is a peripatetic training programme set up by John Britton for performers in the initial stages of their performance careers. It has been running in Athens for the last three years. This year, its fourth year, it is traveling to India. The School was set up with these objectives in mind-

1. To offer the best possible practical training in ensemble and physical theatre to performers wanting a clear, rigorous and creative understanding of how to perform in easeful, healthy and creative ways.

2. To keep the costs of the training as low as possible as, too often, performers from lower income backgrounds cannot access high quality practical training.

3. To have the training delivered by cutting-edge experts in their fields - working artists who can offer contemporary perspectives on being a performer and help students build their own international networks and knowledge.

We keep administration and advertisement costs to a bare minimum and work in low-cost countries and offer significant discounts to local students. We do everything we can to keep fees low while paying artists properly. The DUENDE School is not affiliated to any University which allows for a space where artists can develop work in environments where they are self motivated, can explore diverse aesthetics and their work is not reduced to grades.

The Teachers at the School:

John Britton is the Artistic Director of DUENDE. John will teach throughout the programme and will be responsible for directing the final production. John will teach core training, ensemble, physical performance skills, liveness and will take personal responsibility for the progress of each student at The DUENDE School. 

John is an internationally renowned director and teacher whose work covers the worlds of theatre, circus, dance, improvisation and site-specific work. 

Manjari Kaul is a Delhi based performer/ director and a DUENDE Artist. She will work alongside John for the duration of the School. Manjari will teach compositional performance skills exploring the relationship between bodies, spaces and objects, and will co- direct the final production. Manjari is also Administrator of the DUENDE School for 2018.

Dr. Eilon Morris (also a DUENDE Artist) will teach in the first block of the course at Kamshet. Eilon is a renowned Teacher and Performer, a Percussionist, Researcher and Musical Director. Eilon will teach physical performance skills, musicality and the use of rhythm in making and presenting performance. Eilon is the author of the recently published book: 'Rhythm in Acting and Performance’ (Methuen 2017).

Avantika Bahl who will teach 'Movement Technique and Principles' is a dance practitioner based in Mumbai where she makes her own work and teaches. She studied at the London Contemporary Dance School.

Bindhumalini Narayanaswamy's classes will include voice warm ups and creating and improvising with song and music for Theatre. Bindhumalini works in Hindustani, Carnatic as well folk and mystic music traditions, intersecting paths with film, storytelling, dance and visual arts. She was a disciple of Padma Bhushan Ustad Abdul Rashid Khan who was the oldest exponent of the Gwalior Gharana.

 

 

Importance of the campaign:

This campaign is to help offer a hardship fund to at least 4 Indian students. More often than not artists, especially those who have just embarked upon their professional careers struggle with finances. If we are able to offer a cut in the fees it might enable young Indian artists who are passionate about their Art and wish to commit themselves to rigorous training, to avail of all that the DUENDE School has to offer.

 

The DUENDE School training combines theatre, dance, musicality, voice and improvisation to develop skills as a complete, adaptable, interdisciplinary performer.  Students, over the years have emerged with developed physical skills, more confidence, greater presence, an ability to communicate spontaneously with other performers and a hugely increased belief and trust in their power as unique, skilful and creative performing-artists.

 

What We Need:

Our initial target is to raise around £3000. This will enable us to offer a 50% fee reduction to 4 Indian students. If we raise less, we will be able to offer less, but all money will still go directly to subsidise students at the school. If we raise more, we will be able to offer more assistance

 

The Impact

If we are able to achieve our target, the contribution will be used to offer hardship funds to at least four different performers.

It’s about trying to counteract economic disadvantage.

It’s about trying to enable access

It’s about encouraging talent and passion

It’s about fairness.

 

Risks & Challenges

Incase we are unable to achieve the target, we will be unable to offer any cut in the fees which might make attending the school, for certain prospective students, hard or even impossible.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help monetarily, it doesn’t mean you can't contribute. You could help us with getting the word out and making some noise about our campaign. Do please use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
WHO WE ARE:

VIVO Ballet is a cutting edge American contemporary dance company based in New York City. The company is categorized by its innovative choreography, unique sense of style and emotive qualities.

VIVO Ballet was founded in 2015 by Artistic Director, Enzo Celli, in Rome, Italy. The founding team established two entities; VIVO Ballet a New York based dance company, and the VIVO Ballet Professional Training Center based in Rome.

Since its conception in 2015, VIVO Ballet has performed in international festivals in the USA, France, Portugal, Switzerland, and Italy. With roots in Rome, the company sprouted within the Professional Training Center and then located to a more permanent home in New York. In 2018 VIVO Ballet makes a debut on American soil with a complete cast of 14 dancers.

VIVO Ballet has set a goal for the Fall 2018 season to premiere two evening length works in a theater space in New York City, with 14 diverse, high-caliber dancers.

VIVO Ballet’s Fall production in New York will allow us be a major milestone for the company.

With your support we can continue creating!

 

WHERE YOUR SUPPORT GOES:

Your support is vital to our success, it will help us to secure funds for the following categories:

Technical Fees: The biggest cost weighing on our Fall 2018 season is renting theater space in New York City. Your donations will directly contribute to our theater rental deposits, rentals, lighting and sound design and operation, costumes, and space. With your help, VIVO Ballet will be able to premiere two evening length works on prestigious stages around New York City.

Rehearsal Space: We all know that rent runs extremely high in NYC, and when you are looking for spaces large enough to dance in that cost adds up quickly. VIVO Ballet rehearses in artist friendly locations that try to keep the costs low, but over time it adds up! Your donations will help us rent studio space so we can create the Fall 2018 programs!

Dancer Pay: VIVO Ballet is comprised of 14 wonderful, talented and devoted dancers. These dancers come from across the United States and around the world. They have donated countless hours of rehearsal, passion, sweat and commitment by dancing with VIVO ballet. We would like to use part of these funds to honor them for their hard work. Performing with VIVO Ballet in the fall season will provide an opportunity for each of these dancers to grow artistically. It is vital that we raise funds to respect this growth and performance.

Staff pay: VIVO Ballet has amazing support behind the scenes that help with administration, public relations and communications. We need your help to give them the credit they deserve for making our Fall season run smoothly.

Marketing: Part of the Fall season’s success depends on adequately getting the word about our shows out to the public. We need funds for web, print and social media materials.

Your support will ultimately contribute to the success and longevity of VIVO Ballet as a premiere contemporary dance company!

Any amount can make a large difference in VIVO Ballet’s evolution. Thank you!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

Of course we value donations, but we also would be thrilled if you would share the word about VIVO Ballet by sharing this campaign with your family, friends and colleagues! Either via word of mouth, or on facebook and other social media!  

Stay connected to us and follow VIVO Ballet on Facebook, and on instagram @vivoballet.ny

Lastly, if you are in New York come to one of our fall shows! We would love to show you the work that you have helped produce!

story:
This October, prepare to take the test!

David McKenna has a baby on the way; he needs money. Unluckily, the former enfant terrible is only qualified to do one thing: teach poetry. He lands a position at a large research university, but only after agreeing to join a secret government experiment. But what happens when that secret has a name, and no longer wants to be kept?

Turing Test is a thrilling new play written by Dominick DeGaetano. It's making its debut at the FringeNYC Festival October 13-20, in a production directed by Taylor Edelle Stuart. Tickets go on sale September 1, but WE NEED YOUR HELP to bring this show to life!

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're trying to raise $6000 to cover the majority of production costs. This includes festival fees and marketing materials, but the majority of the money raised is directly going pay the artists, designers, and creators making this possible.
  • Perks for donors include being listed in our program, presale tickets, posters, scripts, and social media shoutouts!
  • We keep every dollar you donate, but we keep a LOT more of the money if the project hits $6000.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there's plenty of other ways to help!

  • Follow and share us on your socials!
  • Do a skillshare! Shoot us a pitch at turingtestfringe@gmail.com.

story:
Thin Space Productions is a multi-medium non-union production company. 

For the past three years, we have been developing and producing indie theatre in NYC. 
"The Tea Party" was produced in full at Manhattan Repertory Theater and received a reading at Dixon Place. A full production of "Die For Me" was performed at the 2016 New York Fringe Festival. This past May, a reading of "Verity" was performed at Shetler Studios.

We are planning to produce our next project--a feature length, two-act musical that has been in development for nearly two years! In 2018 we produced two separate readings to workshop and fine tune Harpies for the Dead; the next steps are putting together a polished submission package.

"Harpies for the Dead" is an eclectic musical that blends jazz, rock, folk and traditional musical theatre styles into a boundary-pushing, rule-breaking new show!
When four people die unexpectedly, they find themselves in a mysterious afterlife ruled over by the five malevolent Harpies. As each of the humans stands judgment for their lives, one by one, they begin to question each other as well as the motives of the Harpies.
The show asks the question--what does it mean to be a good person?

The Impact

Submission Costs: Donations will be applied to the fees accompanying submissions in order to promote and produce Harpies for the Dead in developmental programs, nationwide festivals, and out-of-state theatres.  

Cast Recording: Donations will be used to secure studio time, equipment, and hiring additional musicians to produce high quality recordings of a selection of music. Once completed, these recordings will be imperative to submission applications and future productions of Harpies For The Dead. 

Videography: Donations will be used to pay for a refined and high quality filming of the show. Documenting the performance in this way will serve to archive the shows' development and be essential to submission packages. 

Other Ways You Can Help

One of the most valuable things that you can give us is spreading the word!

Be sure to follow us on Facebook and Instagram to always stay in the loop on what we are developing next. Please share this campaign with anyone you know who might be interested in a groovy new rock musical.
And lastly, THANK YOU for taking the time to read, share, and donate. We truly cannot do any of this without your help, and we remain committed to developing original, exciting, paid non-equity theatre in NYC.

Thank you,
Brit Lenae Gossett, Emily Johnson-Erday, and Ethan Ness
Thin Space Productions

story:
Who We Are & What We Do

  • Peter Zachari and Joey Mirabile have been producing independent theater in New York City since 2011 starting with their production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow at the New York International Fringe Festival. The show was selected as part of the Encore Series and remounted at The Players Theater. The show returned yet again at Theater for the New City in 2014. 
  • We have found the most wonderful artistic home at Theater for the New City. In the past five years we have presented a bevy of original shows: Fat Asses: The Musical, Under the Knife: A Farce, One Love, a freshly reimagined production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow and the premiere of Anne Marilyn Lucas' From Silence.

  • Peter Zachari has rewritten, revamped, retitled this zany, cutting-edge farce.  We have the opportunity to bring this reimagined show in 2019 at Theater for the New City. But we need help to make this happen. 

How You Can Make a Difference

The world wants this show. And we want to make it happen! And we will if you help us. We need to raise $25,000. That funding goes for:

Payment for Equity actors, director, musical director, musicians stage managers, set designer, costume designer, lighting designer and sound engineers 

Sets, props, costumes, projections, video equipment

Publicity and Marketing, printed materials, mailings, ads, email blasts.

The Impact

The world needs this show. We need to laugh. And this farce blends traditional physical and verbal comedy with the social issues that are prevalent today. I think you would be proud to say you were a part of this production team.

Because of people like you we HAVE been producing original works. Six original Peter Zachari plays and musicals have been produced in New York City from the generosity of friends, family and participants of crowdfunding efforts.

Not only does the audiences of New York City get to see the show but tens of New York artists, actors, designers and staff get to participate in this work of passion and contribute to the landscape of the New York City theater scene.

Let's Do This!

We can't let another opportunity like this slip by. It's important that we present shows that challenge the status quo and represent those voices who aren't being heard. Without your help, we could be at risk of not presenting this show next year. And that would be a shame!

story:
We Are But Young in Deed...

We think "Macbeth" is important right now, for the millennial generation.  By supporting us, you'll be supporting not only the careers of LA's artists, but will bring this story’s resonant lessons of ambition, power, and love to its many inhabitants that are currently navigating the complex politics of the world around them to generate lasting change.

Seen through our lens, Macbeth is a coming of age story, of a young man at a crossroads in which he is confronted with the man he is and the man he has always imagined himself to be. With the help of his most beloved partner, they take a course of action down a path that will simultaneously bring them all they ever dreamed possible while destroying the world around them and each other, bringing to them a wisdom far beyond their years.  It’s a cautionary tale. It’s a love story. It’s a play for now.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the deal, we need your help to make this happen.  This IndieGoGo campaign will only cover half of our $20,000 budget.  Your contributions will help with: 

  • Rehearsal & Performance Space Rental
  • Set and prop (and blood) construction and materials
  • Promotional designs and materials
  • Paying designers, crew, and actors a respectable fee for their hard work
  • Safe and professional fight choreography (and blood)
  • Costume design, construction, and laundry (out damn spot)

But we won't leave you empty handed!  We're partnering with some awesome people to give you some great perks for lending us a hand including: 

  • Premium Seating
  • Tours of Downtown LA's booming Arts District
  • Drinks with the Cast
  • Art & Merch special to our show

Risks & Challenges

Ever walk out of an amazing play with a half filled house and said, "Man! I wish more people knew about this!"?  Us too.  Here's your chance to solve that problem.  This production has been in the works for two years.  We have meticulously thought it through and it is essential to do.  It's happening.  But not without you. 

Our Team

Our team consists of a variety of backgrounds, each bringing something unique to the project.  Each of us have our very own vision of the American southwest and how Shakespeare can inhabit it.  For this aesthetically powerful play, we're proud to be putting together a look that you haven't seen yet.

Our senior producer, Susan Lambert Hatem, has an deep background in theatre and film making across the United States.  With decades of experience under her belt, she plans to bring to the table a level of ambition and responsiveness only available in the highest tiers of the performing arts industry.

Tristan Waldron and Megan Ruble, are both professional actors working in Los Angeles who also produce projects they are passionate about.  The two are excited to bring his compelling story to the downtown art scene.

Alyssa Escalante, our director, is a fresh young mind in the field of theater.  She has long been involved in theater as a stage manager across Southern California building a deep understanding of and experience in LA's theatre community.  Under her command, the play's direction and performances will be nothing but extraordinary and razor sharp.

This team came together last year for Homeward LA @ Boston Court. We had such a great time working together, we decided to tackle something even more ambitious. And there is no story more ambitious and powerful than William Shakespeare's Macbeth. Join us!

Other Ways to Contribute: 

Low on funds?  We get it.  Here's some other ways to help this production get off the ground:

  • Come see the show at Art Share LA!  
  • Share this campaign with your friends and family.  
  • Talk up independent LA theatre.  
  • Lend us your talents.  Reach out to us at: MacbethLA2019@gmail.com and we'll keep you in the loop about audition and volunteer opportunities.
story_txt:
We Are But Young in Deed...
We think "Macbeth" is important right now, for the millennial generation.  By supporting us, you'll be supporting not only the careers of LA's artists, but will bring this story’s resonant lessons of ambition, power, and love to its many inhabitants that are currently navigating the complex politics of the world around them to generate lasting change.
Seen through our lens, Macbeth is a coming of age story, of a young man at a crossroads in which he is confronted with the man he is and the man he has always imagined himself to be. With the help of his most beloved partner, they take a course of action down a path that will simultaneously bring them all they ever dreamed possible while destroying the world around them and each other, bringing to them a wisdom far beyond their years.  It’s a cautionary tale. It’s a love story. It’s a play for now.

 

What We Need & What You Get
Here's the deal, we need your help to make this happen.  This IndieGoGo campaign will only cover half of our $20,000 budget.  Your contributions will help with: 

Rehearsal & Performance Space Rental
Set and prop (and blood) construction and materials
Promotional designs and materials
Paying designers, crew, and actors a respectable fee for their hard work
Safe and professional fight choreography (and blood)
Costume design, construction, and laundry (out damn spot)


But we won't leave you empty handed!  We're partnering with some awesome people to give you some great perks for lending us a hand including: 

Premium Seating
Tours of Downtown LA's booming Arts District
Drinks with the Cast
Art & Merch special to our show



Risks & Challenges
Ever walk out of an amazing play with a half filled house and said, "Man! I wish more people knew about this!"?  Us too.  Here's your chance to solve that problem.  This production has been in the works for two years.  We have meticulously thought it through and it is essential to do.  It's happening.  But not without you. 


Our Team
Our team consists of a variety of backgrounds, each bringing something unique to the project.  Each of us have our very own vision of the American southwest and how Shakespeare can inhabit it.  For this aesthetically powerful play, we're proud to be putting together a look that you haven't seen yet.

Our senior producer, Susan Lambert Hatem, has an deep background in theatre and film making across the United States.  With decades of experience under her belt, she plans to bring to the table a level of ambition and responsiveness only available in the highest tiers of the performing arts industry.
Tristan Waldron and Megan Ruble, are both professional actors working in Los Angeles who also produce projects they are passionate about.  The two are excited to bring his compelling story to the downtown art scene.
Alyssa Escalante, our director, is a fresh young mind in the field of theater.  She has long been involved in theater as a stage manager across Southern California building a deep understanding of and experience in LA's theatre community.  Under her command, the play's direction and performances will be nothing but extraordinary and razor sharp.
This team came together last year for Homeward LA @ Boston Court. We had such a great time working together, we decided to tackle something even more ambitious. And there is no story more ambitious and powerful than William Shakespeare's Macbeth. Join us!

Other Ways to Contribute: 
Low on funds?  We get it.  Here's some other ways to help this production get off the ground:

Come see the show at Art Share LA!  
Share this campaign with your friends and family.  
Talk up independent LA theatre.  
Lend us your talents.  Reach out to us at: MacbethLA2019@gmail.com and we'll keep you in the loop about audition and volunteer opportunities.

story:
The Show

How far would you go for something you believe is right? Who is responsible for violence and how do you break the cycle? Days of Rage, inspired by the activities of The Weathermen/Weather Underground Organization and The Black Panther Party in the late 1960s and early 1970s, tells the story of Jean Avery, who leads the militant protest group The Weathermen after her brother leaves for Vietnam, and Fred Hayward, the leader of the Chicago chapter of The Black Panther Party, who tries to keep his fellow Party members from descending into violence. As Fred and Jean’s paths intertwine, they grow closer and apart in a turbulent time of war, civil rights, and rage.

Days of Rage는 1960년대 말 1970년대 초반 반전운동, 흑인인권 운동을 한 Weather Undergound와 Black Panther Party의 운동에서 영감을 받아 만든 뮤지컬로 두 주인공, Jean Avery와 Fred Hayward를 통해 신념을 위해 어디까지 갈 수 있는지, 폭력과 비폭력의 방법으로 그들이 믿는 것을 이루고자 하는 그들만의 싸움을 통해 현재도 반복되는 폭력의 고리를 끊기 위해 우리가 할 수 있는 것은 무엇일까?라는 생각을 던져준다. 

The Story

We began writing Days of Rage because as artists we wanted to respond to the wars and civil rights injustices around the world in our own way. This musical is our movement--it illuminates the past so that we don't repeat our history. Days of Rage speaks to the growing anger among today's youth about how their government operates and its role in wars across the world. It asks who is responsible for violence in the world and how we can be responsible for breaking the cycle of violence. We believe that as artists we have a responsibility with the art we create to make a better world. With Days of Rage, we express our hope for this world.

Days of Rage has been developed with students from the University of California, Irvine; Two River Theater in Red Bank, New Jersey, as part of a writers retreat; and with New York Theatre Barn as part of their New Works Series, a developmental reading, and an invitation to participate in their Choreography Lab last year.

This past year, we have had the amazing opportunity to be among the inaugural Sokoloff Arts Fellows at Town Stages in NYC. The culmination of our fellowship will be a two-performance workshop presentation of the first act of Days of Rage. We need your help to make this workshop possible.

예술을 하는 사람으로서 끊임없이 이어지는 전쟁이나 사회에서 일어나는 부조리들에 어떤식으로든 반응을 하고 싶었고, 유일하게 사용할 수 있는 무기가 음악과 이야기이기에 이 뮤지컬이 우리가 시작하는 작은 운동이 되면 어떨까 하는 마음에 작품을 쓰게 되었습니다. 예술가로서 세상을 좀 더 나은 곳으로 만들기 위한 책임이 있지않을까 하여 이 작품을 개발하게 되었고 뉴욕에서 리딩 시리즈를 통해 조금씩 다듬어가며 지금까지 오게 되었습니다. 

이틀에 걸친 워크샾 공연을 뉴욕에서 하게 되었으니 이 워크샾에 많은 후원 부탁드립니다.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a workshop for a musical in New York City is an expensive endeavor. As part of our fellowship, we are getting a great deal on the space rental. However, this is a large cast show, and we will be paying 15 actors. This will add up to roughly $6,000. We will also be assembling a band of four musicians, which will add up to about $1200. Our director and choreographer will also receive stipends, as well as our designers (we are hoping to have a sound designer, lighting designer, and projection designer). 

We are hoping to offset this cost with donations. Every little bit helps to make this workshop possible, and the more you give, the cooler the perk!

Fellowhip을 통해 장소를 마련하게는 되었지만, 배우, 스텝, 연주자, 연습실 등등. 워크샾을 꾸리기엔 적지않은 예산이 필요하고 여러분에게 도움을 받고자 합니다! 작은 후원도 큰 도움이 되오니 많이많이 도와주시고 금액에 따른 다양한 소정의 감사표시도 있사오니 많은 후원 부탁드립니다! 

The Impact of Your Contribution

We truly can't do this workshop without your help. With this workshop, we will be able to see part of our show on its feet, allowing us to develop the show in a much more productive way. All the stage elements inform how a show is working--the lights, the movement, the choreography--and we've never been able to see this with our previous readings of the show, which have the actors with scripts behind music stands. This workshop will also allow us to show Days of Rage to producers who can potentially help bring our show from a workshop to a full production. We believe this workshop will succeed in achieving both of these goals.

여러분의 도움이 없으면 워크샾은 불가능할거예요. 워크샾을 통해 무대에서 실현이 되면 어떨지 보며 한 단계 좀 더 발전시킬 수 있고, 또한 이것을 통해 이 작품이 실제 무대로 가게 될 수 있는 기회를 만들고자 합니다. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please take a moment to share this campaign on your social media platforms or send it directly to people who you think would be interested in giving. And spread the word about our show to people who may be interested in getting involved on an artistic or producer level. 

이 작품에 관심을 가질 만한 사람들, 뮤지컬을 사랑하는 사람들, 또는 이런 주제에 관심있는 사람들에게도 널리널리 퍼뜨려 주세요~~ 

About the Writers

HYEYOUNG KIM (book and music) is a Jonathan Larson Award Winner Selected for NAMT, ASCAP/Disney Workshop, TRU, Composer/Librettist lab at New Dramatists, Johnny Mercer Songwriting Project and Sokoloff Arts Fellow with Town Stages and Sokoloff Arts. Ewha Womans Univ.; NYU GMTWP. SUNFISH (Co-Book/Music)- Daegu International Musical Theatre Festival(Top Jury Honor), Stoneham Theater(BWW Boston Best musical in a mid-size theater); FALLING(Music)- Songwriters Showcase NAMT, Creative Factory, Korea; CAFE-IN(Music)- Live theater, Korea. Toured to Tokyo and Osaka, Japan; LUNA PARK(Co-Book/Music)- MTF’s 4@15, NYC, Oregon Performance Lab, From Page to Stage, London; VAMPIRE IN A BOX(Co-Lyrics/Music)- SHArthall, Korea; DAYS OF RAGE(Book/Music)- NYTB’s New Works pre-premiere series, NYTB’s Choreography Lab; READY TO FLY(Music)- DIMF, final list Changjak Sansil, Korea; A STORY NO ONE KNOWS(Book/Music)- NYTB’s New Works pre-premiere series.  Hyeyoungkimmusic.com

SHOSHANA GREENBERG (lyrics) is a lyricist, librettist, playwright, singer, and theater journalist. She was recently named a Sokoloff Arts Fellow with Town Stages and Sokoloff Arts. Musicals: Days of Rage (reading with New York Theatre Barn) and A Story No One Knows with composer and bookwriter Hyeyoung Kim, and Lightning Man (Ars Nova ANT Fest) with composer Jeffrey
Dennis Smith. Plays: Lost Girl in Florida Swamp (Fresh Produce’d) and The Rapture of Our
Teeth (ESPA Detention Series). Her songs have been performed at Lincoln Center, The York
Theatre, TriArts Sharon Playhouse, the Laurie Beechman, and the Duplex Cabaret Theater,
where she performed her cabaret show Finding My Own Damn Way. As a journalist she has
contributed to American Theatre Magazine, The Interval, Women and Hollywood, The
Huffington Post, and Culturadar and she is a contributing editor of the journal Musical Theater
Today. MFA: Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program at NYU. BA: Barnard College.
Shoshanagreenberg.com. Twitter: @vmarshmellow

 

Fundraising video by Abdul Jackson 

Poster Designed by Eonju Kim

story:
Short Summary

Great Egg Theatre Company is dedicated to telling stories for the mind (the Eggheads!) and the heart (the Good Eggs) and hopes to scramble the two together! From thought-provoking shows to characters with heart and soul, we're dedicated to theatre which is braver, smarter and kinder. 

le Monocle is the untold story of the Parisian lesbian bar, its clientele and Violette Morris – the successful race car driver and athlete who later became involved with the German SS. LGBT+ stories are often lost to history and we hope to shed some light on the incredible tales of these complex historical characters. 

Our team is:

Tiff Milner – Writer & Director

Pareesa Tai – Producer

Annabelle Mastin-Lee – Marketing Co-ordinator

What We Need & What You Get

  • As we have a cast/crew of 10, our accommodation costs are £1900 for 10 days. To make our Edinburgh dreams come true, we are looking for kind contributions towards this cost. 
  • Even if we don't reach our goal of £1000, every little helps – anything you can give will contribute towards making Edinburgh a reality.
  • We have plenty great perks – so choose a package that works for you!

The Impact

  • Our show uncovers a previously untold LGBT+ story.
  • Opens up conversation about LGBT+ history.
  • Valuable experience for cast & crew.
  • Producing an engaging and warm-hearted show with an important message about we respond to prejudice.

Risks & Challenges

  • Funding is our biggest hurdle in producing a Fringe show. Everything is in place – we just need you!
  • Venue and accommodation have been fully secured, as are cast, crew, script, and rehearsal space. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even £1 would help us out, but otherwise you can:

  • Share our Indiegogo page!
  • Follow us on social media:
    • Instagram @greateggtheatre,
    • Twitter @leMonocle2019
    • Facebook @leMonocle2019

story:
The Story

Mathilda is a grey sheep in a grey world. Her herd is content to munch clovers, but Mathilda's mind is full of questions. When an orange balloon makes a surprise appearance on the farm, Mathilda discovers there is more to who she is than being a grey sheep! But the other sheep don’t understand - how can she be an orange balloon? All they see is a little grey sheep. As she explores what it means to be orange, Mathilda leads her herd (and our narrators) on a journey of self-discovery and the joys of self-expression until Mathilda, the narrators, the sheep, and the audience realise that when it comes to who you are, anything is possible!

The Message

Mathilda’s story shows young people and their adults that the language we choose to identify ourselves and our families matter. Identity language isn’t universal - what one thing means to me doesn’t have to be the same as what it means to you, and that’s awesome! We hope our audience members leave the show feeling a greater acceptance and inclusion of diversity, the freedom to define yourself, and excitement to express your own unique you!

The Method

Developed in R&D at Sheffield Theatres in March 2018, the play is performed simultaneously in British Sign Language, Spoken English, and through animated projections, so it’s accessible to D/deaf, hearing, and hard of hearing audiences and across ages, regardless of sign language literacy or reading skills. All performances are relaxed, and everyone is welcome. Our cast includes Deaf and hearing actors from diverse backgrounds, giving kids the chance to see themselves represented on stage. In the last act of the play, the audience is invited up onto the stage, to play with the cast in Mathilda’s fully realized tactile farm. Young audience members get to explore identity words through a playful, relaxed game and adult audience members observe a conversation about identity with kids, taking away concrete tools for continuing this conversation at home.

The Tour

Mathilda and the Orange Balloon is set to debut in London in February at Greenwich and Lewisham Young People’s Theatre. Following that, in the Spring, she’ll make her way to Cambridge Junction, New Wolsey in Ipswich, Arlington Arts Centre in Newbury, Attenborough Arts Centre in Leicester, and Touchbase Pears in Birmingham, bringing her message all across London, Southeast, and Midlands. This mini-tour will set the stage for a full UK tour in 2019-2020.

 

The DH Ensemble is a professional Deaf and hearing led theatre company. We are actors, directors, theatre makers, writers, artists, musicians, dancers and all round lovely people who come together to create live performances. We use a mix of British Sign Language, Spoken English, creative captions, video projection, movement and soundscapes.We formed in 2013 and consist of experienced freelance theatre practitioners.

As a company, we have worked with The Royal Shakespeare Studio, Forest Fringe, The Roundhouse, Pulse Festival, Shuffle Festival and LimeWharf. Most recently, we have collaborated with or performed at the Yard Theatre, Battersea Arts Centre, Northern Stage, Liberty Festival and the Barbican. Our commissions and awards include an outdoor performance for Liberty Festival and being one of two finalists for the Oxford Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust Award in 2016.

We believe in breaking down barriers and pre-conceived perceptions. We aim to create innovative performance exploring genuine, truthful interaction. All our work is fully accessible for D/deaf and hearing audiences.

Jess Kaufman (Writer, Co-producer) is a New York based theatre for young audiences artist who uses theatre to help families cross boundaries. Her work has been seen from the Camden People’s Theatre (Sprint Festival, Camden Fringe Festival) to the US/Mexico border wall, and her performing credits include Off-Broadway and US national tours. She co-created and performed seven original musicals for families with SJ Productions in New York, and is the co-Artistic Director and Lead Producer of Puppets at the Border, which creates an annual binational arts festival with 3 metre tall puppets at the US/Mexico border wall. Jess studied at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and the Moscow Art Theatre. www.jesskaufman.net

Jennifer K. Bates (Director) studied at The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and resides in Scotland. Her theatre credits include Sheffield Theatres (Tribes), Dundee Rep/Poorboy (Monstrous Bodies), Solar Bear Theatre Company (Funk n Love) and Youth Arts Scotland/National Theatre of Scotland (Re:Location). She has directed all of The DH Ensemble's productions thus far including People of the Eye (UK tour) and Nodus Tollens (Liberty Festival).

Hermon Berhane (Mathilda) is a Deaf Eritrean actor and model with training from Deafinitely Theatre. Theatre credits include People of the Eye (DH Ensemble's UK Tour), You’ve Got Dragons (Taking Flight), and House of Bernarda Alba (Manchester Royal Exchange/Graeae). TV/Film: What Not To Do when Hitting On Someone (Channel 4/Scope), Scream Queens (Melodie Rouleaud). Hermon and her twin sister Heroda run a fashion and lifestyle blog, Being Her.

Erin Siobhan Hutching (Co-producer), a native of New Zealand, wrote and performs in the autobiographical piece People of the Eye. Erin studied acting at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York as well as in New Zealand and Australia where she ran her own company Unicorn Productions,touring the Southern Hemisphere. She has performed at venues across the UK including the Bristol Old Vic, Battersea Arts Centre, The Bush, Unity Theatre Liverpool and Contact Manchester. She has produced most projects for The DH Ensemble including People of the Eye, Nodus Tollens and Macbeth (Research & Development).

 

Our total income and expenditures are broken down in the fun pie charts below! (At least, Jess thinks they’re fun because she’s a mathy nerd.)

Expenses

(The costs of fundraising - Indiegogo’s fees, rewards - have been included in Admin & Overhead.)

Income

 

We are managing the risks of moving into Theatre for Young Audiences through some seriously excellent mentorship. In addition to Jess' experience in TYA, we have several expert TYA companies providing peer-to-peer support, including Mousetrap, Half Moon, and Hot Coals.  

This will be our biggest production to date, and Rachel Barnett, an experienced producer, tour booker, and TYA artist has been contracted to provide management support, mentorship, and budget oversight. 

With regards to legal questions, we have a history of getting the visas we need, and have the rights to adapt the picture book in the US and UK. 

 

Audience development is a huge part of our mission. This will be the first theatre experience for many of our young audience members. Help us spread the word using Indiegogo’s handy social share buttons, or consider tickets as a holiday gift for your favorite young person!
story_txt: The StoryMathilda is a grey sheep in a grey world. Her herd is content to munch clovers, but Mathilda's mind is full of questions. When an orange balloon makes a surprise appearance on the farm, Mathilda discovers there is more to who she is than being a grey sheep! But the other sheep don’t understand - how can she be an orange balloon? All they see is a little grey sheep. As she explores what it means to be orange, Mathilda leads her herd (and our narrators) on a journey of self-discovery and the joys of self-expression until Mathilda, the narrators, the sheep, and the audience realise that when it comes to who you are, anything is possible!The MessageMathilda’s story shows young people and their adults that the language we choose to identify ourselves and our families matter. Identity language isn’t universal - what one thing means to me doesn’t have to be the same as what it means to you, and that’s awesome! We hope our audience members leave the show feeling a greater acceptance and inclusion of diversity, the freedom to define yourself, and excitement to express your own unique you!The MethodDeveloped in R&D at Sheffield Theatres in March 2018, the play is performed simultaneously in British Sign Language, Spoken English, and through animated projections, so it’s accessible to D/deaf, hearing, and hard of hearing audiences and across ages, regardless of sign language literacy or reading skills. All performances are relaxed, and everyone is welcome. Our cast includes Deaf and hearing actors from diverse backgrounds, giving kids the chance to see themselves represented on stage. In the last act of the play, the audience is invited up onto the stage, to play with the cast in Mathilda’s fully realized tactile farm. Young audience members get to explore identity words through a playful, relaxed game and adult audience members observe a conversation about identity with kids, taking away concrete tools for continuing this conversation at home.The TourMathilda and the Orange Balloon is set to debut in London in February at Greenwich and Lewisham Young People’s Theatre. Following that, in the Spring, she’ll make her way to Cambridge Junction, New Wolsey in Ipswich, Arlington Arts Centre in Newbury, Attenborough Arts Centre in Leicester, and Touchbase Pears in Birmingham, bringing her message all across London, Southeast, and Midlands. Our commissions and awards include an outdoor performance for Liberty Festival and being one of two finalists for the Oxford Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust Award in 2016.We believe in breaking down barriers and pre-conceived perceptions. We aim to create innovative performance exploring genuine, truthful interaction. Her work has been seen from the Camden People’s Theatre (Sprint Festival, Camden Fringe Festival) to the US/Mexico border wall, and her performing credits include Off-Broadway and US national tours. She co-created and performed seven original musicals for families with SJ Productions in New York, and is the co-Artistic Director and Lead Producer of Puppets at the Border, which creates an annual binational arts festival with 3 metre tall puppets at the US/Mexico border wall. Jess studied at the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and the Moscow Art Theatre. www.jesskaufman.netJennifer K. Her theatre credits include Sheffield Theatres (Tribes), Dundee Rep/Poorboy (Monstrous Bodies), Solar Bear Theatre Company (Funk n Love) and Youth Arts Scotland/National Theatre of Scotland (Re:Location). story:
Campaign Summary

George Houston Bass, director of Rites and Reason, the black theater group at Brown University where we were both English department faculty, suggested that we work together on a play. As a result of that conversation, Garvey Lives! my first attempt at playwriting—and the first ever  produced about the legendary Pan African activist, Marcus Garvey, had its premiere production at Brown in 1972.

Primarily a prose writer and novelist, I was concentrating that year mostly on the activities related to the publication of my second novel, Runner Mack, which was nominated for the 1972 National Book Award. After writing the play, I focused for the next decades on my prose writing.

Then about a year ago,  Bob Gumbs, an ardent devotee and champion of the accomplishments of Black Moses, wanted to know if I had considered revising my play. The time is ripe, he said, given the nation’s retooled discussion about our racial divide and the political and social consequences swirling around us.

But where could I find the assistance I needed to revise my play about Garvey? I met playwright producer Ron Beverly who liked the play’s potential. We decided that collaborating on what Ron terms reinvisioning the drama for 2018 would take about a month. We would engage in highly interactive collaboration, for the best adjustments of style, structure and theme. We see our final reinterpretation as a great jumpstart, a launching pad for further development.

And why not travel to Kingston, Jamaica for this concentrated focus where we could breathe the air and surroundings of Garvey’s birthplace? After all, he is their national hero. And that’s why we have a campaign at Indiegogo. We want to raise funds to allow us two playwrights to go to Kingston, Jamaica for a spirited, uninterrupted stretch of writing. The revised play will then be ready for expansion into workshops, staged readings, and theatrical exposure.

Who Is Involved?



 

OUR GOAL—WHAT WE WANT FROM DONORS

We want to reinterpret the 1972 first play produced about Marcus Garvey to reflect our current era. Our country is a 2018 stage of characters grappling with the tumultuous issues of race, sex and power that have exploded onto our landscape at an undeniable tempo. At the crux of our national conversation are issues introduced by Garvey. We will show that this time is his time.

Our goal is to bring back into the international spotlight the riveting philosophy of one of the greatest organizers in black history. Martin Luther King, Jr., said that Garvey was the first man “to give millions of Negroes a sense of dignity and destiny.” Further, his philosophy of black self-determination influenced international activists like Nelson Mandela, Jomo Kenyatta, and Kwame Nkrumah.

Garvey’s argument—and theatrical flair—captured the black imagination. Blacks needed their own government, their own economy, and their own organizations to be successful in a world that subjugated and marginalized them. He said to escape the suffering, look to Africa. So, he founded a steamship line to take his people back to the continent. He saw black enterprise evolving from global connections. And he pushed for a Pan-African government.

We are in a heyday of activism right now, unlike anything we've seen. It's time to bring up our children to understand important values, to teach them by the actions we take and by what we care about. 

     REWARDS AND BENEFITS FOR DONORS 

Here is the opportunity to support creative endeavors that pack a philosophical and sociological message. In these turbulent times of social unrest, Garvey’s example is an important reminder that leaders have always been there for us to reverse the insanity and wrongheadedness that often infiltrates society. And their preoccupations have not always been remembered. This play recreates and reminds us of Garvey’s vision—of a world centered on respect and dignity.  

Like no other black leader, Garvey was a visionary activist whose dramatic flair has never been equaled—not by Martin Luther King nor Malcolm X. His Universal Negro Improvement Association radiates and exudes spectacle and theater—through speeches, marches, gatherings, and parades.

Blacks needed their own government, their own economy, and their own organizations to be successful in a world that oppressed and marginalized them, Garvey argued. His answer to escape the suffering: look to Africa. He founded a shipping company called the Black Star Line Corporation whose mission was to help the African diaspora trade, and ultimately, to help black people return to the continent. He pictured both an explosion of black enterprise from commerce within the global black diaspora, and a Pan-African government.

 The impact of his message espoused through the drama will be the re-education us all—especially the young who hold the future of this great nation in their hands.

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES 

 

Of course there are no guarantees that the revision will meet its goals of acceptance and production. But every major creative endeavor faces those obstacles that hinder success. Our optimism is driven by the quality of our team, the success of the original production, and the profound message that Garvey represents. 

 

BUDGET AND EXPENSES

 

The $19,000 in our budget covers the following expenses:

Roundtrip coach air fare to Jamaica for two

Room and board for two in a Kingston, Jamaica b&b including 2 meals daily for 30 days

Dramatist Guild approved compensation for two in a collaborative writing agreement

Marketing for Internet social media activity 

Indiegogo fees

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass on our campaign to others excited about the potential that dramatic work can have on entertaining and educating us. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. And please contact us with any questions or ideas. to entertain us and educate us. Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

story:
Who Are We?

We need more women in comedy. Luckily, we're funny as hell, and we honestly need your support.

  • We're Carly Woods and Katie Dessin. Two actresses and writers, living respectively in Los Angeles and Portland, Oregon. From the dawn of our friendship all those years ago, we've been driven. And we got a habit of coping with our depression with making each other laugh, and diving head first into projects that are entirely too ambitious.
  • Simply put: we want to change the world, but right now, we want to make you guys laugh. Life is short. Sh*t is rough out there. Making fun of ourselves in front of a live studio audience is exactly the kind break from the 24 hour news cycle we all need.
  • With your help, we can show a honest (and humorous take) on the struggles of friendship, the fears that come with success, and how much New Jersey really sucks.

This show is our heart and soul, and like any artist, we are dying to share that with you.

What We Need & What You Get

Okay, here's the nitty gritty:

  • We need 7k. As in $7,000. All of our funds have gone to securing the theatre. This money goes directly to the remainder of the booking costs for the run at the AWARD WINNING (seriously) Hudson Mainstage Theatre. The space alone costs $6,500. If we reach our goal, we'll extend to $10k (!!), because after that, we've got a set to build, designers and dressers to pay... productions cost money. We cannot do this without your help. (*for a full itemized financial breakdown, email tooambitiousshow@gmail.com, so we don't bore you with the logistics here. We promise your money is going to a good, creative cause.)
  • MOST IMPORTANTLY (if you ask us), we're giving back to you guys, and we're f*cking excited to do it. Here's what you'll get when you donate to Too Ambitious:

    $10 - Signed Program 
    $25 - Dedicated Carpool Karaoke Video, and all above
    $50 - Selfie on set with Cast & Crew, and all above
    $75 - Special Thanks in Program, and all above
    $100 - Social Media Video Shoutout, and all above
    $200 - Invitation to Industry After Party, and all above
    $500 - Mention by name in script, and all above
    $750 - Seat Next To Reserved Jeff Goldblum Chair (ONLY THREE AVAILABLE), and all above
    $1000 - Producing Credit, and all above

The Impact

If you live in LA, you're already rolling your eyes. But for the viewers at home, this is for you: by supporting us, local theatre, our projects... you're changing our lives.

  • To find out more about Kate & Carly and how we're making this happen, visit our websites:
  • Carly Woods (Actress/Screenwriter): carlyjwoods.com / instagram: @thecarlywoods
  • Katie Dessin (Actress/Writer/Comedian): katiedessin.com / instagram: @katiedessin

The Risk Is Worth It

It's a lot to put on a show. We're ready to tackle whatever comes at us. Both of us are resourceful, sometimes insane, but most importantly, we're passionate as sh*t. As you'll find out in our show, we can accomplish anything as long as we are together. So rain or shine, no matter what obstacle -- we will be there for you guys. Making all of our lives suck a little bit less one show at a time.

And, hey, you may meet Jeff Goldblum if he shows up.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate -- we still love you guys. Here are some killer ways you can help:

  • Share our Indiegogo link, share our website, share our social media. Tell all your friends. Tell a few strangers, too, if you're feeling chatty at Starbucks.
  • Seriously. Every single penny makes the difference.
  • Sign up for our mailing list. We won't spam. We're pretty cool.

All we're saying is life, uh, finds a way. Let us show you how.

story:
The Play

Via Brooklyn is excited to announce their production of Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky by Dianne Nora. With a strong female protagonist at the helm, Monica:This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky will guide you through a narrative of empowerment and bravery. It's a provocative, risky, and thought provoking piece about a woman fighting to be heard and taking ownership of her own story. Sound familiar? That's because it is. (#MeToo, #BelieveWomen). You've heard her story before through newspapers and videocameras, but this is your chance to see it in an entirely new light. Monica is a play for now and we need your help putting it on stage now. 

Where We're Headed

Via Brooklyn is a Brooklyn-based 501(c)3 not-for-profit pending theatre company. We develop theatrical productions, coupled with interactive programming, to engage audiences around the world. Our mission is to foster enthusiasm, contemplation, and community by blurring the traditional lines between the stage and other art media. Our goal for Monica is, as our mission states, develop the play here in New York and then, bring it elsewhere. Where? We're glad you asked: Scotland, the 2019 Edinburgh Fringe Festival to be exact. As we launch our pre-production efforts for Monica, and bring on board a strong team of collaborators, we greatly appreciate any and all support.

What We Need

Every dime donated will support the following:

Paying the Talent - At Via Brooklyn paying our talent is not optional. (And we mean it- we firmly believe artists need to be paid, and paid in a timely manner). Your donation will support the creativity of our actors, director, playwright, stage manager, set designer, costume designer, light designer, sound designer, projection designer, assistants, dressers, and anyone else that helps us bring Monica from the page to the stage.

Paying for the Theatre - *Insert lyrics from the hit musical RENT*

"How we gonna pay [...]

Last year's rent
This year's rent
Next year's rent
Rent rent rent rent rent"! 

So yeah, about the cost of rent in New York City (and Scotland, for that matter)... we could sing about it all day, but we still have to pay the venue bill.

Programming - Via Brooklyn makes it a mission to bring accessible programming to the community to foster conversation around the major issues each of our plays brings to light. In the past these programs have included lectures, film screenings, and murder mystery parties. In the future…stay tuned…but it’s going to be GOOD.

The Impact

You can have a true impact on this piece of theater. On a practical level, your generous donation will help us to support the vision of our creative collaborators in bringing Monica to life here in New York and across the pond in Scotland. But your impact is so much bigger than that.

This play hits close to home for us, both personally and nationally. Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky puts a badass, female, powerhouse protagonist center stage. Through a series of intimate scenes, Monica’s relationships, identity, privacy, and sense of self worth are constantly challenged. But Monica is no victim. Monica takes ownership of her own story, speaks up, and never settles for less. In doing so she serves as a strong role model for any woman or person who feels unheard, unseen, or alone. That’s the true impact of this play and the impact of your support. 

Risks & Challenges

Making theater in New York (or anywhere...) is always a challenge. It's (distressingly) expensive, it's (unfortunately) competitive, and, no matter what, it will always (always, always…) cost more than you think it will. We are well aware. But we will never allow that expense to impede our ability to pay our artists and bring powerful new pieces of theater to the stage. We know it's risky. But the promise to produce visionary theatrical work and accessible programming is the backbone of our organization.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word. Tell your friends, tell your friends' friends, and then tell those friends to tell their friends. If you cannot donate at this time, trust us, we get it, we're artists- we just ask you to share our IndieGoGo page and join us for the premier of Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky in 2019!
story_txt: The PlayVia Brooklyn is excited to announce their production of Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky by Dianne Nora. With a strong female protagonist at the helm, Monica:This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky will guide you through a narrative of empowerment and bravery. It's a provocative, risky, and thought provoking piece about a woman fighting to be heard and taking ownership of her own story. Sound familiar? That's because it is. (#MeToo, #BelieveWomen). You've heard her story before through newspapers and videocameras, but this is your chance to see it in an entirely new light. Monica is a play for now and we need your help putting it on stage now. Where We're HeadedVia Brooklyn is a Brooklyn-based 501(c)3 not-for-profit pending theatre company. We develop theatrical productions, coupled with interactive programming, to engage audiences around the world. Our mission is to foster enthusiasm, contemplation, and community by blurring the traditional lines between the stage and other art media. Our goal for Monica is, as our mission states, develop the play here in New York and then, bring it elsewhere. Where? We're glad you asked: Scotland, the 2019 Edinburgh Fringe Festival to be exact. As we launch our pre-production efforts for Monica, and bring on board a strong team of collaborators, we greatly appreciate any and all support.What We NeedEvery dime donated will support the following:Paying the Talent - At Via Brooklyn paying our talent is not optional. (And we mean it- we firmly believe artists need to be paid, and paid in a timely manner). Your donation will support the creativity of our actors, director, playwright, stage manager, set designer, costume designer, light designer, sound designer, projection designer, assistants, dressers, and anyone else that helps us bring Monica from the page to the stage.Paying for the Theatre - *Insert lyrics from the hit musical RENT*"How we gonna pay [...]Last year's rentThis year's rentNext year's rentRent rent rent rent rent"! So yeah, about the cost of rent in New York City (and Scotland, for that matter)... we could sing about it all day, but we still have to pay the venue bill.Programming - Via Brooklyn makes it a mission to bring accessible programming to the community to foster conversation around the major issues each of our plays brings to light. In the past these programs have included lectures, film screenings, and murder mystery parties. In the future…stay tuned…but it’s going to be GOOD.The ImpactYou can have a true impact on this piece of theater. On a practical level, your generous donation will help us to support the vision of our creative collaborators in bringing Monica to life here in New York and across the pond in Scotland. But your impact is so much bigger than that.This play hits close to home for us, both personally and nationally. Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky puts a badass, female, powerhouse protagonist center stage. Through a series of intimate scenes, Monica’s relationships, identity, privacy, and sense of self worth are constantly challenged. But Monica is no victim. Monica takes ownership of her own story, speaks up, and never settles for less. It's (distressingly) expensive, it's (unfortunately) competitive, and, no matter what, it will always (always, always…) cost more than you think it will. We are well aware. But we will never allow that expense to impede our ability to pay our artists and bring powerful new pieces of theater to the stage. We know it's risky. But the promise to produce visionary theatrical work and accessible programming is the backbone of our organization.Other Ways You Can HelpPlease spread the word. Tell your friends, tell your friends' friends, and then tell those friends to tell their friends. If you cannot donate at this time, trust us, we get it, we're artists- we just ask you to share our IndieGoGo page and join us for the premier of Monica: This Play Is Not About Monica Lewinsky in 2019!

story:
Shelly Hawkins-Artistic Director

Shelly Hawkins is a dancer, teacher, and choreographer who has called Tucson her home since 2003. Shelly has danced for Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines and was a principal dancer with Tucson’s Artifact Dance Project.  She has choreographed for both the proscenium stage and non-traditional spaces including the Tucson Museum of Art and the Phoenix Art Museum. Shelly received her Masters of Fine Arts from the University of Arizona School of Dance with an emphasis in choreography and performance and was the recipient of the Outstanding Teaching Assistant Award for the College of Fine Arts. She has taught both major level and non-major level dance classes at UA, and University of Nevada Las Vegas.

Shelly’s choreographic style is contemporary, inventive and expressive, and is influenced by Giordano jazz and Lewitzky modern techniques. Her work is often non-narrative, though typically expresses an evolution or journey. Thematically, her work reflects ideas of feminism, transformation, the afterlife, and an exploration of truth and reality. 

Our Mission

Hawkinsdance seeks to contribute to the growth of the Tucson arts community and the collective American cultural landscape through its commitment to the propagation of new choreographic works. We believe that generating new work creates the opportunity for human connection, and is not only fundamental to enriching our community but essential to expressing the ideas and values of this age. We value unbridled creative expression and pursue the horizons of our potential in order to contribute to the forward progression of the universal and ageless art form of dance. 

What We Need & What You Get

Hawkinsdance is extremely excited to present our first self-produced show, The People Electric. A self-produced contemporary dance show involves many different moving parts, our incredible dancers, theatre rental, lighting, music, flooring, rehearsal costs, advertising, etc. Dance is a physical art form, utilizing human bodies as the visual medium and Hawkinsdance has hired nine professional dancers for our first show. We are proud to offer fair wages to our dancers because we understand the importance of paying artist what they deserve. As a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization we consider everyone who makes a donation to be a collaborator and a Hawkinsdance family member. The total cost to produce our show is $20,000. With close to half of that goal being met, we have $10,000 left to raise to be able to meet our goal. We are proud to offer certain perks to our donors who meet levels of $15, $60, $120, $300, and $1000. These perks include custom rehearsal footage, Hawkinsdance logo stickers, Hawkinsdance t-shirts, signed photo prints from one of our company members, and two tickets to the main event: The People Electric. ANY and ALL donations are appreciated and support the creation of new contemporary dance!

Risks & Challenges

Historically, dance companies in the United States were able to receive federal funding in the form of grants from the National Endowment for the Arts. As arts funding has been significantly cut over the years, funding for dance companies, especially smaller local organizations, has become almost nonexistent, with the bulk of the funding going to the largest institutions.  By the time the leftover funds trickle down to medium and smaller sized companies, the amount left is minimal at best.  One of the biggest risks involved with starting a dance company and producing a show is doing so without sufficient government funding. This is where our donors and collaborators play a crucial role!

Your donation allows us to offer our dancers paid contracts. Most contemporary artists use non-living materials to produce their artwork, whether that be oil paints, watercolors, sculpting materials, technology, etc. As a contemporary dance company, our work is collaborative in nature, where the role of a dancer in the rehearsal and performance processes is crucial.

Shelly Hawkins has successfully started Hawkinsdance and been commissioned to do several works in the company’s first year. Some of Hawkinsdance’s past performances include:

  • Residency at the Tucson Museum of Art for the Arizona Biennial 2018 Exhibition. Hawkinsdance was featured in three events, featuring site-specific works created for the museum
  • Shelly Hawkins is the recipient of stART Grant, presented by the Arts Foundation for Tucson and Southern Arizona
  • Selected for the Breaking Ground Dance and Film Festival, with Hawkinsdance being commissioned for original work at this years’ festival
  • Collaborated with local musicians Jillian Bessett and Anton Faynberg to perform original work alongside their original compositions
  • Created Current Exhibitions, a Hawkinsdance original film at the Tucson Museum of Art, directed by Shelly Hawkins with videography by Julius Schlosberg
  • Community Performances at JCC, Club Congress, Tucson Museum of Art, Tempe Festival of the Arts, and the Phoenix Art Museum

Other Ways You Can Help

While donations of any size big or small will help us reach our goal, there are other ways that you can help contribute!

  • Share our Indiegogo campaign! The power of social media is real and the more people that we can share our mission with, the better
  • Attend our show! The People Electric will be presented at the March 15th-17th at the Scoundrel and Scamp Theatre at the Historic Y in Tucson, Arizona. Tickets available at https://hawkinsdance.brownpapertickets.com
  • Like our Facebook page and follow us on Instagram!
    • Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/hawkinsdance
    • Instagram: @hawkinsdance
  • Make an in-kind donation. Want to donate rehearsal or performance space, or items for a fundraising event? Contact Artistic Director Shelly Hawkins at Shelly@hawkinsdance.org. 
  • Volunteer! Time donations are just as valuable as monetary donations. Email shelly@hawkinsdance.org to inquire about volunteer opportunities

Share our Indiegogo campaign! The power of social media is real and the more people that we can share our mission with, the better
Attend our show! The People Electric will be presented at the March 15th-17th at the Scoundrel and Scamp Theatre at the Historic Y in Tucson, Arizona. Tickets available at https://hawkinsdance.brownpapertickets.com

Like our Facebook page and follow us on Instagram!
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/hawkinsdance

Instagram: @hawkinsdance


Make an in-kind donation. Want to donate rehearsal or performance space, or items for a fundraising event? Contact Artistic Director Shelly Hawkins at Shelly@hawkinsdance.org. 
Volunteer! Time donations are just as valuable as monetary donations. Email shelly@hawkinsdance.org to inquire about volunteer opportunities

story:
THE ROARING ONES

An interactive performance that takes stories from the audience and brings them to life on stage.

 

About us

Hello!

My name's Madeline, I'm a Chicago area director, actor, and theatre-maker mounting a unique piece of theatre in Chicago called "The Roaring Ones". The show premiers at the Prop Thtr in the Rhinoceros Theatre Festival, opening late January 2019. 

This project is a collision of passions; improvisation, dance, movement, music, all with a Bacchic flourish. I've assembled a roster of amazing artistic collaborators and we cannot wait to show you our work.

My fledgling Theatre company, Labyrinth Arts Underground, needs a push from the nest- and we would be honored to receive that shove from YOU!

 

The Breakdown

Funds will cover

  • Rehearsal space - $125 
  • Actor rehearsal stipends - $300 ($50 per actor)
  • Costumes and props - $100
  • Print materials (such as art work, posters, advertisements, programs) -$75

 

The Impact

The level of commitment that these actors have put into this show is equivalent to taking on a part-time job in addition to the jobs they already work! Paying a rehearsal stipend, clothing them in appropriate performance attire, and ensuring a respectable, reliable rehearsal space are just a few ways to thank them for the work they have done, and continue to do.

Aside from being able to provide my ensemble with an appropriate baseline, support from friends, family, and theatre-lovers means the world to me! Building a show like this from scratch takes time, energy, blood, sweat, and tears- having a network of people who believe in that is incredibly important.

Transforming art from concept to reality is a true gift!

 

The Details

The show opens Saturday, January 19th at 9:00pm and runs each Saturday night until February 23rd.

We perform at the front studio at the Prop Thtr, an experimental theatre venue in Chicago's Avondale neighborhood: 3502 N Elston Ave, Chicago, IL 60618.

For more information about the Rhinoceros Theatre Festival, or to purchase tickets, visit https://Rhinofest.com.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's okay... but there are other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about THE ROARING ONES!
  • Like and share my promotion posts!
  • Come to Rhinofest!
  • Share this campaign on social media!

story:
Short Summary

Night Shadows — Or, One Hundred Million Voices Shouting focuses on the life of Russian poet Anna Akhmatova, just prior to, during, and after the Russian revolution. In the play she is keeping her promise to tell of “the true twentieth century”—of lives disrupted, her poetry banned, and so many loved ones lost under Stalin’s brutal regime.

We are raising funds to bring our play about this poet's heartbreaking and inspiring life, a story that resonates with the world we are living in now, to the On Women Festival at the Irondale Center in Brooklyn for performances March 11th through 14th, 2020.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a minimum of $4500 to pay salaries and cover publicity, scripts, programs, and art for the production. All who donate will be mentioned in the program and we offer various small gifts in return, starting with our gratitude and ranging from signed programs from the show, tickets to opening night, and a variety of material related to Akhmatova's poetry,

With director Scott Klavan, we are assembling a most astonishing cast (soon to be announced here), and after two staged readings (at Emerging Artists Theatre in 2017 and HB Playwrights Theatre in 2018), we are very excited to now have a full production.

The Impact

One of Akhmatova’s challenges was to remain an artist and speak up through her poetry at a time when it was not allowed and was even life-threatening, both to her and those close to her.  It just might inspire us all to speak up in whatever way we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please do come to see the play: March 11 to 14th at Irondale Center in Brooklyn.  And spread the word! That is the ultimate support.

story:
Clarification Theatre Company

We're Courtney Henson and Hazel Mayall, founders of Clarification Theatre Company. We're both graduates from the Arts University Bournemouth who have one common consuming passion - to illuminate difficult issues for local communities. Our productions will be created with an aim to shed light on topics that seemed so important as children in school assemblies but now have floated into the back of our minds as adults.

Clarification's first production, Of Hemlock I Had Drunk, is a performance of tension and certain uncertainty. It is an exploration of mortality and questions both society's impulse control and our fascination with death. It is a play very close to the heart of its writer, co-founder Hazel Mayall, who has an Autism Spectrum Disorder diagnosis and, because of the way her brain works, has constantly struggled with the concept of death. It's an incredibly important production to both her and the company, so any help to get this to wider audiences will be so very gratefully received.

We believe our play will make a difference. Help make that difference by donating.

 

How your donation will help us:

We're looking to raise £1000 to cover our company's start up costs.

This includes:

  • Rehearsal spaces - We're hoping to put some of the money raised back into the community by supporting venues like The Crumbs Project in Bournemouth, which "is a charity which provides training for independence for adults with learning disabilities, mental health issues and stabilized addictions." The money they receive from room hire is put directly "back into the project to support people with special life challenges to have better life chances." We think that would be a great use of your money - helping charity and helping our company rehearse is a two in one benefit!
  • Advertising Material - Word of mouth is unbelievably helpful, but we need posters, business cards, fliers, etc. to get the word out. We might have a play, a director, and a full cast, but we still need the most important element: An Audience!
  • Paying our Cast and Crew - Our lovely actors are taking time out, (some even using up work holiday!) to join us on this journey. We want to pay them for their time and pay them fairly too! We also have other people currently involved working on sound, video, and graphic design and we think they deserve to be paid for their brilliant work! We want to start as we mean to go on.
  • Venues - Venues aren't free, nor are they cheap. If we want to hire out a venue to be able to put on our previews and full show, we'll need the money!
  • Transportation - Until we have a company minibus (...and when one of us learns to drive), we'll need to use the dreaded public transportation. Trains and busses will be taken by all members of the cast from a variety of locations. We will use money raised to reimburse transportation costs.
  • Registering as a Company - Basically, everything about starting a theatre company costs a lot of money, including, well, being a company in the first place!

So as you can see, we have a lot to put your money towards - Every bit of spare change counts!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have no money to spare, please share this fundraiser around - tell all your friends!

(And if you can pool together to raise a little to donate, we will be unbelievably grateful. Forever.)

(We mean it.)
