story:
Ella in the Tundra

Synopsis:

Ella, a world class fertility doctor, specializes in the latest cryo-freezing technologies and also happens to be every cursed princess's fairy godmother. Ella's perfectly controlled world gets turned upside down with the appearance of a most unusual patient who also happens to be a convicted criminal about to go to prison.

 

Learn more about the show in this video interview:

 

 

Origin of the Play:

“I was first inspired to write this play as a result of endless bombardment by Facebook ads terrorizing me to freeze my eggs immediately. Facebook's marketing algorithm had pinpointed me as among the target demographic of women who should be most fearful of their pending reproductive demise. This contemporary fertility anxiety, in part constructed by recent medical technologies and statistics, is compounded by my upbringing in a Russian Jewish family with traditional folkloric and existential values of the woman as the baby-maker. Her value and meaning are derived from her ability to make babies...

So without the babies what is there?”

-Marianna Staroselsky

 

A bit about the production:

Ella in the Tundra is a dynamic, theatrical exploration of female identity in modern-day life. The play is Marianna Staroselsky’s Columbia University MFA thesis under the mentorship of Jocelyn Clarke. Ella in the Tundra will go up as a full production at Signature Theater May 2-4, 2019 as part of Columbia’s New Plays Festival 2019. A collaborative, female-led production written by Marianna Staroselsky and directed by Daniella Caggiano, the all star all-female design team includes sound designer Bryn Scharenberg, lighting designer Krista Smith, set designer Emona Stoykova, and costume designer Nina Vartanian. The production features an equally all star all-female cast including Angela Batuure (Ensemble,) Rivka Borek (Dr. Ella Sinta,) Megan Paradis Hanley (Ensemble,) JessAnn Smith (Ensemble,) and Gabriela Urquia (Jennifer Guavaro,) and integrates fairytale, naturalism, and high-tech science.

 

Why we need your help:

First off, we hope to pay all of our brilliant actors and creative staff more so that they can do the wonderful work that they do. We are in rehearsals for about 5-6 days a week until the performances in early May to create as beautiful and developed a show as possible. Second, designers Emona, Krista, and Nina are creating brilliant designs for set, lighting, and costuming that live between fantastical and medical worlds and we will need your support in order to get these designs as fully realized as we can.

Your support means the world to us!

We are pleased to offer you the some amazing incentives as a thank you for your donation.

Thanks a million,

Ella in the Tundra Team

 

 

Who we are:

Marianna Staroselsky (Playwright) (MFA - Columbia University, ‘19, PhD - University of Chicago, ‘19) writes, teaches, and makes art about identity and the strangeness of being a person in modern society. Her full-length projects, produced and developed in New York City and Chicago include "Cry Baby Meets Audrey Hepburn,"(20% Theatre Company, Cornservatory, Tikkun Fellowship, 2016,) "How I Married Myself and Other Misadventures," (The New Colony, Athena Theatre Company, Columbia University School of the Arts, 2015-18,) “Simulacrum,” an opera libretto (Path New Music Theater, 3LD, 2018) and "100 Awkward Ways to Be a Person" (Columbia University School of the Arts, La MaMa, 2017-18, Rising Sun Performance Company, 2018.) “Ella in the Tundra” was first conceived at Casa na Ilha Artist Residency in the heat of the Brazilian sun.

Daniella Caggiano (Director) is a freelance director and native New Yorker. She was named one of The Interval's Women to Watch in 2016 and is a former MTC Directing Fellow, the recipient of a 2018 Drama League Residency, and an alum of Labyrinth’s Ensemble Workshop and the Lincoln Center Directors Lab. She has directed at Joe's Pub, The Flea, Dixon Place, Ugly Rhino, WOW Cafe, Musical Theatre Factory, Merkin Concert Hall, The Kraine, Le Poisson Rouge, HERE, FringeNYC, and 54 Below among others. Favorite projects include Next To Normal (benefit presentation starring Tony nom. Christiane Noll), Vinegar Tom, and an original adaptation of Macbeth. She has been the Assistant or Associate Director to Leigh Silverman, Rebecca Taichman, and Daniella Topol. MFA The New School for Drama, BA Sarah Lawrence College www.daniellacaggiano.com

Creative Team: James Monaghan (Dramaturg), Jonathan Gelb (Producer), Daniel Vaughn* (Stage Manager), Emona Stoykova (Set Designer), Nina Vartanian (Costume Designer), Bryn Scharenberg (Sound Designer), Krista Smith (Lighting Designer)

Cast: Angela Batuure, Rivka Borek*, Megan Paradis Hanley, JessAnn Smith*, Gabi Urquia

*Appearing courtesy of Actor's Equity
story_txt: Ella in the TundraSynopsis:Ella, a world class fertility doctor, specializes in the latest cryo-freezing technologies and also happens to be every cursed princess's fairy godmother. Ella's perfectly controlled world gets turned upside down with the appearance of a most unusual patient who also happens to be a convicted criminal about to go to prison. Learn more about the show in this video interview:  Origin of the Play:“I was first inspired to write this play as a result of endless bombardment by Facebook ads terrorizing me to freeze my eggs immediately. Facebook's marketing algorithm had pinpointed me as among the target demographic of women who should be most fearful of their pending reproductive demise. This contemporary fertility anxiety, in part constructed by recent medical technologies and statistics, is compounded by my upbringing in a Russian Jewish family with traditional folkloric and existential values of the woman as the baby-maker. Her value and meaning are derived from her ability to make babies...So without the babies what is there?”-Marianna Staroselsky A bit about the production:Ella in the Tundra is a dynamic, theatrical exploration of female identity in modern-day life. The play is Marianna Staroselsky’s Columbia University MFA thesis under the mentorship of Jocelyn Clarke. story:
Galway Tix on Sale

https://tinyurl.com/Galwayrunaway

 

Runaway Princess is a story of transformation..of hope.

Support the arts....please 

Just released 

 

For Immediate Release

Press Contact: Betsyann Faiella at SavoyPR

bafaiella@savoypr.com or phone/text: 1.310.283.2415 (USA)

“Runaway Princess, a Hopeful Tale of Heroin, Hooking and Happiness” Comes to Galway Fringe

Mary Goggin’s Multiple Award Winning Show Plays July 23rd through July 28th

June 19 – (NEW YORK, NY) “Once upon a time, there was a Princess born to a King and Queen who were banished from their island, forced to flee to America in a coffin ship.” Thus begins the tale of the Runaway Princess… in which Mary Goggin shares a true story, laced with wicked humor and much pathos, of her Irish Catholic upbringing, drug addiction and prostitution, and the multitude of characters she encountered along the way to ultimately finding joy. Goggin brings Runaway Princess, A Hopeful Tale of Heroin, Hooking and Happiness to Galway Fringe from July 23rd through July 28th. The play, which swept up three awards at United Solo Festival 2018 in New York City (Best Storyteller, Solo Critics Choice, Best Seller), will run for six performances at The Loft, 7 Bridge Street. All performances are at 3pm, and all tickets are 12€.

 

“Miss Goggin injects effortless humor into a masterful story of drugs, homelessness and prostitution… from Ireland to the Bronx she vividly describes the debaucheries of the 70s…the story of someone who has come into herself.” All About Solo Critics Choice.

 

Mary Patricia Goggin’s family hails from Schull, Co Cork and Bangor Erris, Co Mayo (God help us!). Her parents emigrated from Ireland to the Bronx, New York, where Mary was born in the 1950s. She returned in her teens to live with her aunt and continue her education with the nuns in Glasnevin, before leaving again for New York where she went on to forge a successful career as an actor on stage and in film for 20 years. Goggin is delighted to make her Galway Fringe debut with Runaway Princess.

 

Her favorite recent roles include “Ella O’Neill” (mother of Eugene O’Neill) in Ann Hansen’s “Road to Babylon,” in the Broadway Bound Festival. She has enjoyed being directed by Cyndy Marion in numerous Tennessee Williams works including, Cavalier for M’Lady, Clothes For A Summer Hotel and A Perfect Analysis Given by a Parrot. Mary appeared in PB & J for the NY Fringe Festival and Born to be Blue, a winner in the Samuel French Festival. Her favorite TV roles include spots in Broad City, Law and Order, Guiding Light, The Grind (Amazon). Favorite film roles include Little Children, MAD (soon to be released), The Trouble with Bliss, Gasoline, Bronx Paradise. Mary is the recent winner of the Best Actress Award at The NJ Recovery Film Festival for her role in Reservations, a film by Jeanine Flynn, directed by Neal Hemphill.

 

Dan Ruth (Director) is an award-winning actor and performance artist. His solo play, A Life Behind Bars, has been produced in New York City, Los Angeles and around the country, and is the winner of the 2016 United Solo Festival Award for “Best Autobiographical Show,” The 2018 Bistro Award winner for “Outstanding Solo Play,” MAC Award for “Best Spoken Word Artist” and the 2018 Producers Encore Award from the Hollywood Fringe Festival. Dan has directed both regionally and in NYC where he also served as a core director for The A-Train Plays at the Sanford Meisner Theatre.

@danruthbkny

 

Established in 2013, the unique Galway Fringe Festival is a boutique multidisciplinary arts festival based in Galway City. It includes theatre, art, live music, and comedy in venues spread out all over the city, and brings international artists together with some of Galway’s best local talent.

 

WHAT: Runaway Princess, a Hopeful Tale of Heroin, Hooking and Happiness

WHO: Written and performed by Mary Goggin. Directed by Dan Ruth

WHERE: Galway Fringe Festival, The LOFT, 7 Bridge Street

WHEN: July 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28 at 3pm

TICKETS: Call 86 066 5756 or email info@galwayfringe.ie

COST: 12€.

FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT:

VISIT MARY GOGGIN: http://marygoggin.com

http://runawayprincessplay.com

Twitter: @marypat218

Instagram: @ Marypat218

FB: runawayprincesplay

 

###

 

Grateful for you 

The Impact of Runaway Princess

Simply put if I bypassed talking about the things I did when I was drunk and high. I’d still be drunk and high. Self-honesty is the key.

I am only as sick as my secrets.

Drug use is a symptom of a soul sickness a sickness that is, in our culture, very often treated with other drugs…for example Methadone and Narcan.

Don’t talk and don’t die.

I say talk about it.

Runaway Princess is, I hope, is gracefully honest. We need to talk about everything. This I hope, is achieved in RP; sharing what I did as opposed to preaching...walking the walk. Do what I do....not what I say.  Oh, and when you see the show…its ok to laugh…I know its wicked.

Isolation and the inability to communicate are the hallmark traits of addiction.

I can only speak for myself. When I first got sober I was like an open wound and the only word I knew was fuck!

Now after a lot of work on myself including 27 years of therapy. I have a feelings vocabulary and a voice and I am funny as hell.

And most of all grateful.

Boy, did I learn to communicate and I am not alone.

My wickedly funny ..absolutely true Solo Show was written in 2017,

Written to give others permission to share their secrets, to know they are not alone.

I need to reach those that may not ever make it to a meeting (or a shrink) and die.

I am and have been a professional actor for 20 years.

I’d been sober a year and attended this retreat in Garrison, New York for recovering alcoholic women. I sat down with this nun, she asked, “Are you an actor?” I said, “Yeah, I wish.” That’s when I realized that is what I wish! When I started doing theater I found it. I found out who I was. When I was a child I wanted to be an archeologist. I now realize my need to dig for the truth is fulfilled thru my work. I knew I had this show in me…now sober 31 years. I knew that my comedic timing and self-knowledge could heal myself and others. Which is what I was born to do. Why I am still here after this tale of heroin, hooking and happiness.

I was told to keep doing my show (of course the sold out shows and awards helped)

  • I put all my resources to create RP and bring it this far.
  • Contributors help support an antedote to the opiod crisis. To keep it going, keep the story being told.
  • The money is for airfare to Shannon for the Galway Fringe.
  • Its for air fare and accommodations for 10 days, I need to hire Stage Manager and Tech for sound and lights. 
  • If there is money left over I am doing the Charm City (Baltimore) Fringe  October 10th to 20th..Check my websites for details/updates
  • www.marygoggin.com
  • www.runawayprincessplay.com

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give $. Please pass it on.

There are 2 NYC shows in August, If you havent already, please come. If  you cannot afford please contact me.

https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/4268404

story:
Short Summary

Είμαστε η Ζωή και η Σοφία. Ξεκινήσαμε τη συνεργασία μας τον Ιούλιο του 2019. Το project που ετοιμάζουμε ονομάζεται: «Μέσα στο πλήρες, συναντάμε εμάς» και θα παρουσιαστεί για πρώτη φορά στο Φεστιβάλ Χορού στο θέατρο στο Τρένο στο Ρουφ το Σεπτέμβριο του 2019. Παρακάτω, θα βρείτε αναλυτική περιγραφή του project. 

We are Zoi and Sofia. We are both dancers. We created our dance idea during the period of 2018-2019. We got invited to a unique greek dance festival in a train to perform in September 2019. 

For English description please scroll down.

 

  • Το πλήρες (plenum), είναι το αντίθετο του κενού. Μιλάμε για το plenum του καθένα μας. Εκείνη τη στιγμή που και οι δύο βρίσκονται στον πυρήνα του plenum, που δεν είναι τίποτα άλλο παρά το μέσο του κενού. Εκείνες τις στιγμές που ο καθένας, σε μία αδιάκοπη προσπάθεια κατάκτησης της ανεξαρτησίας, δεν επιβιώνει χωρίς τον άλλον. Ο σημαντικός Άλλος είναι εκείνος που επηρεάζει τη σκέψη, τα συναισθήματα. Είναι εκείνος που κατασκευάζει την πραγματικότητα. Σε έναν άδειο χώρο, παραδομένο στην απλότητά του, δεσμεύονται και καθρεφτίζονται όλα. Δεσμευόμαστε εμείς και μέσω της επαφής, μελετάμε τις σχέσεις κάτω από την επιφάνεια. Τις σχέσεις μέσα μας, όπου εγώ και οι Άλλοι νοηματοδοτούμε την ενθάρρυνση, την υποστήριξη, την εμπιστοσύνη. Μία σχέση μοναδικότητας, μία σχέση της οποίας τα θεμέλια βρίσκονται στη μοναχικότητα του καθένα. Μία σχέση πλήρης και ταυτόχρονα μετέωρη. Δύσκολη στις ισορροπίες. 

 

Ο κύκλος ολοκληρώνεται. Έχοντας παρουσιάσει δύο παραστάσεις, συμπληρωματικές μεταξύ τους, το Σεπτέμβριο θα παρουσιαστεί μία 30λεπτη ολοκληρωμένη παράσταση στο Κεντρικό Stage στην αποβάθρα του τρένου. 

 

Οι δύο προηγούμενες παραστάσεις ενώνονται και παρουσιάζονται στην αποβάθρα του Τρένου. Πρόκειται για μία ωδή στο χορό και τη σύνδεση της εσωτερικότητας δύο γυναικών με τον κόσμο που δημιουργείται γύρω τους και μεταξύ τους.

Αυτή τη φορά συνυπάρχουν δύο γυναίκες στη σκηνή. 

Πρόκειται για τη μεταβίβαση και το «μοίρασμα» εμπειριών δύο γυναικών.

Σ' έναν κόσμο μοναχικότητας, εμείς δημιουργούμε μαζί. Μια συνάντηση που οδηγεί στη μεταβίβαση, στο μοίρασμα, στη συλλογικότητα.

ΣΥΝΤΕΛΕΣΤΕΣ:

Ιδέα/Σύλληψη: Ζωή Ευσταθίου

Χορογραφία/Ερμηνεία: Ζωή Ευσταθίου, Σοφία Μαρτίου

Σύνθεση: Fabian Fiorini

Ακούγεται το κομμάτι «Echoes of a Distance»

Σύνθεση: Αθηνά Ρούτση, Claudia Matola 

Rhodes: Άλκηστις Ραυτοπούλου 

Ηχογράφηση: Φώτης Μυλωνάς 

Ακούγεται το κομμάτι «Summer13» 

Μουσική: Αλεξάνδρα Παπαναστασίου 

Στίχοι: Ιωάννα Κουγεντάκη 

Ερμηνεία: Αθηνά Ρούτση 

 

Κοστούμια: Ελλάδα Δαμιανού

Special thanks to: Kinitiras Artistic Network for Performing Arts

 

  • Η συμβολή σας σε αυτό το έργο θα μας βοηθήσει να πετύχουμε τους στόχους μας και να υλοποιήσουμε τις ιδέες μας. Θα μας βοηθήσετε να νοικιάσουμε ένα στούντιο χορού για πρόβες. Οι πρόβες είναι πολύ σημαντικές στη διαδικασία δημιουργίας. Οι απαιτήσεις του φεστιβάλ είναι πολύ υψηλές και θέλουμε να παρουσιάσουμε μια παράσταση που να αντιστοιχεί σε αυτό το επίπεδο. Ωστόσο, καθώς δεν διαθέτουμε χρηματοδότηση, το κόστος ενοικίασης χώρου είναι ιδιαίτερα σημαντικό και είναι αδύνατο να το καλύψουμε χωρίς τη βοήθειά σας. Επίσης, θα μας βοηθήσετε να σχεδιάζουμε και να δημιουργήσουμε κοστούμια υψηλής ποιότητας. Η σχεδιάστρια των κοστουμιών είναι μία ανερχόμενη σχεδιάστρια που ζει και εργάζεται στο Βέλγιο. Ωστόσο, τα υφάσματα και ο σχεδιασμός είναι μια πολύ σημαντική και χρονοβόρα διαδικασία. Με τη βοήθειά σας, τα υφάσματα θα αγοραστούν και θα βοηθήσετε στη δημιουργική διαδικασία της κατασκευής των κοστουμιών μας. Κλείνοντας, θα μας βοηθήσετε στο σχεδιασμό φωτισμού. Αυτή είναι η πρώτη φορά που θα δημιουργήσουμε μια παράσταση που δεν είναι site-specific και θα είναι στη σκηνή. Ως εκ τούτου, είναι απαραίτητο να συνεργαστούμε με έναν τεχνικό φωτισμού.

 

English Description

  • `We find each other in the plenum` is a duet. The full (plenum) is the opposite of the vacuum. We are talking about the plenum of each one of us. At that moment both are in the core of the plenum, which is nothing but the middle of the vacuum. Those moments when everyone, in an unremitting effort to gain independence, does not survive without the other. The important Other is the one that affects my thoughts, my feelings. She is the one who creates my reality. In an empty space, surrendered to its simplicity,everything is reflected. We commit ourselves and through contact, we research relationships under the surface. The relationships within us, which give a meaning to encouragement, support, trust. A complete and at the same time unrelated relationship. Difficult to balance.

    The circle is completed. Having presented two performances, complementary to each other, a 30-minute complete show at the Central Stage of the theater `The Train At Rouf``will be presented in September.
     
    In July 2019 there was an audition held to choose the dancer who will be with me on this creative journey.  I got very lucky to meet and finally collaborate with Sofia. The purpose of this performance is to create the base for a longer-lasting project, which will be sent to festivals in Greece and the rest of Europe. 

In a world of loneliness, we create together.

 

  • Contributing in this project will help us to achieve our goals and make our ideas true. You`ll help us renting a dance studio to rehearse. Rehearsals are very important in our creating process.  The requirements of the festival are very high and we want to present a performance that corresponds to the level of the festival. However, as soon as we do not have any funding, the cost of renting a space is particularly important and it is impossible to cover it without your help.  Also, You`ll help us to design and create high quality costumes.   The costume designer is a rising Greek designer who lives and works in Belgium. However, fabrics and design, as well as sewing costumes is a very important and time-consuming process. With your help, the fabrics will be purchased and you will help in the creative process of creating our costumes.  In closing, you will help us with lighting design. This is the first time we will create a show that is not site-specific and will be on the stage. Therefore, it is necessary to cooperate with a lighting technician who specializes in lighting design.

 

Βιογραφικά:

Zoi Efstathiou was born in Greece in 1989. She graduated from the Professional Dance School of Niki Kontaxaki- Nikoletta Bakali in Athens (2010). She is a dancer of ROSAS Dance Company of Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker.

ROSAS Company - Anne Teresa De Keersameker / dancer

Company  Michèle Noiret / dancer

Company "Bud Blumenthal " / dancer
New creation "Leaves of Grass"

Dominique Duszynski / Co-creator - Dancer
Performed the pieces"Sous Les Pants" (2010) , "Sotto Voces "(2011),"Walkabout" (2014). Created and Performed the duet" RIFF" (2012-2015)

Created and Presented her own work in progress "Mr Gingerbread Man"( Preview in Buhnenwerkstatt Festival in Graz and Belgian Premiere in Volksroom Studio on 12/11/12). Created and Presented `9 NiNe` and  `CHAPTER I` (2014-2015) Created the piece "Tie Me In Series in collaboration with Mafalda Deville
Performed for the opening ceremony of the Festival "Life Awards" in the Concert Hall of Athens

Education

"Niki's Kontaxaki" Nikoletta's Bakali Private Professional School of Dance.

Dancer - Choreographer - Teacher of Ballet and Contemporary Dance - Classical Ballet (RAD) - Improvisation - Contemporary Dance - Choreography - Classical Ballet And Contemporary Dance Theory - Anatomy - Music - Rhythmics

Recipient of a Scholarship for the three years Professional Studies

Workshops

P.A.R.T.S's Summer School

lmpulzTanz Festival Nordine Benchorf '& Beniamin Boar (ROSAS) - "DIE GROSSE FUGUE"

Marta Coronado (ROSAS) - Roberto Olivan "DRUMMING"

Samantha Van Wissen (ROSAS) - "ROSAS DANST ROSAS"

Julyen Hamilton, Thierry Smits, David Zambrano,
Mafalda Deville, lñaki Aspillaga (Ultima Vez),
Marielle Morales, Les Slovaks, Saju Here (Akram Khan), Rasmus Olme, German Jauregui, Ted Stoffer, Jozsef Csaba Hajser, Kenji Takagi (Pina Bausch)

Certifications

ADVANCED II (Royal Academy Of Dance)

Sofia Martiou was born in Volos in 1995. From a very early age she has been involved in Rhythmic Gymnastics and TAE KWON DO at the championship level with many achievements. In 2013 she became a student of the Athens Gymnastics Academy and was selected by SEAD Dance School Austria. In 2017 she graduated from the National school of dance (KSOT). She has collaborated with Hellenic Dance Company for the production of “TOMORROW” at Athens Concert Hall by dancing two pieces of famous choreographers such as Martha Graham
“STEPS IN THE STREET” and Anthony LACHKY “SPECIAL GALA”. In 2018 she was selected by
FLUXUM FOUNDATION to produce “LA CREATION DU MONDE” at the Athens Concert Hall
and she was also a member of the group of S.Spyratou dancing in two theatrical productions
“THISEAS” and “DON QUIXOTE”.
She participates actively in workshops and seminars of contemporary dance both abroad
and in Greece with prominent dancers and choreographers.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help / Τρόποι με τους οποίους μπορείτε να συμβάλετε στην προσπάθειά μας

Αν δεν μπορείτε να συμβάλλετε οικονομικά, υπάρχουν τρόποι να μας βοηθήσετε να υλοποιήσουμε τις ιδέες μας.

Διαδώστε όσο θέλετε την ιδέα μας!

Θα είμαστε ιδιαίτερα ευτυχείς αν μπορείτε να μας βοηθήσετε παρέχοντας χώρο για τις πρόβες μας το χειμώνα του 2019.

If you can not contribute financially, however, there are ways to help us make our ideas a reality.

Spread the word as much as you like!!!!

We will be particularly pleased if you can help us by providing a space for our rehearsals.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Είμαστε η Ζωή και η Σοφία. Ξεκινήσαμε τη συνεργασία μας τον Ιούλιο του 2019. Το project που ετοιμάζουμε ονομάζεται: «Μέσα στο πλήρες, συναντάμε εμάς» και θα παρουσιαστεί για πρώτη φορά στο Φεστιβάλ Χορού στο θέατρο στο Τρένο στο Ρουφ το Σεπτέμβριο του 2019. Παρακάτω, θα βρείτε αναλυτική περιγραφή του project. 
We are Zoi and Sofia. We are both dancers. We created our dance idea during the period of 2018-2019. We got invited to a unique greek dance festival in a train to perform in September 2019. 
For English description please scroll down.
 
Το πλήρες (plenum), είναι το αντίθετο του κενού. Μιλάμε για το plenum του καθένα μας. Εκείνη τη στιγμή που και οι δύο βρίσκονται στον πυρήνα του plenum, που δεν είναι τίποτα άλλο παρά το μέσο του κενού. Εκείνες τις στιγμές που ο καθένας, σε μία αδιάκοπη προσπάθεια κατάκτησης της ανεξαρτησίας, δεν επιβιώνει χωρίς τον άλλον. Ο σημαντικός Άλλος είναι εκείνος που επηρεάζει τη σκέψη, τα συναισθήματα. Είναι εκείνος που κατασκευάζει την πραγματικότητα. Σε έναν άδειο χώρο, παραδομένο στην απλότητά του, δεσμεύονται και καθρεφτίζονται όλα. Δεσμευόμαστε εμείς και μέσω της επαφής, μελετάμε τις σχέσεις κάτω από την επιφάνεια. Τις σχέσεις μέσα μας, όπου εγώ και οι Άλλοι νοηματοδοτούμε την ενθάρρυνση, την υποστήριξη, την εμπιστοσύνη. Μία σχέση μοναδικότητας, μία σχέση της οποίας τα θεμέλια βρίσκονται στη μοναχικότητα του καθένα. Μία σχέση πλήρης και ταυτόχρονα μετέωρη. Δύσκολη στις ισορροπίες. 
 
Ο κύκλος ολοκληρώνεται. Έχοντας παρουσιάσει δύο παραστάσεις, συμπληρωματικές μεταξύ τους, το Σεπτέμβριο θα παρουσιαστεί μία 30λεπτη ολοκληρωμένη παράσταση στο Κεντρικό Stage στην αποβάθρα του τρένου. 
 
Οι δύο προηγούμενες παραστάσεις ενώνονται και παρουσιάζονται στην αποβάθρα του Τρένου. Πρόκειται για μία ωδή στο χορό και τη σύνδεση της εσωτερικότητας δύο γυναικών με τον κόσμο που δημιουργείται γύρω τους και μεταξύ τους.
Αυτή τη φορά συνυπάρχουν δύο γυναίκες στη σκηνή. 
Πρόκειται για τη μεταβίβαση και το «μοίρασμα» εμπειριών δύο γυναικών.
Σ' έναν κόσμο μοναχικότητας, εμείς δημιουργούμε μαζί. Μια συνάντηση που οδηγεί στη μεταβίβαση, στο μοίρασμα, στη συλλογικότητα.
ΣΥΝΤΕΛΕΣΤΕΣ:
Ιδέα/Σύλληψη: Ζωή Ευσταθίου
Χορογραφία/Ερμηνεία: Ζωή Ευσταθίου, Σοφία Μαρτίου
Σύνθεση: Fabian Fiorini
Ακούγεται το κομμάτι «Echoes of a Distance»
Σύνθεση: Αθηνά Ρούτση, Claudia Matola 
Rhodes: Άλκηστις Ραυτοπούλου 
Ηχογράφηση: Φώτης Μυλωνάς 
Ακούγεται το κομμάτι «Summer13» 
Μουσική: Αλεξάνδρα Παπαναστασίου 
Στίχοι: Ιωάννα Κουγεντάκη 
Ερμηνεία: Αθηνά Ρούτση 
 
Κοστούμια: Ελλάδα Δαμιανού
Special thanks to: Kinitiras Artistic Network for Performing Arts
 
Η συμβολή σας σε αυτό το έργο θα μας βοηθήσει να πετύχουμε τους στόχους μας και να υλοποιήσουμε τις ιδέες μας. Θα μας βοηθήσετε να νοικιάσουμε ένα στούντιο χορού για πρόβες. Οι πρόβες είναι πολύ σημαντικές στη διαδικασία δημιουργίας. Οι απαιτήσεις του φεστιβάλ είναι πολύ υψηλές και θέλουμε να παρουσιάσουμε μια παράσταση που να αντιστοιχεί σε αυτό το επίπεδο. Ωστόσο, καθώς δεν διαθέτουμε χρηματοδότηση, το κόστος ενοικίασης χώρου είναι ιδιαίτερα σημαντικό και είναι αδύνατο να το καλύψουμε χωρίς τη βοήθειά σας. Επίσης, θα μας βοηθήσετε να σχεδιάζουμε και να δημιουργήσουμε κοστούμια υψηλής ποιότητας. Η σχεδιάστρια των κοστουμιών είναι μία ανερχόμενη σχεδιάστρια που ζει και εργάζεται στο Βέλγιο. Ωστόσο, τα υφάσματα και ο σχεδιασμός είναι μια πολύ σημαντική και χρονοβόρα διαδικασία. Με τη βοήθειά σας, τα υφάσματα θα αγοραστούν και θα βοηθήσετε στη δημιουργική διαδικασία της κατασκευής των κοστουμιών μας. Κλείνοντας, θα μας βοηθήσετε στο σχεδιασμό φωτισμού. Αυτή είναι η πρώτη φορά που θα δημιουργήσουμε μια παράσταση που δεν είναι site-specific και θα είναι στη σκηνή. Ως εκ τούτου, είναι απαραίτητο να συνεργαστούμε με έναν τεχνικό φωτισμού.
 
English Description

`We find each other in the plenum` is a duet. The full (plenum) is the opposite of the vacuum. We are talking about the plenum of each one of us. At that moment both are in the core of the plenum, which is nothing but the middle of the vacuum. Those moments when everyone, in an unremitting effort to gain independence, does not survive without the other. The important Other is the one that affects my thoughts, my feelings. She is the one who creates my reality. In an empty space, surrendered to its simplicity,everything is reflected. We commit ourselves and through contact, we research relationships under the surface. The relationships within us, which give a meaning to encouragement, support, trust. A complete and at the same time unrelated relationship. Difficult to balance.The circle is completed. Having presented two performances, complementary to each other, a 30-minute complete show at the Central Stage of the theater `The Train At Rouf``will be presented in September. In July 2019 there was an audition held to choose the dancer who will be with me on this creative journey.  I got very lucky to meet and finally collaborate with Sofia. The purpose of this performance is to create the base for a longer-lasting project, which will be sent to festivals in Greece and the rest of Europe. 
In a world of loneliness, we create together.
 

Contributing in this project will help us to achieve our goals and make our ideas true. You`ll help us renting a dance studio to rehearse. Rehearsals are very important in our creating process.  The requirements of the festival are very high and we want to present a performance that corresponds to the level of the festival. However, as soon as we do not have any funding, the cost of renting a space is particularly important and it is impossible to cover it without your help.  Also, You`ll help us to design and create high quality costumes.   The costume designer is a rising Greek designer who lives and works in Belgium. However, fabrics and design, as well as sewing costumes is a very important and time-consuming process. With your help, the fabrics will be purchased and you will help in the creative process of creating our costumes.  In closing, you will help us with lighting design. This is the first time we will create a show that is not site-specific and will be on the stage. Therefore, it is necessary to cooperate with a lighting technician who specializes in lighting design.

story:
Overview

We're looking to raise $1250 to support the development and production of a new play about the world of art and our human connection to the art we experience, called Black Deer In Blizzard. A new play by emerging writer Steven Griffin, we are seeking support to produce the show in Fringe festivals and uplift the work of young talent in Toronto.

 

The Show

Black Deer In Blizzard is a play about a painter's daughter and an art forger meeting to try to understand the worthiness of authenticity in art. With this project, we are exploring the separation between art and artist, real and fake, and if it really matters at all. Interrogating our modern obsession with perfectly curated lives for public consumption, the show sets out to ask why we create, what that creation means, and the value of authentic creations in a world built for "Insta-experiences." The show is a way for us to question the things we experience and how we experience them together. 

Black Deer In Blizzard is set to premiere in summer 2020.  As part of our artistic values, the production will have a diverse, equitable creative team both on and offstage and will include mentorship opportunities for new and emerging talent to help develop their craft.

By supporting this campaign, you'll support the work of a dozen independent artists and creators working to make the art that is stronger, more inclusive, and more accessible.

 

Who We Are:

Black Deer In Blizzard is helmed by two young artists with a wide array of experience in theatre and independent production. 

 

Joseph Burdi (Producer & Dramaturg for Black Deer in Blizzard) is a Toronto-based Dramaturg, Director, Producer, Artistic Director of Fly The Nest Productions, and recent graduate of York University with a specialization in Dramaturgy and Devised Theatre. Having worked across Toronto and internationally, his work is inspired by political-socioeconomic issues and justice, exploring substantial risks in content, form, and presentation through a queer aesthetic as well as a focus on character study and image work. He is currently the assistant director for Litmus Theatre’s upcoming production of Wendy, mentoring under Matthew Thomas Walker, and is producing Fly the Nest Productions’ first project, an interactive work of theatre, with a focus on working with and uplifting diverse, queer creators. He was the Director for Homo For Christmas (2019) at the Inspirato Festival, Midnight Rubes (2015) at Social Capital Theatre as part of the inaugural Short Short Play Festival, and Chaperone Blues (2014) and A Nondenominational Holiday Party for the Lonely (2014) at Unit 102 as part of Operation 24, Assistant Director and Dramaturg for High School Symphony at the 2018 Toronto Fringe Festival, and Dramaturg for My Korean American Friend (2018), Jennaration Y (2017) at the Edinburgh International Fringe, The Ashley Plays (2017), Telling Tales Out of School (2016-17), and The Lost City of Alanis (2016). 

 

Steven Griffin (Playwright & Director for Black Deer in Blizzard) is a Toronto based director and writer of both theatre and film. He's had short films screened in numerous festivals including Toronto ArtHouse Film Fest, Kingston Film Festival, and the Toronto International Shorts Festival. As a theatre director, his most recent fringe show “Dominion” played at 2017’s Toronto Fringe Theatre Festival and he was named talent to watch by NOW magazine. In addition to that, he has directed for both Toronto Queer Theatre Festival and InspiraTO Theatre Festival (where the show, One Small Step, won the People’s Choice for Best Play). His work tends to play with perspective, to explore the rationales someone will convince themselves of in order to justify their own life choices, and focuses on time, and the short amount of it that we have. He has always been very curious about different lifestyles having grown up around family and friends who mostly existed in the same economic/geographical spaces. The frustration of only being limited to the individual perspective and understanding of himself has fueled his obsession with exploring the logic and rationale of others. The show comes from that obsession with people's relationships to art and the effect a person connected to an artist can have when attempting to enjoy that person’s art.

 

 

Where Will Your Money Go?

The funds from this campaign will form part of the budget for the production going to each other shows various expenses. This includes:

60% goes to the Artists - The creators, innovators, explorers, and risk-takers jumping onto this project with us. Your donation will help them get paid a fair and decent wage for their tireless creative effort. This ensures that the artists we bring on board can focus dedicate their time to crafting artistic excellence.

11% goes into production costs - Space to work, design costs, printing. Your funds will help us create a dazzling world, then fill it with beautiful light and incredible soundscapes. This money brings the page onstage.

11% goes to marketing - By being here you already know about the show but so many other people have yet to hear about it. The money going to marketing will help us advertise on multiple platforms, create posters and postcards to drum up excitement, and help get the public seeing the work of the incredible artists on this project. 

18% goes to Admin - The Application fees and costs for theatre festivals. They help us produce the work at a significant discount, allowing us to put more of our funds to the people behind the project,  but they still need to cover some costs too!

 

We are proud to say most of the money goes back to artists to support their livelihoods, build their careers, and make indie theatre more sustainable. Your generosity makes that possible! Go You!

 

Rewarding Your Generosity

Giving is such an incredible gift and one that we cherish so much! In the spirit of the holidays, we wanted to give back to you as much you're giving to us! So we partnered with some sponsors and donors to gift you with:

Weekly Raffles

Every Sunday (December 8, 15, & 22) each person from the past week who donated $20 or more will be entered into a raffle to win a special prize announced each week. 

Grand Prize Raffle

At the end of our holiday campaign, on December 23 each person throughout the campaign who donated $50 or more will be entered into a raffle to win our Grand Prize, including some of our weekly raffle items and some exclusive prizes to be announced the week before the draw. 

 

Every contribution counts! Everyone who donates has our gratitude and will have an acknowledgment of their support in our program in addition to any perks of your donation level.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand you might not be able to contribute financially. There are other ways you can help:

  • Share the campaign on social media and/or with friends. Tell people why you’re excited about Black Deer In Blizzard and invite them to get involved!
  • Follow us on Instagram @jos11b & @stevenpgriffin. If you dig this project, you can track it's progress there and get behind the scenes looks.
  • Join our email list to stay in the loop.

He's had short films screened in numerous festivals including Toronto ArtHouse Film Fest, Kingston Film Festival, and the Toronto International Shorts Festival. As a theatre director, his most recent fringe show “Dominion” played at 2017’s Toronto Fringe Theatre Festival and he was named talent to watch by NOW magazine. In addition to that, he has directed for both Toronto Queer Theatre Festival and InspiraTO Theatre Festival (where the show, One Small Step, won the People’s Choice for Best Play). His work tends to play with perspective, to explore the rationales someone will convince themselves of in order to justify their own life choices, and focuses on time, and the short amount of it that we have. He has always been very curious about different lifestyles having grown up around family and friends who mostly existed in the same economic/geographical spaces. The frustration of only being limited to the individual perspective and understanding of himself has fueled his obsession with exploring the logic and rationale of others. The show comes from that obsession with people's relationships to art and the effect a person connected to an artist can have when attempting to enjoy that person’s art.
 
 
Where Will Your Money Go?
The funds from this campaign will form part of the budget for the production going to each other shows various expenses. This includes:
60% goes to the Artists - The creators, innovators, explorers, and risk-takers jumping onto this project with us. Your donation will help them get paid a fair and decent wage for their tireless creative effort. This ensures that the artists we bring on board can focus dedicate their time to crafting artistic excellence.
11% goes into production costs - Space to work, design costs, printing. Your funds will help us create a dazzling world, then fill it with beautiful light and incredible soundscapes. This money brings the page onstage.
11% goes to marketing - By being here you already know about the show but so many other people have yet to hear about it. The money going to marketing will help us advertise on multiple platforms, create posters and postcards to drum up excitement, and help get the public seeing the work of the incredible artists on this project. 
18% goes to Admin - The Application fees and costs for theatre festivals. They help us produce the work at a significant discount, allowing us to put more of our funds to the people behind the project,  but they still need to cover some costs too!
 
We are proud to say most of the money goes back to artists to support their livelihoods, build their careers, and make indie theatre more sustainable. Your generosity makes that possible! Go You!

 
Rewarding Your Generosity
Giving is such an incredible gift and one that we cherish so much! In the spirit of the holidays, we wanted to give back to you as much you're giving to us! So we partnered with some sponsors and donors to gift you with:
Weekly Raffles
Every Sunday (December 8, 15, & 22) each person from the past week who donated $20 or more will be entered into a raffle to win a special prize announced each week. 
Grand Prize Raffle
At the end of our holiday campaign, on December 23 each person throughout the campaign who donated $50 or more will be entered into a raffle to win our Grand Prize, including some of our weekly raffle items and some exclusive prizes to be announced the week before the draw. 
 
Every contribution counts! Everyone who donates has our gratitude and will have an acknowledgment of their support in our program in addition to any perks of your donation level.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand you might not be able to contribute financially. There are other ways you can help:

Share the campaign on social media and/or with friends. Tell people why you’re excited about Black Deer In Blizzard and invite them to get involved!
Follow us on Instagram @jos11b & @stevenpgriffin. If you dig this project, you can track it's progress there and get behind the scenes looks.
Join our email list to stay in the loop.

story:
NOTE: I have received fiscal sponsorship from Fractured Atlas, meaning donations made through Fractured Atlas are tax-deductible. The link to that site is: https://fundraising.fracturedatlas.org/making-a... 

If you prefer to send a check my address is PO Box 16436, St. Paul, MN 55116. Please make the check out to Fractured Atlas for the tax deduction.

 

Summary:

The book will provide a comprehensive history of Twin Cities (TC) dance – or rather as comprehensive as possible, given the breadth of experience and story. The main time frame will be 1960 to 2020 – a span of 60 years – however I will introduce some of the pioneers and defining events pre-1960 to set the stage. Mid-2021 is when I hope the book will be self-published so the last chapter will be a summation through 2020 and a look forward. 

The focus will be on a variety of companies, schools and individual artists as well as their collaborators, presenters and funders. A variety of dance and movement-based performance techniques will be featured including ballet, modern/postmodern dance, improvisation, tap/percussive dance, hip hop, American Indian, and the wide variety of international forms represented in the community.

In addition, the book will provide additional context with other artistic movements such as the rise of the TC music scene and local social justice or other legal concerns that crossover with the arts. 

The book will also place the TC scene within the context of the national dance landscape and show its reciprocal influence on larger dance communities such as NYC. Finally, while the book will focus on the TC there will be an exploration of relevant influences from other parts of the state such as college dance programs that “feed” the TC scene. 

I have attempted to seek a publisher locally and nationally. All I have contacted agree that it is worthy project but difficult to market because the subject matter is region-specific. Still, I believe there are many stories that need to told, so now I'm crowdfunding with the hopes that there will be a book that others would like to see here in Minnesota, and possibly beyond. 

To my knowledge there has never been a book offering a comprehensive overview of the TC dance scene. Nationally, there are books covering specific eras in dance history and dance artists, with significant focus on connections to New York City. However, given the significant list of artists, companies and historic events associated with the TC dance community, a book on its contributions would be welcome to the local and national conversation on dance.   

Plan:

Primarily, I will conduct interviews with choreographers, dancers, musicians, lighting and set designers, presenters, writers/editors, funders, philanthropists, and historians. 

I will dig into archives at the University of Minnesota and New York Public Library Jerome Robbins Dance Division at Lincoln Center as well as the Minnesota History Center, Walker Art Center, Star Tribune, City Pages/Sweet Potato, Twin Cities Reader, Pioneer Press, Minnesota Daily, Jerome Foundation, McKnight Foundation and Dance Magazine archives (among others).

Additionally, I will review available imagery (photographic and video/film) plus additional documentation from New York-based companies with strong Minnesota ties such as Merce Cunningham Dance Company, Trisha Brown Dance Company, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company, Bebe Miller, Ralph Lemon, Charlie Moulton, Twyla Tharp, and David Gordon and Pick-up Company.

The manuscript will be approximately 300 pages with about 20 percent individual images including photography, posters, flyers, choreographer notes and diagrams, lighting, costume and set design examples, music composition examples, and other related documentation. 

It is also my hope that this book can spark an exhibit and website. 

Anticipated Costs: Copies, mileage, transcribing, photo rights, one trip to New York to research at the NYPL archives and interview artists with TC connections, self-publishing fees, outside editor costs, website, basic marketing in the TC area

Background:

2019 will mark my 30th year as a dance and performance writer. My first arts writing gig was for Paper Magazinein New York City in 1989. When I moved to Minnesota in 1994 I started contributing to City Pages and in 2008 joined the Star Tribune’s freelance pool. I  recently stopped freelancing to work full-time as a state employee but see this change as the perfect opportunity to focus on a book project I have long anticipated.

Writing honors include the Mike Steele Fellowship from the University of Minnesota Journalism Center, Critics’ Travel Study Grant from the Center for Arts Criticism, American Theater Fellowship, Sage Cowles Land Grant Chair/Cowles Guest Artist Opportunity in the University of Minnesota Dance and Theater Department, and critic/presenter through the Link Vostok International East-West Arts Exchange (Kostroma and Yaroslavl, Russia). 

I spent several years in arts administration after I graduated from Barnard College in New York (English major/dance minor). I worked at Performance Space 122 and Dance Theater Workshop in New York City (NYC), Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Massachusetts, and the Minnesota Dance Alliance in Minneapolis. I also provided freelance grant writing and company management services for several artists. I became well acquainted with many artists in this work.

In December 1998 I graduated from law school and began working as a lawyer full time in 1999, but stayed committed to arts writing. I hold a special interest in artistic approaches that incorporate social justice perspectives given my early career exposure promoting work by artists caught up in the censorship debates created by Congressional scrutiny of the National Endowment for the Arts in the early 1990’s. 

Aside from covering the arts, I have written or co-written several law review articles and other legal publications. I contributed a chapter to Awakening from the Dream: Civil Rights Under Siege and the New Struggle for Equal Justice (Carolina Academic Press 2005). 

Although I have been writing about the Twin Cities dance scene since 1994, when I moved to Minneapolis, I was already well aware of the rich arts community. From 1989 to 1994 I was an arts publicist and writer based in New York City. I was exposed to several Twin Cities-based artists during this period and knew of Minneapolis, in particular, as an important tour stop for New York City-based artists through my connections to the Performance Space 122 Field Trips program and the National Performance Network touring program operated through Dance Theater Workshop. 

I began freelancing for City Pages in Minneapolis in 1994 and wrote extensively on dance and performance art for many years there. In 2008 I began writing for the Star Tribunein Minneapolis. I estimate that I have written hundreds of articles, reviews and spotlights about dance, with the majority focused on Twin Cities-based artists. I can draw from my own archive for source material.

As a writer and fan, I am aware of some of the pioneers who built the Twin Cities dance (going back as far as the 1930’s and 40’s) as well as the artists and scholars who are the current keepers of the stories of the dance community. I also know the newest generation of innovators. I have watched emerging choreographers grow into leaders, seen the ups and downs of major institutions for dance, witnessed the birth of companies who now have national or even international reach, and observed the rich diversification of the community through a wide array of cultural and aesthetic influences. I have been on the frontlines of challenging moments (the financial troubles of the Minnesota Dance Alliance), witnessed successes (the opening of the Cowles Center for Dance and Performing Arts and the Walker Art Center’s McGuire Theater), and seen work blossom on stages of all sizes as well as in site-specific settings.

story:
Short Summary

Our theatrical provenance earned the respect of the film's producer, leading him to grant the stage rights for a musical theater adaptation without hesitation.  

The Queen Documentary (1968) is ripe for a stage adaptation.  We are incorporating the oral history of the film as told by the film makers to tell a woefully overlooked civil rights story that rightfully paints Jack Doroshow (Flawless Sabrina), our narrator and protagonist, as a hero for the LGBTQ community.  On the surface it looks like a fun, campy drag queen beauty pageant, and it is...but it is so much richer and deeper than it appears.  

The developmental phase of this project was in full swing when COVID-19 threw a wrench into our cogs.  We need help to continue to research, to sustain the creators through the lockdown, and ready this project for the next phase...workshop, which, if we are successful here will begin in 2021.  Any funds beyond what we immediately need to complete development will be rolled over into the expensive workshop.  

We are a team of well educated, well trained, talented, experienced professionals.  We have a long term, well thought out, realistic plan for The Queen and a lot of heavy weight theater industry interest, but want to keep it tight until the workshop phase. 

Please give what you can afford. If you, like us, have been impacted by our current social condition, and cannot afford to contribute, you can still help by forwarding our information to your contacts.  

Thank you,

The Queen 1968 Documentary: The Musical team

story:
Virtual Venue Theatricals

This is an unprecedented time for the arts. As performance-centered workers, our livelihoods are directly affected by the widespread closures and the continued uncertainty of when our careers will resume. While there is no handbook for navigating this new arena, Virtual Venue Theatricals believes in the strength of our community and the ability of artists to create magic out of adversity.

The aim of VVT is to open up a space for friends and colleagues in the arts community to work and create in this time. The beauty of remote theatre is the ability to collaborate with artists across the country and the globe; our upcoming Benefit Concert involves industry professionals from every time zone in the continental U.S. and as far as the UK, Canada, and Japan. In addition to creating work for performers, choreographers, stage managers, and other industry professionals, Virtual Venue Theatricals provides a new space for writers to workshop or even premiere new works.

What We Need

The arts can't survive without funding from patrons. In addition to producing shows, turns out establishing a new business is an expensive endeavor. We need your help.

  • Start up expenses: $10,000
    • Business License
    • General Liability Insurance
    • Website domain/hosting
    • Lawyer
      • Operating Agreement
      • Employer Identification Number
      • Articles of Incorporation
      • Contracts for performers and production team
    • Trademark 
    • Software and equipment
    • Zoom Business Account
    • File storage/online sharing
    • QuickBooks/Accounting services
  • Production costs: $7,000
    • Licensing/production rights
    • Production Team
    • Performers

What You Get

  • $50-$100
    • Signed poster
  • $100-$200
    • A free ticket to our next full length production
    • Plus the above
  • $200-$500
    • Special thanks in our credits and on the webpage for our upcoming show
    • Plus all of the above
  • $500+
    • A cameo in the show
    • Plus all of the above
  • In the Event we do not reach our entire goal, we will be allocating the money received as follows
    • 50% Towards Startup Fees
    • 35% Towards Production Costs
    • 15% Towards Wages 

The Impact

Virtual Venue Theatricals was born out of the desire to put theater professionals back to work. Our success means we can support the success of others in our industry. Our core objectives are to:

  • Give space to performers to do what they do best.
  • Collaborate with production and technical staff to create innovative virtual performances.
  • Provide workshop and performance space to writers and show creators.
  • Keep live theater accessible to audiences.

Risks & Challenges

Let's face it. Most theatre companies aren't producing full-length, licensed musicals and plays right now because there are no guidelines to producing in a virtual space when the precedent has always been physical venues.

I plan on bridging this gap by combining my skills in both live theatre and TV/Film to produce a multimedia style production via our virtual stage. 

My goal is to continue finding creative ways to engage my artists and performers in this process, with a full scale virtual rehearsal process culminating in a fully realized virtual production, complete with musical elements and choreography where applicable! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate. We thank you for being here and supporting our vision.

  • Like the idea? Share VVT with your friends, your neighbors, your grandma, your Facebook feed. Every theater needs an audience.
  • Reach out to an artist you know with some love and encouragement.

story:
Call Me Papa Theatre Workshop

Adapting Unexpectedly Trans for Kids in Grades 4-6

 

In a Nutshell

Call Me Papa is a play about Blair and Iris, their trans father, Dan, and their separate journeys accepting his gender identity.

We need your help to raise money to workshop the script so we can present it to schools in Toronto and across Ontario.

You will get cool stuff! 

Perks/Prizes

We’ve got an autographed LP/CD and a t-shirt from award-winning musician Rich Aucoin; gorgeous naturally-sourced lip glosses from Lippie Lab, a Pride Tarot deck and online tarot course from Andrew at the Hermit’s Lamp, tarot readings by Hanlon, bath bombs and gifts from Lush, beautiful and lively Mermaid prints (would make excellent home/kid decor) from children’s illustrator Janine Carrington, and SO MUCH MORE is coming as we go. You will be amazed! 

The Project:

The draft script for Call Me Papa was developed in 2020 by Hanlon McGregor and Mihaly Szabados through the support of the Ontario Arts Council and Roseneath Theatre. Dramaturgy by acclaimed writer/performer Diane Flacks. 

Call Me Papa is based on Hanlon’s play Unexpectedly Trans, about which the Coast said:

Prepare to get misty-eyed at Unexpectedly Trans, as Hanlon McGregor performs scenes inspired by his transition and coming out to himself and his family. Dan is trying to “make friends with the awkward” while navigating family life, hormones, and public transit.

Read the whole review

The next step, in November 2021, is to mount a one-week workshop of the draft script, with actors, in Roseneath’s studio. We will further develop the songs and characters in the workshop and innovate a way to share the show online.

And we need your help with this!

Who are we?

Under the Bus is a collective comprised of artists who identify as trans*, queer, black, disabled, newcomers, and/or mad. We create theatre and film in Toronto. 

Current Members:

Hanlon McGregor
Mihaly Szabados 
Dr. Syrus Marcus Ware
Karla Rae James 
Thorne Brown
Stephen St.Christian

What have we done? 

Though we are small, we’ve done a LOT together! 

  • plays in three seasons of Halifax Fringe
  • a play at the 40th Rhubarb Festival at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, 
  • created two short films; one was an official selection at the Toronto Short Film Festival
  • made a music video of The Change for music artist Rich Aucoin

YOU can help the kids of trans parents, and trans/non-binary youth be better understood in their schools and communities! This play in development can do just that.

Please help us tell this story. Synopsis of Call Me Papa:

Two siblings have near-opposite reactions when Mom comes out as Papa. Teenaged Blair is unbelievably supportive, whereas 5-year-old Iris doesn’t want to let go of ‘Momma.’ Aunt Jane is worried about how the transition affects Iris. The family struggles at home and at school to find the ‘new normal.’ When Blair comes out as non-binary, Aunt Jane fights with Papa over the children, but Iris and Blair come to Papa’s defence. Iris concludes, “Momma’s gone…but I’ve got the best Papa in the whole world!”

How will this play help?

Hanlon grew up moving between several small communities in rural Nova Scotia without a concept of being transgender, and seeing this play would have saved him decades of pain and questioning. Instead, Hanlon’s kids had to take on education and advocacy beyond their years during his transition - let’s spread the word far and wide through this funny and fun show that has a lot of heart - so fewer kids are burdened with answering the sticky questions.

We are excited to work with this outstanding cast!

Blair - 13-year-old child of Dan
Played by Sai Lian Macikunas (he/him), a disabled nonbinary Chinese-Malaysian/Lithuanian performer-playwright whose previous credits include many University of Toronto student-affiliated productions (2015-2019), and the fu-GEN Kitchen Creators Unit (2018-2019). 

Papa - trans father of Blair and Iris, 
Played by River Oliveira, a queer, trans, and disabled theatre artist and musician based in Toronto. He has been working and training with various companies as a creator, performer, sound designer, and emerging producer. 

Aunt Jane - Dan's sister, opposes his transition
Played by Bilal Baig* (they/them), a queer, trans-feminine, Muslim playwright, performer, and workshop facilitator. Bilal's first play, Acha Bacha, had its world premiere in 2018 and has been published by Playwrights Canada Press. 

*unconfirmed

Iris - Dan's 6-year-old daughter

Played by Emily Andrews (she/her), an Actor and Producer. She studied and graduated with her BA from the prestigious London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts in London, England. Her theatre acting credits go as far as the West End in London and the World famous Edinburgh Festival, and she toured across Canada in a variety of theatre productions. 

How will we do it?

We don't know how the world will look or how COVID protocols will adapt. So Call Me Papa will be covid-safe. Roseneath is providing us with cameras and green screens, and we will use them to design an interactive way to share our shows with students across the province - whether learning in school or at home. We will also send out kits with fun interactive props for students to use while watching the show!

We have raised $7500 in government funds so far of a 10.5 k+ budget for this one-week development workshop. Most of the budget is being used to pay artists.

We need to raise another $3,000 to: 

  • Pay trans actors - above the minimum requirement - they deserve it
  • Pay technicians, musicians, and ourselves 
  • Purchase props, instruments, unanticipated tech needs
  • Print scripts 
  • Purchase covid safety supplies (masks, antiseptic wipes)
  • Purchase contents of the kits we will be sending to audience members - top-secret interactive *FUN STUFF* 
  • Purchase postage to ship the kits
  • Pay ASL interpreters**

Challenges

  • We are innovating a new way of presenting live theatre in schools, and there will be technical details to figure out, but we trust that with the help of Roseneath and Franco Pang (No More Mr. Rice Guy), we will be able to figure out how to do this
  • We need schools to invite us into their virtual classrooms. We are confident that we will get the word out between Roseneath’s network and our networks by reaching out to other trans-positive organizations. 
  • Our creative goals are ambitious for a week -  but we will do a lot of prep with the musical director, directing mentor, and dramaturge in advance; every moment of the workshop will be used strategically to develop the musical numbers and work on the crucial relationships and scenes. But, again, we have veterans in our corner, and we are excited to tackle these challenges!!!
  • Covid might prevent rehearsing/performing in-person Fingers crossed it won’t happen, but we have a contingency plan, again through the magic of green screens. 

Non-financial Ways You Can Support Call Me Papa

If you are unable to donate money, we understand entirely.
Here are some other VITAL ways you can help!

  • Help to extend our reach by sharing with your friends and family and colleagues/workplaces - this is helping us grow our support base AND, equally important, reach our audience.
  • You can do this using the IndieGoGo share tools!
  • You can donate or ask your workplace to donate a perk- do you make a product? Perform a service? We can use it to create even more excitement for this campaign or later in our Patreon account (launching soon).
  • Connect us with potential schools! For example, are you connected to a Grade 4-6 class? Please let them know about our campaign to keep in touch about participating in the workshop showing or the later productions!
story_txt:
Call Me Papa Theatre WorkshopAdapting Unexpectedly Trans for Kids in Grades 4-6 In a NutshellCall Me Papa is a play about Blair and Iris, their trans father, Dan, and their separate journeys accepting his gender identity. We need your help to raise money to workshop the script so we can present it to schools in Toronto and across Ontario. You will get cool stuff! Perks/PrizesWe’ve got an autographed LP/CD and a t-shirt from award-winning musician Rich Aucoin; gorgeous naturally-sourced lip glosses from Lippie Lab, a Pride Tarot deck and online tarot course from Andrew at the Hermit’s Lamp, tarot readings by Hanlon, bath bombs and gifts from Lush, beautiful and lively Mermaid prints (would make excellent home/kid decor) from children’s illustrator Janine Carrington, and SO MUCH MORE is coming as we go. You will be amazed! The Project:The draft script for Call Me Papa was developed in 2020 by Hanlon McGregor and Mihaly Szabados through the support of the Ontario Arts Council and Roseneath Theatre. Dramaturgy by acclaimed writer/performer Diane Flacks. Call Me Papa is based on Hanlon’s play Unexpectedly Trans, about which the Coast said:Prepare to get misty-eyed at Unexpectedly Trans, as Hanlon McGregor performs scenes inspired by his transition and coming out to himself and his family. Dan is trying to “make friends with the awkward” while navigating family life, hormones, and public transit.Read the whole reviewThe next step, in November 2021, is to mount a one-week workshop of the draft script, with actors, in Roseneath’s studio. We will further develop the songs and characters in the workshop and innovate a way to share the show online.And we need your help with this!Who are we?Under the Bus is a collective comprised of artists who identify as trans*, queer, black, disabled, newcomers, and/or mad. We create theatre and film in Toronto. Current Members:Hanlon McGregorMihaly Szabados Dr. Syrus Marcus WareKarla Rae James Thorne BrownStephen St.ChristianWhat have we done? Though we are small, we’ve done a LOT together! 
plays in three seasons of Halifax Fringe
a play at the 40th Rhubarb Festival at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, 
created two short films; one was an official selection at the Toronto Short Film Festival
made a music video of The Change for music artist Rich Aucoin
YOU can help the kids of trans parents, and trans/non-binary youth be better understood in their schools and communities! This play in development can do just that.Please help us tell this story. Synopsis of Call Me Papa:Two siblings have near-opposite reactions when Mom comes out as Papa. Teenaged Blair is unbelievably supportive, whereas 5-year-old Iris doesn’t want to let go of ‘Momma.’ Aunt Jane is worried about how the transition affects Iris. The family struggles at home and at school to find the ‘new normal.’ When Blair comes out as non-binary, Aunt Jane fights with Papa over the children, but Iris and Blair come to Papa’s defence. Iris concludes, “Momma’s gone…but I’ve got the best Papa in the whole world!”How will this play help?Hanlon grew up moving between several small communities in rural Nova Scotia without a concept of being transgender, and seeing this play would have saved him decades of pain and questioning. Instead, Hanlon’s kids had to take on education and advocacy beyond their years during his transition - let’s spread the word far and wide through this funny and fun show that has a lot of heart - so fewer kids are burdened with answering the sticky questions.We are excited to work with this outstanding cast!Blair - 13-year-old child of DanPlayed by Sai Lian Macikunas (he/him), a disabled nonbinary Chinese-Malaysian/Lithuanian performer-playwright whose previous credits include many University of Toronto student-affiliated productions (2015-2019), and the fu-GEN Kitchen Creators Unit (2018-2019). Papa - trans father of Blair and Iris, Played by River Oliveira, a queer, trans, and disabled theatre artist and musician based in Toronto. He has been working and training with various companies as a creator, performer, sound designer, and emerging producer. Aunt Jane - Dan's sister, opposes his transitionPlayed by Bilal Baig* (they/them), a queer, trans-feminine, Muslim playwright, performer, and workshop facilitator. Bilal's first play, Acha Bacha, had its world premiere in 2018 and has been published by Playwrights Canada Press. *unconfirmedIris - Dan's 6-year-old daughterPlayed by Emily Andrews (she/her), an Actor and Producer. She studied and graduated with her BA from the prestigious London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts in London, England. Her theatre acting credits go as far as the West End in London and the World famous Edinburgh Festival, and she toured across Canada in a variety of theatre productions. How will we do it?We don't know how the world will look or how COVID protocols will adapt. So Call Me Papa will be covid-safe. Roseneath is providing us with cameras and green screens, and we will use them to design an interactive way to share our shows with students across the province - whether learning in school or at home. We will also send out kits with fun interactive props for students to use while watching the show!We have raised $7500 in government funds so far of a 10.5 k+ budget for this one-week development workshop. Most of the budget is being used to pay artists.We need to raise another $3,000 to: 
Pay trans actors - above the minimum requirement - they deserve it
Pay technicians, musicians, and ourselves 
Purchase props, instruments, unanticipated tech needs
Print scripts 
Purchase covid safety supplies (masks, antiseptic wipes)
Purchase contents of the kits we will be sending to audience members - top-secret interactive *FUN STUFF* 
Purchase postage to ship the kits
Pay ASL interpreters**
Challenges

We are innovating a new way of presenting live theatre in schools, and there will be technical details to figure out, but we trust that with the help of Roseneath and Franco Pang (No More Mr. Rice Guy), we will be able to figure out how to do this


We need schools to invite us into their virtual classrooms. We are confident that we will get the word out between Roseneath’s network and our networks by reaching out to other trans-positive organizations. 


Our creative goals are ambitious for a week -  but we will do a lot of prep with the musical director, directing mentor, and dramaturge in advance; every moment of the workshop will be used strategically to develop the musical numbers and work on the crucial relationships and scenes. But, again, we have veterans in our corner, and we are excited to tackle these challenges!!!


Covid might prevent rehearsing/performing in-person Fingers crossed it won’t happen, but we have a contingency plan, again through the magic of green screens. 

Non-financial Ways You Can Support Call Me PapaIf you are unable to donate money, we understand entirely.Here are some other VITAL ways you can help!

Help to extend our reach by sharing with your friends and family and colleagues/workplaces - this is helping us grow our support base AND, equally important, reach our audience.

You can do this using the IndieGoGo share tools!


You can donate or ask your workplace to donate a perk- do you make a product? Perform a service? We can use it to create even more excitement for this campaign or later in our Patreon account (launching soon).

Connect us with potential schools! For example, are you connected to a Grade 4-6 class? Please let them know about our campaign to keep in touch about participating in the workshop showing or the later productions!

story:
Overview

At Karib Dance and Cultural Arts Studio (KDCAS), we strive to keep the culture alive through dance and education by fostering a love for Africa and her Diaspora through movement, creativity, and freedom.

Your contribution will allow the full launch of our Hybrid Youth Dance & Enrichment Academy in January 2021, and add more programming to empower, educate, and energize our community.

The pandemic has taken many small businesses by storm. In addition, A recent study noted the impact of the pandemic on young people to be “systematic, deep and disproportionate.” Research shows young people specifically are likely to suffer severe and long-lasting impacts from the changes faced as a result of the pandemic. 

Our goal is to combat this by offering youth scholarships and provide ongoing accessibility to our programs to low-income families.

We want to move forward, together! Help us reach our goal!

 

Short Summary

KaribFIT and KaribDCAS provides empowerment through movement. Women from all walks of life come to our classes and programs and feel happiness, joy, and walk away feeling empowered.

Our studio recently opened, a couple of months before the COVID-19 pandemic and restrictions on operations hit our area hard. We had recently hired new instructors to lead our daily Youth Dance & Enrichment Academy, which launched on March 23, 2020. The Youth Academy was created to provide a place for young people to express confidence through movement. We train our youth dancers in Afro Jazz, West African Dance, and Caribbean Folk Dance, while also providing them with Dance Conditioning. We would love to add African Drumming and Acro classes, as well.

Many of the young people we were targeting, and begun communicating with are future first generation college students, from underserved areas in our community. Many of these youth have experienced trauma from bullying, lack of community resources, lack of guidance on healthy lifestyles, among a myriad of mental health conditions. The Youth Dance Academy stands to offer freedom of expression, and foster an appreciation of African and Caribbean culture as Students learn and grow. We focus on building not only great dancers, but building confidence as well as self-esteem, while providing a safe space for them to perform and enable them to further connect with their community. 

Our ultimate goal would be to provide 10 scholarships to underserved, deserving young people in the surrounding area who could access the wide range of enrichment offered at no cost. As schools in our area begin to open, we will keep our studio open expanding our to provide monthly in school cultural exchanges. We will also be able to open our after school enrichment programs, once schools in our county reopen, providing a safe enriching environment for young people.

 

Our Story

For the past nearly 6 years, the KaribFIT community has become a refuge for women. When the studio opened, it provided a safe space for women to escape the grind of daily life pressures and connect with other like minded women all seeking community in the arts while feeling empowered. 

After holding classes all over Maryland, DC, and Virginia, we finally opened our own studio, KDCAS in November 2019, to celebrate, experience, and honor the cultures of Africa and the Caribbean with our community. In addition to KaribFIT Dance Fitness, the Studio also showcases cultural dance education classes and workshops, youth programs, private trainings, private party rentals, and so much more. 

KDCAS dance, fitness, and cultural arts programming appeals to people of varying ages, abilities/experience, and backgrounds, for creative self-expression, exercise engaging mind-body-spirit, and social events/opportunities.

Your support will ensure KDCAS will continue provide the greater Silver Spring. MD/DMV area with a comfortable, friendly, community oriented environment for dance, fitness, and cultural connection.

KDCAS provides a missing piece in one of the largest counties in Maryland – authentic African and Caribbean experiences, in one place. For years, people of African and Caribbean descent had to leave the county to find a place to call home where they could experience and be engulfed in the culture of Africa and her diaspora.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The fundraising goal for Karib Dance & Cultural Arts Studio is $8,500. This goal was carefully calculated to be both reasonable and realistic.

All funds raised will go towards:

  • In studio equipment such as:
    •  3-4 portable barres
    • Safe, lightweight glassless mirrors
    • Lighting, and equipment to enhance our online wellness platform and experiences (such as additional cameras to allow multiple angle views, lighting and sound system that transfers across the virtual platform)
  • Providing equipment for at home use for our immuno-compromised Youth Academy members who are unable to attend in person for related health reasons
  • Academy scholarships to underserved, deserving young people in the surrounding area

Your contribution will allow the full launch of our Youth Academy in January 2021, and add more programming to empower, educate, and energize our community.

We will also implement a fully digital wellness platform that will allow access to people nationally and internationally.

The funds from this campaign will help the overall operation of Karib Dance and Cultural Arts Studio. We will also be able to provide equipment for at home classes to youth in our programs who may otherwise not have access/the means to obtain it.

If we raise more than our initial goal amount, we will be able to offer additional scholarships to youth and families who may otherwise not be able to afford it.

In return for your support, KDCAS Studio has some perks to get you moving including everything from a motivational thank you card, to movement apparel, classes, trainings, and events.

 

 

The Impact

Supporting Karib Dance and Cultural Arts Studio will help to transform others lives through the active and creative benefits of dance. Your support will ensure KDCAS will continue provide the greater Silver Spring. MD/DMV area with a comfortable, friendly, community oriented environment for dance, fitness, and cultural connection.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks in expanding small business, especially for a small business like a dance studio. However, over the last 6 years, our team has collectively demonstrated what we can offer our community and how committed we are to making a positive impact. With a concentration on dance training, fitness instruction, nutrition, education of African and Caribbean culture and music, our team of Instructors is certified to continue to meet the needs of a wide range of people, from many walks of life.

We understand that we've set a big goal, but we believe we will reach it. Regardless of how much we raise through this Indiegogo campaign, you can feel confident that 100% of your contribution will go toward our studio and particularly, our Youth Academy.  No dollar is wasted. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If giving money isn't possible for you right now, we understand, you can help spread the word!

  • Spread the word about our studio. It means so much to us when you bring new friends to build our community. Word of mouth is a great way for us to serve more people.
  • Consider sharing our Indiegogo campaign on social, with your family, with your co-workers, and any other way you can think of.

We sincerely thank you for all the support you give to us.
