story:
THE AUDITION REVOLUTION

Auditioning is hard, right? Let’s make it easier - together. It’s time for an Audition Revolution! The mission is simple - save time, save money, help save the planet. How? Pledge to go paperless, ditch the hardcopy headshot, and support AuditionAnswer.

AuditionAnswer is an online organizational solution for open casting calls. We save Casting Professionals valuable time by automating the audition flow and simplifying Performer sign in/group divisions. We save Performers money by eliminating the need for hardcopy headshots and resumes. We help save the planet by decreasing the amount of paper waste generated at large open calls.

The AuditionAnswer approach is more efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally-friendly than current audition practices. With the support of Performers and Casting, AuditionAnswer will revolutionize audition protocol throughout the industry.

THE AUDITION GAME

AuditionAnswer conducted a survey of NYC Performers to better understand the life of a professional actor. Nervous, stressed, impatient, frantic. These were the most common words Performers used to describe their state of mind at open calls.

We found that Performers who audition at least once a week spend an average of $345/year on headshot printing services. This left Performers feeling “frustrated” and “annoyed” because, more often than not, auditioners don’t know where their headshots end up or if they are being considered for the job.

What about the people on the other side of the audition table? Casting Professionals are responsible forcollecting hundreds of headshots, organizing them into piles, answering Performer questions, and making split second decisions based on minute long dance routines and 16 bar cuts.

Of course every organization runs its auditions differently, but the general nature of open casting calls is chaotic, stressful, and overwhelming. Picture hundreds of Performers cramped in a small room, while an Audition Monitor fields questions, and the Casting Team is bombarded with headshots and resumes. Not as glamorous as you thought, huh?

HOW AUDITIONANSWER CHANGES THE GAME

AuditionAnswer streamlines the day-of-audition by automating the time-consuming tasks that bog down the audition flow. We are not a submission-based audition service and we are not a substitute for attending in-person auditions.

That’s only the tip of the iceberg. Although our current focus is open casting calls, we plan to tackle audition appointments, invited calls, and every other type of audition you can think of.

With funds raised through this Indiegogo Campaign, we plan to enhance our current solution and begin developing subsequent audition flows. That’s where you come in!

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Just as theater is a collaborative art form, AuditionAnswer is a collaborative effort with Performers and Casting Professionals at the forefront. The project's success rests in your hands. Please support us and rally behind the Audition Revolution. 

Our goal is to raise $8,000 over the next 40 days. This money will be used for debugging, software enhancements, and marketing. We opted for flexible funding so we will receive the total amount funded, regardless of whether or not we reach our goal. In the event that we exceed our goal, the funds will be allocated to future enhancements and team building.  

There are many ways you can help. Make a donation to our campaign and bring us one step closer to our goal. If you are unable to donate, spreading the word and sharing our campaign on social media is equally appreciated. Follow us on Twitter and Instagram, and like us on Facebook.

A third, and very important, way you can help is providing feedback, suggestions for enhancements, and signing up to be a Beta Tester. Designing an online audition solution is no small task and the only way we can create a solution that fits your needs is if you tell us your needs. Kindly contact us HERE with your feedback.

AuditionAnswer is currently in Beta and being tested by industry professionals. If you’re a Casting Professional interested in checking out our software, click HERE to sign up for our Beta Test.

This is only the beginning of our fundraising efforts, but it’s an important first step. The more eyes that see this page, the more likely we are to reach our goal! For more information, check out auditionanswer.com and read our blog.

WHY NOW?

If not now, when? Technology touches nearly every aspect of our lives - sending a text, calling an uber, ordering Seamless, “ordering” a date on Tinder. Why, then, is there no effective technological solution for in-person casting calls?

As a younger generation of Performers and Casting Professionals break into the industry, we will see a shift in general practices and expectations. Millennials are in tune with technology — they expect things to happen quickly, efficiently, and electronically.

The landscape is already changing - with Actors Equity Association announcing online sign ups for ECCs and several other companies seeking to improve and strengthen the theater industry through apps and tech. 

Bookster is changing the way Performers find, attend, and track auditions, while ScriptMatch is changing the way aspiring playwrights interact with directors and producers. The Artist Co-op is introducing a much needed shared workspace for performing artists in Central Manhattan. With all this innovation in the performing arts community, how could you say the time isn’t now?

ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

Another reason to incorporate technology and eliminate paper in the audition space is to decrease our carbon footprint. A typical open casting call at Pearl or Ripley Grier could easily attract 200 Performers. What happens to all those headshots and resumes once they leave the audition room? Are some stuffed into filing cabinets? Are others discarded?

Our impact might seem small in the grand scheme of global paper usage, but we can still make a huge difference. We can be part of the solution by going paperless. Think of all the trees we’ll save!

AuditionAnswer supports the amazing work being done at the Green Globe Theatre, an eco-friendly theatre company in Baltimore. Their mission is to cultivate an environment in which all aspects of design and production are renewable and sustainable. Support their vision and check out their​ GoFundMe.

ABOUT THE FOUNDER

Hi - I’m Alexis and my career began at age 4 when I directed and choreographed my first musical, starring my mom and my sister. Yes, there is video evidence and no, they did not receive EMC points ; )

I graduated from Boston College with a B.A. in Communications and Theater Arts. After graduation, I had the pleasure of working with the amazingly talented staff at Ocean State Theatre in Rhode Island.

After moving to NYC and attending several open casting calls, I saw the need for a simpler, more efficient audition process and I began working on the solution.

FOR PERFORMERS

To learn more about how AuditionAnswer helps Performers check out our website. Click HERE to create your free profile - simply upload your headshot and resume to get started. The Standard Performer profile is (and always will be) free.

In the not too distant future, we plan to introduce a Premium Performer profile with extra features and useful industry discounts. Our goal is to keep the Premium subscription fee as low as possible, so you get the most bang for your buck.

At its core, AuditionAnswer is a movement to lessen the financial burden that Performers face in preparation for auditions. I know firsthand how much money Performers spend on dance shoes, voice lessons, dance classes, the perfect audition outfit, and professional headshots.

It’s a small price to pay for the opportunity to live your dreams and pursue your passions, but why not lessen the burden. Yes, the elimination of the paper headshot and resume may seem like a minimal cost differential, but every little bit counts when you’re paying NYC rent.

If you’re ready to bring auditions into the 21st Century, then strap on those LaDuca’s and join the Audition Revolution!If every Performer that sees this page donates just $5, we’ll be one step closer to our goal.

What should AuditionAnswer’s first enhancement be? How much money do you spend annually on headshot printing services? Tweet your thoughts @auditionanswer. Thanks for your support - we sincerely appreciate every donation, like, and tweet.

Performer Resources

  • Bookster App        

  •   ScriptMatch                                   

  •   Get Creative Social Media

  • Mustard Seed Coaching

  • ActorsComfort

  •  Rock the Performance


FOR CASTING

To learn more about how AuditionAnswer helps Casting Professionals, check out our website. If you’re interested in becoming a Beta Tester, click HERE. The Beta Tester with the most referrals will win an iPad to use at future auditions.

Following our Indiegogo Campaign and Beta Test, we will reveal the new and improved version of AuditionAnswer. At such time, our standard pricing guide will be implemented for Casting Professionals. Pricing will differ from company to company, depending on number of auditions, size of auditions, and number of shows to cast. It is our priority to keep costs as reasonable as possible, so that all organizations can utilize our services.


Our primary goal is to create a casting solution that best suits your needs, so kindly contact us with any feedback, questions, or comments. We’d love to hear about your current audition process and figure out how AuditionAnswer can best support that. To see AuditionAnswer in action, please request a demo and we will guide you through the software step by step.

Once you receive your AuditionAnswer login credentials, you can create your Casting Team and schedule auditions. If you would like AuditionAnswer to be present during your audition to help with the sign-in and applicant viewing process, let us know. We’re here to help you every step of the way!

story:
Our Story:

The Other Theatre Company is a 501c3 Non-Profit Theatre Company based in Chicago. We are collective of artists dedicated to telling stories of those who are othered by systems of oppression. 

Join us this holiday season at the Greenhouse Theatre Center in Chicago for our world premiere musical parody!

Yando Lopez and Chicago drag queen sensation Dixie Lynn Cartwright star in this musical parody of Elf. After Santa Claus retires, his wicked son begins a not-so-jolly reign as the new head of Christmas. The North Pole begins to crumble under his tyrannical rule, and Barney the Elf is forced to leave his home. Soon he embarks on a fabulous journey of self-discovery (or is it elf-discovery?) that lands him in one of Chicago's hottest drag bars. But can he truly leave Christmas behind for a new life in the big city? Barney the Elf brings musical numbers galore and plenty of queer holiday cheer to Chicago's Greenhouse Theatre Center. ​

What We Need & What You Get:

The Other Theatre Company needs your help! Every dollar raised will go toward the following:

  • Performance Space Rental: $3,000
  • Tier N Equity Wages + Paymaster fees + 12 Non-Equity Performers + Production Team/Designers/Management: $6,800 
  • Scenic Budget + Costumes + Makeup + Lighting + Props + Publicity + Marketing Fees: $5,800
As you can see - we need all the help we can get! We're only in our second season, and 100% of our funding comes from private donations and ticket sales. While we are consistently applying for grants, it can be incredibly difficult for a young company to receive that type of funding. We need YOU!
We have fantastic PERKS! Check out our Perks tab to see what you'll get for donating your hard-earned money!
Yes - this show is silly and wonderful, but it reinforces the mission of our organization: Discrimination of ANY kind is intolerable. Whether it's in the classroom, the workplace, or at the North Pole.
Our 2014 INDIEGOGO campaign was hugely successful! We asked for $2500 and we raised $3400. Please help us reach or SURPASS our goal for 2015!

Other Ways You Can Help:

We know that some of you might not be in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools! Send our link to everyone you know! 

Thank you for helping The Other Theatre Company make our world a better, more just place for everyone!

story:
We are Quite Right Theatre                 

Our Mission

We are a company that prides itself on creating and adapting works that transcend language barriers, making accessible and engaging theatre for a universal audience.

Our goal is to establish a European theatre network which will see Shakespeare's plays performed in places where they aren't traditionally shown, while collaborating with theatre makers across Europe to create new innovative work.

There is so much potential to develop a wide and expansive theatre network and this is our first big step in achieving this.


La nostra missione

Siamo una compagnia che si vanta di creare e adattare le opere che trascendono le barriere linguistiche, fare teatro accessibile e coinvolgente per un pubblico universale.

Il nostro obiettivo è quello di creare una rete europea di teatro che vedrà opere di Shakespeare eseguite in luoghi dove non lo sono tradizionalmente, collaborando con i responsabili del teatro in tutta Europa per creare lavoro innovativo.

C'è tanto potenziale per sviluppare una rete di teatro ampia ed espansiva, e questo è il nostro primo grande passo per raggiungere questo obiettivo.


                                            


The Shakespeare in Puglia Project: Measure for Measure  

This October we will be touring an adaptation of 'Measure for Measure' in London and Puglia, Italy.

The tour (5th-19th October) will therefore have three important aims.

·  10 performances of Measure for Measure in theatres and spaces across Puglia

·  Using the play as inspiration we will lead Shakespeare and theatre workshops for local schools and communities, working with aspiring actors young and old.

·  Working with theatre companies in Puglia to develop new projects inspired by each other’s culture, with the aim of collaborating in the future.

Our retelling of Shakespeare's classic problem play is set in a world in post-apocalyptic chaos, threatened by disease and disorder, where the pimps speak reason and the politicians breed fear.  The Duke has a plan to restore it, but it may come at a severe cost.

This will be our biggest challenge yet as we involve the audience and bring the drama to life taking them on a journey of Vienna under the rule of evangelical fascism.


Shakespeare in Puglia Progetto: Measure for Measure

Il prossimo ottobre porteremo in tour un adattamento di 'Measure for Measure' a Londra e in Puglia.

Il tour (5-19 OTTOBRE) avrà quindi tre obiettivi importanti:

· 10 spettacoli nei teatri e luoghi della Puglia

· Usando il Teatro come ispirazione, porteremo Shakespeare in laboratori teatrali per scuole e comunità locali che lavorano con aspiranti attori giovani e meno giovani.

· Lavorare con associazioni e compagnie teatrali in Puglia per sviluppare nuovi progetti ispirati alla cultura di ciascuno, con l'obiettivo di una collaborazione duratura.

La nostra rivisitazione del classico di Shakespeare è ambientata in un mondo nel caos post-apocalittico, minacciata dalla malattia e governata dal disordine, dove i protettori parlano di ragione ed i politici di razza e paura. Il Duca ha un piano per il ripristino, ma può avvenire solo con gravi conseguenze.

La sfida più grande sarà ancora una volta quella di riuscire al meglio nel coinvolgimento di un pubblico di un’altra lingua nella rappresentazione del dramma della vita shakespeariano attraverso un viaggio nella Vienna sotto il dominio del fascismo evangelista.



We aren't new to this


                           


The new Measure for Measure project is the latest in a series of reimagined Shakespeare texts that the company members have been involved in.

In 2014 we staged King Lear under old company name 'Without Walls Theatre Company' an adaptation which focused on the generational divide within families during the emigration of Italians into America in the 1920s.  This marked a second outing for many Quite Right's members after Romeo y Giulieta in 2012 with company 'By Any Other Name', and we have been blown away by the audience's reaction.  

This year we will be combining modern theatre techniques with the classical text, keeping the original language intact to provide audiences with a production never before realised but that can be enjoyed by audiences regardless of language or age.


LE PASSATE EDIZIONI


'Measure for Measure' è solo l'ultimo di una serie di testi di Shakespeare rielaborati per la Puglia, in cui i membri della compagnia sono stati coinvolti.

Nel 2014 è stato portato in scena 'Re Lear' sotto il vecchio nome della società ' Without Walls Theatre Company '. Un riadattamento incentrato sul divario generazionale all'interno delle famiglie mafiose americane durante l'emigrazione degli italiani negli anni ‘20.

Questa fu, per molti del cast, la seconda esperienza dopo 'Romeo e Giulietta' portato in scena in Puglia nel 2012 con la compagnia ' With Any Other Name '. 

E siamo sempre rimasti spiazzati dalla reazione del pubblico.

Quest'anno gli spettacoli avverranno combinando tecniche teatrali moderne con il testo classico , mantenendo la lingua originale intatta per fornire al pubblico una produzione mai realizzata, ma che può essere goduta indipendentemente dalla lingua o dall'età .


How can you help us make this happen?


Our work is about connecting with new audiences in communities everywhere and we do this out of a labour of love, not money.  Our team of 10 is made up of people who simply love staging theatre that moves and entertains people. 

To make this production happen, to realise this incredibly exciting project, we need your help.  We are asking for a donation towards our production costs that are all based on the lowest possible budget that we could generate. 


The total cost of the project, based on the tightest budget, will be a little over £5,000.  This excludes all costs associated with our 3 week rehearsal period. 


We will not make any money from this production.  

This is broken down into;

£1300 for travel. This will be for budget flights to Italy for 10 company members, & cost of transporting props/costumes
 
£1000 for van hire for 2 weeks between performance venues around the region.

£1000 for self-catering.

£1100 for Airbnb rented accommodation for 2 weeks in Puglia.

£200 for publicity (posters, flyers, social media campaign, programmes)

£400 for costume/props/set.  

Come potete aiutarci perché questo accada?


Il nostro lavoro si basa sul collegamento con un nuovo pubblico nelle comunità e si tratta di un lavoro d'amore, non per denaro. Il nostro team è composto da 10 persone che amano il teatro che si muove e si diverte.

Per realizzare questa produzione abbiamo bisogno del vostro aiuto.

Chiediamo una donazione per i costi di produzione che sono tutti basati sul bilancio più basso possibile che si possa generare.

Il costo totale del progetto, basato su un budget ristretto, sarà poco più di £ 5.000. Sono esclusi tutti i costi associati al periodo di prove di tre settimane.

Non guadagneremo soldi da questa produzione.

I costi sono suddivisi in;

£ 1.300 per il viaggio. Comprende i voli per l'Italia per 10 membri della compagnia, e spese di trasporto strumenti / costumi

£ 1000 per il furgone a noleggio per il periodo di 2 settimane in giro per la regione.

£ 1.000 per il cibo.

£ 1.100 per un alloggio di due 2 settimane in Puglia.

200 sterline per la pubblicità (manifesti, volantini, campagna sui social media, programmi)

£ 400 per costume / puntelli / set.


Rewards
In return for your kind donations, you will receive a 'thank you' token.  
Based on the size of your donation, we will send you one of the following: a bottle of Puglian olive oil, a poster, a t-shirt, a free show ticket, a professionally taken performance portrait, a performed monologue, workshop place, dinner with the cast and even a personal performance of the show for your family and friends.  Any support you give will be warmly appreciated and we hope you enjoy our ways of saying thanks. 

Ricompense

In base alle dimensioni della donazione, invieremo le seguenti:

bottiglia di olio di oliva pugliese, un poster, una t-shirt, un biglietto gratuito per uno spettacolo, un ritratto professionale, cena con il cast e anche una prestazione personale dello spettacolo per la vostra famiglia e amici. Ogni supporto offerto verrà calorosamente apprezzato e ci auguriamo che gradirete il nostro modo di dire grazie.



Use your voice
Mostly we want to hear from you, get in touch and find out more, helps us spread the word even if you don't have any spare pennies to give.

Usa la tua voce

Vogliamo sentire voi, entrare in contatto e saperne di più, aiutateci a diffondere l'iniziativa, anche se non vi è possibile donare un centesimo.


  https://www.facebook.com/quiterighttheatre?ref=hl

 https://twitter.com/QuiteRightTC






The Impact            


We look for opportunities to unite and work with companies from countries world wide and we are lucky to have some amazing partners in Liola Eventi who have helped us produce our recent tours.  With their help the people of Puglia have been able to experience texts that have been cut and adapted for their enjoyment but also gain a unique experience.  Our aim is to one day be collaborating with companies across Europe and beyond to bring the power of Shakespeare to those who have never had the chance to see it staged.

With your help you are thus a patron of our company and you have shown us your support for our ethos to transcend language through theatre. Your contribution not only directly helps us put together and organise the Measure for Measure Shakespeare tour but also allows us to continue producing meaningful work for communities everywhere including yours.  So please join our ever expanding theatre network.

L'IMPATTO

Cerchiamo partner provenienti da paesi di tutto il mondo per  collaborare con noi.

Siamo fortunati ad avere supporto eccellente come quello delle persone di Liola Eventi che ci hanno aiutato a produrre i nostri tour più recenti. Con il loro aiuto, i pugliesi hanno potuto sperimentare i testi riadattati e fare un’esperienza unica.

Vogliamo collaborare con organizzazioni e compagnie di tutta Europa e portare la potenza di Shakespeare a chi non ha mai avuto la possibilità di vederlo in scena.

Con il vostro aiuto diventate quindi un patrocinatore della nostra compagnia e ci dimostrate il supporto per il nostro ethos a trascendere il linguaggio attraverso il teatro.

Il vostro contributo non solo aiuta direttamente a mettere insieme e organizzare il tour di "Misure for Misure" di Shakespeare, ma ci permette anche di continuare a produrre lavoro utile per le comunità in tutto il mondo tra cui il sottoscritto.

Quindi, per favore fate parte della nostra rete di teatro in continua espansione.


Risks & Challenges  


Embarking on a project like this commands its fair share of stage fright, however the respect you give to someone who goes up there and does it anyway is what we hope you'll appreciate about our project.  There is nothing easy about this process. 3 weeks to rehearse, devise and formulate a Shakespeare adaptation designed for an audience that doesn't speak the same language is not an easy feat.  The cast and crew are giving up large amounts of time to complete this project, and with it will come the usual stresses and mayhem but we chose this life for a reason and we are dedicated to the cause.

                               


This is our third Shakespeare in Italy, and by far our most difficult, but then we said that the first two times and should disaster strike at the climax, the show will go on, and might even be better.


RISCHI e SFIDE

Imbarcarsi su un progetto come questo comporta la sua giusta quota di paura da palcoscenico, ma il rispetto che si dà a qualcuno che fa, è quello che ci auguriamo che riconoscete nel nostro lavoro.

Non c'è nulla di facile: 3 settimane per provare, elaborare e formulare un adattamento di Shakespeare pensato per un pubblico di lingua differente. Il cast e la troupe stanno impiegando grandi quantità di tempo per completare questo progetto, e con esso arriverà anche il solito stress, ma abbiamo scelto questa vita per una ragione e ci sono dedicati pienamente alla causa.

Questo è il nostro terzo Shakespeare in Italia, e si figura essere quello più difficile. Come abbiam detto le altre due volte, ci dovesse colpire un disastro sul più bello, lo spettacolo andrà avanti, e potrebbe essere anche meglio.



                   Thank You!

Anything you do now to support our cause, whether that's giving a pound or even a shout out is enormously appreciated.  Thank you all so much and we look forward to seeing you in post-apocalyptic Vienna (London, Puglia)


Grazie!

Tutto ciò che fate ora per sostenere la nostra causa, sia che state dando un euro o anche un urlo è enormemente apprezzato. Grazie davvero a tutti e non vediamo l'ora di vedervi nella post-apocalittica Vienna (Londra, Puglia)

 Our Mission
We are a company that prides itself on creating and adapting works that transcend language barriers, making accessible and engaging theatre for a universal audience.
Our goal is to establish a European theatre network which will see Shakespeare's plays performed in places where they aren't traditionally shown, while collaborating with theatre makers across Europe to create new innovative work.
There is so much potential to develop a wide and expansive theatre network and this is our first big step in achieving this.

story:
Our Project:

The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company is a non-profit arts organization founded by Karen Alwin in 1981.  Our mission is to provide excellent pre-professional training, education, and outstanding performance opportunities to young dancers (age 8 - 18), and to offer high quality dance entertainment to its community.

Our Eternal Elegance Fund was created to honor the late Ms. Edna Nation.  She was not only the mother of Ms. Karen Alwin, she also played a vital role in The Performers' performance opportunities.  In particular, she had an artistic eye and a vision for excellence in beautifying each production.  She strived to make sure our dancers had the props and costumes they needed to catch the eye of the audience and exude the emotion of the dances.  

This fund allows us to create new pieces and beautify those pieces with amazing costumes and props.  A beautiful example of this fund 'at work' is our newest piece, On Our Knees, featured for the first time during our 2014 production of Christmas Joy.  Pictures of this number are highlighted in the Gallery Tab.  

We continually need funds to add new pieces to our repertoire of current numbers and to replace/update costumes and props.  The costs associated with doing this is astounding!  An average new piece costs approximately $4,300.  That's an average based on 10 dancers in a new piece.  


 What You Get:

We are offering a variety of fun and valuable incentives for your donation.  We truly appreciate your support of The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company!

 The Impact:
 Christmas Joy 2015 will be our 31st production of the show and How Love Wins 2016 will be in its 3rd year of production.  We strive to keep the shows fresh and up to date while preserving the beauty of classical ballet and the spirit of jazz dance. 
By contributing to our cause, you will be supporting these dancers in their dance education and in their pursuit of providing a beautiful, novel, and emotional experience to their audience. 

 Challenges:

The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company rely on dues, sponsorships, fundraising, and donations to bring to life their two primary productions:  Christmas Joy and How Love Wins.  Without the generosity of people like you, we would not survive.  Your donation will make a very positive impact on these young dancers.  It will allow them the ability to express themselves in new ways through the art of dance.  

Testimonials:

"It has been a beautiful and unique privilege to journey the "Christmas Joy" story for the past 30 years.  To have been part of the early creation of the production and involved still 30 years later is a true blessing in my life.  The dancers that I have had the opportunity to work with, create on and mentor over these decades have been a true delight for me.  Many of them now are colleagues and dear friends in my own life which is such a testament to the rich history in our "Chrismas Joy" experience.   It has become a loving collaborative between dancers and their faith, and an opportunity to speak silently the profound story of the birth of Christ.  
     The production has grown, matured and changed over the past 30 years and yet it has been exciting to see the rich traditions preserved in ways to honor the history of the creation of Christmas Joy.   The profound commitment from Karen Alwin, the Performers Ballet and Jazz Co. Board and the new artistic leader Wendy Miner to bring this production to the audiences every year is an impressive achievement and a act of faith each year to follow this mission.  The numbers of young dancers who have journeyed through the "Christmas Joy" experience is an example of the fruit of this ministry. The experience not only touches and grows the heart of an audience member but each little heart out on that stage each year is given the opportunity to pour their passion into telling the story of Gods love.   Their faith is challenged and grown in the process.  Story after story of lives that were changed through this experience.  Brings tears to my eyes just thinking about it.  And the sweet legacy of dancers that Karen and I trained way back when, bringing their beautiful little children to participate in Christmas Joy.  The history is rich. The history is full of love.  
   It's a very special production. It is about faith.  It is upheld and maintained by faith. By the strong power of prayer and by very extraordinary people working very hard to fulfill the purpose God has given them to share. It is a privilege to be a part of it and to share in the mission.  Come share in the "Joy" this Christmas."         

~Lynn Cox, Founding Choreographer

"My daughter Rachel has been a Performer for nine years now.  It has been a wonderful experience that has really helped her to grow in her dancing, confidence and stage presence.  She has also made many good friends in the company.  It is like a second family."

~Anne Jones, mother of Rachel Jones

"I have had the wonderful privilege of being a part of "The Performers" family for 16 years.  Throughout my time with this group I was inspired by the commitment to excellence - whether it be in the quality of the dancing, the gorgeous choreography or the exquisite costuming.  Nothing "The Performers" produced was anything less than 'excellent'.  When the curtain goes up on a "Performers" production, I am certain of one thing - I am about to be entertained by a performance of the highest quality.  Ms. Edna Nation had more than just an eye for lovely costumes.  Ms. Nation saw what could be beautiful in every aspect of "The Performers" productions and saw to it that her visions were achieved.  To this day, Ms. Nation's call to excellence is in the heart and mind of every person her life touched.  She is missed but her legacy of beauty and excellence lives on."

Ms. Edna Nation with McKee's
~Denise McKee,  mother of Cassidy McKee

"Wow, I can’t imagine what path my career would have taken if I hadn’t had the exposure to dance and performing that this company gave me. It truly was one of the best things that I could have had as a young student dreaming to become a professional dancer. A youth dance company lead by such amazing teachers, mentors, and organizers is hard to come by. Ms. Karen and Ms. Lynn made sure we carried the discipline, respect, and dedication we needed to accomplish great things, and Ms. Nation made sure we did it with class.  I will never forget the mark that these women have made on my life. They gave us the exposure and skills needed to embark on a dance career and I continue to feel supported by these ladies on a daily basis 30 years later. Amazing! I can’t thank The Performers and my mentors enough for preparing me in such a supportive, encouraging, and well rounded way. I am forever grateful and I will continue to hold Ms. Nations’ spirit close to heart. I think the Eternal Elegance Fund is a perfect way to continue to honor her and all that she has done for us!"  

~Andrea Basile

"Being a part of the Performer’s is something that has shaped my life in more than just dance-related aspects. The Performer’s taught me to value the pursuit excellence in every task; to find artistry and passion past the surface level; to respect talent and hard work; and to truly cherish the friendships, memories, and lessons I was privileged to experience for my 12 years as a member. Without The Performer’s, I would not be the dancer I get to be today; but more than that, I wouldn’t be the person I grew to be because of this organization."  

~Cassidy McKee 

"Being a member of "The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company" was one of the best experiences of my life! Like many members of The Performers I went on to dance professionally as well as teach throughout the United States. I am now a small business owner, my business is centered around ballet /fitness fusion giving everyone the chance to be a ballerina! My entire career,  my entire livelihood and my entire means of supporting myself, my husband and my 2 children is all thanks to The Performers!  The Performers also gave me the opportunity to perform in Christmas Joy! Christmas Joy was one of the main highlights of my childhood.  It taught me at a very young age that being a Christian is who I am and I can share my faith through the talents that my Lord has blessed me with." 

~Ashley Solomon Onstott  (Please see picture in The Gallery)

 

About the Artistic Staff for The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company:

Karen Alwin, Founder:  Karen Alwin has taught dance for more than 40 years.  She was the owner and founder of Alwin School of the Dance (1975 - 2010) and the founder of The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company.  Ms. Alwin is a member of Dance Masters of America, Cecchetti Council of America, and Chicago National Dance Masters.  Ms. Alwin holds a teacher's certificate for Intermediate Professional grade for Cecchetti Method through Cecchetti Council of America.  She takes great pride in the quality of this company's productions and workshops, and the training and experience the company offers both students and guests.

Wendy Miner, Artistic Director:  Wendy Miner began her study of dance at the age of three under the instruction of Karen Alwin.  Wendy also grew up as a member of The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company.  She began teaching and coaching rehearsals at age 14 and performed leading roles in Performers' productions.  Wendy went on to study ballet at both the University of Utah and Chicago Ballet and studied jazz at Lou Conte's school in Chicago and EDGE Performing Arts Center in Los Angeles.  Wendy danced with companies in Chicago, Los Angeles and Albuquerque, including Touch Dance Ensemble and Luis Fuente Ballet New Mexico.  Wendy also taught Master Classes across the country and was on faculty with Line Ballet School.  After returning to New Mexico, Wendy earned a Bachelor's degree in Psychology from The University of New Mexico with additional studies in biology and nutrition.  She has received her Teacher's Certificate for Cecchetti grades one through four.  In addition to teaching, Wendy is an accomplished choreographer and has commissioned full-length shows for both The Performers and Santa Ana Star Casino as well as numerous ensemble pieces and solos.  In 2010, Wendy became the new Artistic Director of The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company.  She currently owns Magnify Dance Center in Albuquerque, NM where she also teaches.  Wendy and her husband, Allen, are the proud parents of three children. 


 Other Ways You Can Help:

Spreading the word is another great way you can support The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company.  Just use the Indiegogo share tools.  Thanks so much!

The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company:  https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Performers-B...
story_txt:
Our Project: The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company is a non-profit arts organization founded by Karen Alwin in 1981.  Our mission is to provide excellent pre-professional training, education, and outstanding performance opportunities to young dancers (age 8 - 18), and to offer high quality dance entertainment to its community.
Our Eternal Elegance Fund was created to honor the late Ms. Edna Nation.  She was not only the mother of Ms. Karen Alwin, she also played a vital role in The Performers' performance opportunities.  In particular, she had an artistic eye and a vision for excellence in beautifying each production.  She strived to make sure our dancers had the props and costumes they needed to catch the eye of the audience and exude the emotion of the dances.  
This fund allows us to create new pieces and beautify those pieces with amazing costumes and props.  A beautiful example of this fund 'at work' is our newest piece, On Our Knees, featured for the first time during our 2014 production of Christmas Joy.  Pictures of this number are highlighted in the Gallery Tab.  
We continually need funds to add new pieces to our repertoire of current numbers and to replace/update costumes and props.  The costs associated with doing this is astounding!  An average new piece costs approximately $4,300.  That's an average based on 10 dancers in a new piece.  

 What You Get:
We are offering a variety of fun and valuable incentives for your donation.  We truly appreciate your support of The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company!
 The Impact: Christmas Joy 2015 will be our 31st production of the show and How Love Wins 2016 will be in its 3rd year of production.  We strive to keep the shows fresh and up to date while preserving the beauty of classical ballet and the spirit of jazz dance.  By contributing to our cause, you will be supporting these dancers in their dance education and in their pursuit of providing a beautiful, novel, and emotional experience to their audience.   Challenges:
  The Performers Ballet and Jazz Company rely on dues, sponsorships, fundraising, and donations to bring to life their two primary productions:  Christmas Joy and How Love Wins.  Without the generosity of people like you, we would not survive.  Your donation will make a very positive impact on these young dancers.  It will allow them the ability to express themselves in new ways through the art of dance.

The history is full of love.     It's a very special production. It is about faith.  It is upheld and maintained by faith. By the strong power of prayer and by very extraordinary people working very hard to fulfill the purpose God has given them to share. It is a privilege to be a part of it and to share in the mission.  Come share in the "Joy" this Christmas."         
~Lynn Cox, Founding Choreographer

story:
Short Summary

The Wayne Densch Performing Arts Center in Sanford, Florida, formerly known as the Ritz Theater, is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that has fully restored and operates a historic theater that was first opened in 1923.  Unlike some organizations, WDPAC provides the opportunity for performers to appear onstage without the payment of dues or any other cost.  At the community theater level, we have taken on some projects that other theaters our size have avoided – shows such as “Les Miserables”, “Miss Saigon” and “The Mystery of Edwin Drood”.  Each production utilizes a live orchestra; we do not use canned music, as we want the shows to retain their authenticity.  The theater, which seats over 500, is a significant economic driver in the community.

In our continuing efforts to do more – both for our immediate community and for the larger Central Florida theater community – we will be the first Florida community theater to stage “Bring It On: The Musical”.  As the rights for this show have only recently become available, we are looking for this debut show to serve as an outreach to the “next” generation of theatergoers – to show them that musicals are and can be relevant for them.  We hope that by staging shows like this one that we will be able to instill a love of theater in people who haven’t previously experienced the power of theater. 

This is where you come in.  We have the opportunity to use the original costumes from the professional production of “Bring It On: The Musical”, but the cost to do so is something that exceeds our minimal production budget.  Although we will continue to utilize the talents of a live orchestra, we want to make sure that for the premiere performance of this show that we are able to make this production truly spectacular.  We believe that if we are able to do this, we will be able to keep this show “real” and authentic.  Please help us to elevate the quality of this production to a new level.  Please consider making your tax deductible donation to our cause and helping us to bring a new generation to a love of theater. 


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • The cost of bringing in the costumes is $5,000.  As we cannot self-fund this amount, we are asking for your help in bringing a bit of Broadway to our community.  
  • As a token of our appreciation, we are offering the following:

  • For a donation of:

      $25 – A Pom-Pom

      $50 – A button saying “I brought on, Bring It On”

      $100 – A program signed by the entire cast

      $200 – An 11 x 17 poster for the show – signed by the cast.

    If you are in Central Florida and donate, we are offering for a donation of $500, 4 tickets to a performance of your choice, your name in the program honoring your donation, a signed program, and a signed poster.

    For a donation of $750, you would receive 6 tickets to a performance of your choice, your name in the program honoring your donation, recognition on the theater website, a signed program, a signed poster, and a cast photo.


  • The cost of making and purchasing the costumes is approximately $3,500 so that is what we will use the money for if we do not reach our goal.

The Impact

As a community theater you can imagine that we do not have a very high budget for our shows and purchasing the rights to a show and the retention of a live orchestra eats up most of that. 

  • We want the next generation of theater goers to develop the same passion that we have.
  • This particular show is more than a musical about cheerleading, it is about diversity, it is about becoming self-esteem and becoming what you set out to accomplish, no matter where you start in life.
  • We would love for you to be a part of making this happen!

Risks & Challenges

We realize that this will be a challenge but we are hoping that with your help we can make it happen. We are also working on several sponsors to help us achieve our goal.

  • We will also try some other fundraising techniques, the cast is willing.
  • Since our cast is young we know that social media is what they do and hope that helps us achieve our goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time please do the next best thing and share our info with your friends!

  • The more people hat know about us the better chance we have.
  •  Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Imagine being an actor or director or writer from a smallish town in Virginia, and you get this amazing opportunity to perform in New York City. Well, that happened to us! Eeek!!! We will perform Robert Wray's play BULLET FOR UNACCOMPANIED HEART at The FringeNYC Festival this August. The play is the comic/tragic tale of Dugan (Rodney Umble) who is being held hostage by the ghost of his ex-girlfriend, Anya (Mariah Johnson) and her sometimes deaf henchman Milo (Robert Ryland). The play is directed by Marty Moore. The FringeNYC attracts a wide array of producers, performers, agents, directors, and theater lovers from around the world, the opportunity to have our production in front of them is amazing and humbling.  

What We Need 

We are looking to raise $5,000. This will help cover a multitude of expenses.

•Festival fees, insurance and publicity $2500.

•Transportation and meals for the cast and crew $1500.

•Set, props, costumes, sound, lighting $400.

•Staffing in NYC $600. 

To be honest, this is a low estimate, some of us went to FringeNYC 2014 and know the expenses can add up to much more, we just hoping to defray some of the cost. 

The Impact

We realize that donating to a small group of theater folks isn't top on everyones list, every little bit helps us make this dream come true. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd also be thrilled just to have you in the audience. BULLET FOR UNACCOMPANIED HEART will be performed at Teatro Sea, 107 Suffolk Street New York, NY 10002. Listed below are the performance dates:

SAT 8/15 9:30pm

TUE 8/18 7:00pm 

FRI 8/21 4:45pm

TUE 8/25 4:45pm

THU 8/27 9:30pm

Thank you in advance for contributing in any way, even if it's just sending positive vibes from afar - although, money will put NY pizza in bellies of starving actors. :)

story:
ABOUT THE SHOW

Orford, the Suffolk coast, 1167. A fisherman hauls up a mysterious catch: a scaly, glistening creature from the depths of the sea. Man or monster? Is the wild man barbaric or simply free from the constraints of society? A tale from English folklore, fusing puppetry and video projections with live action and music. 

Rust & Stardust is a new Sussex collective combining theatre, puppetry, animation and music, through storytelling, folklore and mythology.

Following a three show run at the Brighton Fringe, including two SOLD OUT performances, The Wild Man of Orford will be venturing to Scotland for the annual Edinburgh Fringe in August. 

We have the costumes, we have the set, we have the beautiful puppets, cracking animation and a wonderful cast....all we need is your help.

WHAT WOULD YOUR DONATION COVER?

  • Travel Expenses: With the majority of the Company being based in Sussex, it's going to prove a lengthy (but hopefully enjoyable) journey by public transport, beginning at King's Cross.
  • Accommodation: We will not be going alone! Rust & Stardust will be working with Atomic Force Productions as part of "The Sea of Stories" during the run. The lodgings have been booked. However, being the Scottish capital and a fair few of us to accommodate, it's going to put us a bit out of pocket
  • Cast & Crew: We love what we do, it's great fun but it is our living as well. With your donation, no matter how big or small, you will be supporting our team with a basic wage and for that we would be truly thankful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see the show! The Wild Man of Orford is suitable and fun for all the family.
If you are going to the Edinburgh Fringe this August, we will be there from the 10th to 23rd at the Sweet Grassmarket, everday at 12:45pm.
For tickets and more info, follow the link below:
 https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/475805-the-wild-man-of-orford/
Check out the Atomic Productions's shows to!
Beowulf:
https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/482558-beowulf/
The Tale of Tommy O'Quire:
https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/482751-the-tale-of-tommy-oquire/

ABOUT THE SHOW Orford, the Suffolk coast, 1167. A fisherman hauls up a mysterious catch: a scaly, glistening creature from the depths of the sea. Man or monster? Is the wild man barbaric or simply free from the constraints of society? A tale from English folklore, fusing puppetry and video projections with live action and music. Rust & Stardust is a new Sussex collective combining theatre, puppetry, animation and music, through storytelling, folklore and mythology.
Following a three show run at the Brighton Fringe, including two SOLD OUT performances, The Wild Man of Orford will be venturing to Scotland for the annual Edinburgh Fringe in August. 
We have the costumes, we have the set, we have the beautiful puppets, cracking animation and a wonderful cast....all we need is your help.
WHAT WOULD YOUR DONATION COVER?
 

Travel Expenses: With the majority of the Company being based in Sussex, it's going to prove a lengthy (but hopefully enjoyable) journey by public transport, beginning at King's Cross.

Accommodation: We will not be going alone! Rust & Stardust will be working with Atomic Force Productions as part of "The Sea of Stories" during the run. The lodgings have been booked. However, being the Scottish capital and a fair few of us to accommodate, it's going to put us a bit out of pocket

Cast & Crew: We love what we do, it's great fun but it is our living as well. With your donation, no matter how big or small, you will be supporting our team with a basic wage and for that we would be truly thankful.
  Other Ways You Can Help
Come and see the show! The Wild Man of Orford is suitable and fun for all the family.
If you are going to the Edinburgh Fringe this August, we will be there from the 10th to 23rd at the Sweet Grassmarket, everday at 12:45pm.
For tickets and more info, follow the link below:

 https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/475805-the-wild-man-of-orford/

Check out the Atomic Productions's shows to!
Beowulf:

https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/482558-beowulf/

The Tale of Tommy O'Quire:

https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/482751-the-tale-of-tommy-oquire/

story:
Raising Revolution at the Children's Peace Theatre July 2015

The production Raising Revolution explores questions critical to understanding what democracy truly is and what is necessary to achieve it.  It will inspire children and youth to become more curious, compassionate and creative about their role in the future of democracy. 

From now until July 6th we need to raise $7,500 to support 20 children to attend camp on bursaries and to cover the cost of a nutritious snack program.  If the majority of people viewing this campaign donate @$20 or more we can reach our goal.  Can you join us?  We are a registered Canadian Charity so we can offer you tax receipts based on the value of your donation minus the value of any perks you received.

Every year, Children's Peace Theatre runs a three-week Camp where accomplished professional artists and marginalized youth work with 45 children aged 8-13 in a collaborative process to create an original production based on explorations of social issues that impact their lives and teach skills in Conflict Transformation. 

Some of Toronto’s top theatre and music artists are on board for this years production of Raising Revolution.  Artists like Brownman Ali and Tanisha Taitt will be guiding children and youth to explore some critical questions like,

“What is the current state of our democracy?”

 “If there can be no peace without justice, can there be democracy without justice?” 

Raising Revolution will be performed for over 600 audience members in an arts underserved community.

Our Plea

I joined the team here at Children’s Peace Theatre 11 years ago because I believe that each and everyone of us must be engaged in creating peace in our own lives. When I saw how the Children’s Peace Theatre was using theatre and art to transform conflict in the lives of youth in my community, I wanted to help children and youth to use Courage, Compassion and Creativity to build peaceful relationships with others. 

For 15 years Children’s Peace Theatre has been Creating a Culture of Peace by engaging children and youth in exploring the issues impacting their lives using the arts.  Our flagship program Peace Camp teaches Conflict Transformation in action and bravely explores some of our societies most entrenched issues.

I am so excited about this years production 'Raising Revolution' which is about the raising of voices, the raising of consciousness, a summoning of the moral energy of our youth, and a call to action for all people who believe in the power of people to fight for justice and dignity and to shape history in the process.  It also refers to the raising of our children.  How do we raise young people to see past their own their comforts, and past the version of the truth spun by the media, to the question of how their government operates and how it treats ALL of its people?  How do we raise young people who care enough about TRUE democracy to question and challenge its impostor?

We are a tiny organization that packs a big punch. In the past 15 years we have trained over 10,000 children and youth in Conflict Transformation and provided much needed arts programming and space for children and youth to create and dream.

In 2014 we were honoured as a finalist for the Toronto Arts Foundation youth award. 

We’re committed to using Courage, Compassion and Creativity to make a difference in the lives of children and youth and to build more peaceful communities, but we can’t do it without your help.

With fierce love,

Karen Emerson, 

Artistic Director, Children’s Peace Theatre


The Impact Of Your Donation

This summer 45 children will participate in our highly acclaimed three week theatre camp and 12 youth will have a chance to work as Guides and learn theatre, life and leadership skills. 

But you know as I do that there are a lot of barriers for many children in our community that prevent them from being able to attend programs like this.  

With your support, we’ll be able to provide bursaries to 20 children to participate who otherwise might not have access to artistic processes and opportunities to express themselves creatively, about democracy, community and theatre.   

About The Artists

Actor-director-playwright, Tanisha Taitt is back for a third year as director of this year’s Peace Camp 2015 Summer Theatrical Production entitled “Raising Revolution”.  As an artist, Tanisha is well known for her work with young people and adults addressing deep-rooted global issues with powerful theatre. 

“In an election year, I am incredibly interested in having children and youth become curious about and excited by the political process.  I am even more excited, though, about having young people invested at a deeper level -- asking the bigger and more profound questions about their government and its ideologies.  I know that once again, Children's Peace Theatre will take these young people on an incredible investigative journey resulting in a poignant and resonant artistic creation. 

I approach this project with a goal to have those who participate in Raising Revolution come to understand the enormous power that they hold, beyond the vote.  The power of their voices, and of their choices.  I want them to know that political will, responsibility and awareness are not limited to their parents and "grown-ups".  I want them to see themselves as the promise of a better society.  I want them to know that THEY are the revolution.”  Tanisha Taitt

The Musical Director of “Raising Revolution” is BROWNMAN ALI.  Hailed as “Canada’s preeminent jazz trumpet player”, multiple Juno & National Award winning trumpeter, BROWNMNAN is a very familiar face at Children’s Peace Theatre.  BROWNMAN takes the month of July off to work at CPT’s Peace Camp, writing the music for the theatrical production and exposing the youth in the program to real-world expertise.  His outstanding work with youth is yet reason another to support this year's production of Raising Revolution.

                    


Ways You Can Support Us

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

  •  SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN with everyone you know on Social Media and more! (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) INDIEGOGO has some easy share tools for you to do just that.

  •  HELP US PROMOTE Raising Revolution on July 25th by sharing our show’s blog, viral videos and "liking" Tweets, FB Posts and Ticket links.

  •  BUY TICKETS to Raising Revolution on July 25th ! Tickets go on sale July 6th. 

  •  Become a MEMBER   http://www.childrenspeacetheatre.org/ 

  •  Become a VOLUNTEER http://www.childrenspeacetheatre.org/

story:
Robin Hood: An Elegy
Presented by Generic Ensemble Company in Partnership with The VORTEX

by Krysta Gonzales with portions devised by the Ensemble
Directed by kt shorb

Featuring: Althea Clemons, Morgan Robyn Collado, Marina DeYoe-Pedraza, Chelsea Manasseri, Cameron McKnight, Tonya Pennie, Saray de Jesus Rosales, and Taji Senior.
Dramaturgy by Anthony Watkins II and Toi Scott. Lighting Design by Paige Binder. Scenic Design by Ann Marie Gordon. Costume Design and Graphic Design by Graham Cumberbatch. Sound Design by Kendra Dobson. Stage Management by Tamara L. Farley. Images taken by Kannou. With Puppetry by Love & Monster Puppet Co.

Robin Hood: An Elegy follows a Black Robin Hood who magically transcends space and time experiencing state-sanctioned racism. Set both in 2015 and the past, Robin’s plight mirrors and invokes the ethos of #blacklivesmatter in a struggle to assert humanity, dignity, and cunning against long-standing foes. In an age-old fight against white supremacy for justice and freedom, will Robin prevail?

Why This Project Now

From the recent tragedy at Emanuel AME Church to the multiple killings of unarmed black people by the police, the last year has been turbulent in the visibility and frequency of anti-black violence. As a creative organization committed to engaging with issues that affect communities of color and ultimately "making the invisible visible," Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is producing Robin Hood: An Elegy to affirm that #blacklivesmatter, and that creativity serves to assert the humanity of marginalized people while creating space for emotion, pain, hope, and change. 

How We Will Use These Funds

Donations from this campaign will go directly toward paying creative collaborators, that include eight actors, a playwright, a director, a stage manager, two dramaturges, four designers and a puppetry team. We have already received a grant from the City of Austin, which will cover $6000 of our talent and materials costs. We are grateful to The VORTEX for underwriting our project through providing performance space and other material goods so we can direct most of our resources toward paying talent. It is our goal to pay each actor at least $500. The $4000 will insure that. It is the goal of the Generic Ensemble Company to make creative labor sustainable for all collaborators. Love makes art good, but you can't eat it. Money helps.

Let's Talk About Radical Rush

We are so proud to be partnering with The VORTEX on their Radical Rush program that reserves a bloc of free tickets in the spirit of sustainability, accessibility, and participating in the gift economy. Radical Rush tickets are released an hour before the performance starts--first come first serve. Your donation to this campaign allows us to offer our show to all patrons, regardless of their socio-economic status. 

Why We Are So Cool

The Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is one of the few troupes in Austin, and nationally, that centers people of color bodies and experiences in physically engaged, experimental, ensemble-based performance. GenEnCo has some grants and awards under its belt, and director, kt shorb, has presented work nationally. This is the most recent project aimed at asking profound questions toward social change through rigorous, dangerous, and community-conscious theatre. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help out with donating to our cause, we are looking for volunteers to run the house, be backstage, and distribute media material. Do you have a blog, radio show, or column? Talk to us and share our project with your audience!

Ticket Info

You can reserve a seat by going to The VORTEX ticketing page.

story:
Our Project

What you are supporting:

This project will be a full production of our play Curing the Void at the New York International Fringe Festival. A play we've been creating collectively  for over 2 years which has gone from readings at the Dramatists Guild, to a Workshop Residency in Montreal (Canada), and a performance at Dixon Place. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3000 to help cover:

  • Fringe Fees & Insurance Costs
  • Costuming, Props, Set, Production Value!
  • Renting Rehearsal Space
  • MARKETING! (Press releases, Postcards, Posters, etc...)
What you GET:
  • Online shout out about how awesome you are! (Good for job interviews)
  • Digital Copy of the plays ORIGINAL music by Profeta Poeta
  • Digital Recording of the play to keep watching for a lifetime!
  • Signed & Binded copy of the script by the whole cast!
  • A pair of tickets with reserved seating to a performance of your choosing!
  • Dinner with the Creative team & Cast of show
  • Executive Producer Credit in Playbill 

The Impact

Every pledge will go towards ensuring this play gets reviewed, published, and assuring its extended run within the Fringe and at a future venue.

Risks & Challenges

We're in a unique position -- we've confirmed our place in the festival and we're going either way. The risk we face without funding is that we can't pay our artists, we can't get the exposure this play needs to grow, and that we can't set the play up to have a future life beyond this festival.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us spread the word by using the share buttons on the top left 
  • Come see the show by purchasing tickets here Curing the Void @ FringeNYC
  • Leave comments of support to keep us going strong!

story:
ABOUT OUR CAMPAIGN

What is your money going towards?

The money from this campaign will be going towards rental space and marketing. One of our main challenges has been relocating from Waterloo to Toronto for rehearsals. What we fund from this campaign will help cover some of these space rental costs. As first-time producers another challenge we are facing is marketing our show. Our marketing plan is crucial for the success of our show as we generate local audiences.

What will we give you in return?

To show our appreciation for your support we would like to shower you with rewards. Every actor's dream is to receive recognition for their hard work and talent, we would like to treat you just the same for your generosity.  Have a look at the fun rewards we are offering to your right.

If any of our perks spark your interest, please click "Select a Perk" at the bottom of our campaign page. All perks will be rewarded once the campaign is closed.

Why your support is important to us?

With your support we are able to give this production the life it deserves.

Here is a current list of our show expenses:

Marketing: $1,000

Festival Participation Fees: $750

Rental Space: $780

Stage Supplies: $160


With your support we will be able to cover our main concerns which are marketing and rental space; however, in addition to the list above we also have artist fees to consider based on the success of our show in the festival, which you will help us accomplish.

WHO ARE WE?


Pace Theatre Toronto is a company co-founded by Andreea Hluscu and Meghan Jones, who are fellow Almuni from the Drama Department of the University of Waterloo.  After Pace Theatre Toronto was selected to participate in the Toronto Fringe Festival, they knew they wanted to create a show about some of their recent experiences entering the entertainment industry. With some support from their former department, they were able to workshop a part of their production before relocating to Toronto. For this production the company also includes fellow Alumni associate artists William Innes, Kandice Prosser and Zach Parsons.

ABOUT OUR SHOW

"Cut-Throat: The Isolation of Ambition" tells a story about two roommate actresses, entering the industry of the performing arts. Living in Toronto they face the struggles of low income and the resourcefulness required for their chosen career paths. Coincidently, each has a murderous past, that will come into play once they are up for the same role in an up and coming inter-arts production where the stakes are high. Our show highlights the differences between their experience, approach, and understanding of the industry, as well as how these differences work for and against their future success.

ABOUT THE TORONTO FRINGE FESTIVAL

The Toronto Fringe, a proud member of Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals (CAFF), is a worldwide network of indie theatre festivals. What makes it unique is that it is lottery based, selecting up to 150 participants out of approximately 700 applications per year. With 100% box office going to the artists, the festival allows for artistic freedom of expression and it is an opportunity for those on the margins of the performing arts. It is a great platform for theatre students to mount their first production outside of school, and where emerging artists can get their big break, while established artists can test out new work.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please help share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools via your social media. Speaking of social media, LIKE us on Facebook, FOLLOW us on Twitter and Instagram @PaceTheatreTO. We would love to hear from you.

Finally, make sure you come see our production. There is no better way to show your support.

Location: St. Vladimir Theatre, 620 Spadina Ave, Toronto, Ontario

Show Dates and Times:

July 3rd - 7:00pm 

July 4th - 5:45pm

July 6th: 10:30pm

July 7th - 8:30pm

July 8th - 12:15pm

July 10th - 4:00pm

July 11th - 10:30pm

story:
Love Sounds Bad

is a four-part musical comedy written by Jenna and Connor of Little Big Theatre. In the play, four short stories are told loosely based on our relationship experiences. If you don't cry yourself to sleep after watching, we didn't do our jobs right.

Who are we?

Jenna Berenbaum (Co-creator/Actor)
A recent graduate of the University of Saskatchewan, Jenna Berenbaum holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting. She finished her university career on the Greystone Stage as Thomas in Coram Boy and Taylor in Vernon God Little. Throughout the summer, she has been working as a production assistant with Sum Theatre and spending all her spare time with Connor. She would like to extend a huge thank you to all her friends and family who have supported her throughout the years. A special thank you to Connor Brousseau himself, without him there would be less laughs and no music.
Connor Brousseau (Co-creator/Actor/Musician)
Connor Brousseau is an actor and musician based out of Saskatoon. His most recent performances were with the Persephone Theatre Youth Tour, with the shows The Stones, and Head à Tête. Connor is one of the founding members of Little Big Theatre, and he can be seen around the city with his band Raising Acadia. Connor would like to invite you all for drinks after the show.
Wade Klassen (Co-Director)
Wade Klassen (Actor & Director) is a director and actor from Saskatoon. This past spring he made his directorial debut for the stage as assistant director for Coram Boy (Greystone Theatre). Wade is returning to the University of Saskatchewan in the fall to pursue a career in education, and  is eager to share his passion for drama and biology. When it comes to art and science, Wade is living proof that you truly can have the best of both worlds.
Caitlin Zacharias (Co-Director/Stage manager)
Caitlin is thrilled to be a part of Saskatoon's Fringe Theatre Festival this summer and eager do well as a first time stage manager. Earlier this year she made her acting debut as Thomas in Coram Boy (Greystone Theatre) and is going into her fourth year of acting at the University of Saskatchewan.  Caitlin also enjoys writing short plays with her good friend and creative partner Sarah Grummett, both making their writing/directing debut with The Legend of Bone Creek (Flloyd Youth Theatre). The two also wrote and performed Junk Mail, a short play presented at both We the Artists and Ladybits Improv comedy night. Caitlin is thankful to be a part of Love Sounds Bad and hopes you enjoy the show as much as she does.

Here's the Deal...

We need your help, because it turns out, producing amateur theatre is a pretty huge expense! But, don't worry, beautiful people! There are some pretty great perks for those of you who contribute!

  • For a $15 donation, you'll receive a poster of the show!
  • For a $25 donation, you'll get a free soundtrack of the musical!
  • For a $40 donation, you will receive a sock puppet replica from the show!
  • For a $50 donation, Jenna and Connor will write a personalized rap just for you, and post it on your Facebook wall!
  • So many perks, so little time! Get them while supplies last!

Why We Need You!

We want to put on the best show possible for you! That means we want sets, costumes, and the most complete experience we can make up!  Unfortunately, a lot of the planned budget was spent in reserving our spot in the festival, so this is a way for us to make the show we've been wanting to bring you for the past two years!
Below is an estemated budget for the show:
Fringe Application and Venue: $1000
Set: $100
Props: $50
Photographer fees: $50
Printing and Advertising: $300
Total: $1500

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Don't worry! There are many other ways you can help us with this project!

  • Share this link with others that are interested in the arts!
  • There's a pub crawl fundraiser on the 18th of July! More info here: https://www.facebook.com/events/1382546882052751/ 
  • Come to our show! It runs from July 31st to August 8th at Oskayak School! Tickets available online at http://www.25thstreettheatre.org/2015-indoor-theatre/
SHOW TIMES
Friday July 31st @ 8:45pm

Saturday August 1 @ 5:50pm

Sunday August 2 @ 2:50pm

Monday August 3 @ 7:15pm

Thursday August 6 @ 7:15pm

Friday August 7 @ 8:50pm

Saturday August 8 @ 5:50pm

story:
AIN'T NOBODY (A Civil Rights Musical)

Times were a changin' or so we thought…

The Civil Rights Movement brought out the hopes and dreams of many African Americans that every thing was changing and any thing was possible. Kaleidoscope Cultural Arts Collective (producing company Arden Blair Enterprises, LLC) is back and hitting the road with an all-new touring production of AIN'T NOBODY...A Civil Rights Musical. Spanning 20 years from the "Jim Crow Laws” of the segregated south during the 1950s to the Black Power Movement of the 1970s, “Ain’t Nobody” takes the audience on a journey through time letting them hear the real life tales of those “Freedom Fighters” who made the ultimate sacrifice of "giving their lives for equality and justice" during this revolutionary time in American History. The work pays tribute to the fact that times were definitely a changin' but with recent events  they reveal that they are just echoes in a continuous battle to eliminate worldwide injustice.

Since its inception and having garnered a life of its own, AIN'T NOBODY is a timeless musical celebration of life that proves with just a little heart and the determination of a few great accomplishments can be made!

“Explosive and thrilling! Theater-shaking intensity…a vibrant production. AIN'T NOBODY is nothing short of a masterpiece.”

OPENING JAN 2016

story:
I am self-producing my play Dutch as part of the Planet Connections Theater Festival. It is a sweet and salty romantic comedy about how hard it can be to let go of our ideas of love in order to actually experience it. 

I have a fantastic cast and crew. Super talented. I just need some help in supporting them and putting up the best show possible.

The money donated will go to technical salaries, props, costumes, and advertising.

story:
THE CAMPAIGN TO TURN THE BALLROOM AT MECHANICS HALL INTO A MODERN PERFORMANCE VENUE

Last fall, the Maine Charitable Mechanic Association (MCMA), the non-profit organization that owns and operates historic Mechanics’ Hall, located at 519 Congress Street in Portland, and Acorn Productions, a local community-based arts group, collaborated to raise over $14,000 to meet our Phase I fundraising goal. This beautiful and elegant space was designed by John Calvin Stevens, but had been out of the public eye for over half a century. These funds enabled us to accomplish needed life and safety upgrades in order to receive a public assembly license that brought the historic third-floor ballroom at Mechanics Hall back into use. 

We celebrated the re-opening of this space with a performance showcase on March 6th during First Friday, and the ballroom has since hosted a variety of events, including an evening of staged readings of new plays, two Naked Shakespeare performances, swing dances, birthday parties, classes and workshops, and even a prom!

While we are thrilled to have met our first fundraising goal, we now need to raise funds in order to complete upgrades and renovations.

The ballroom contains over 2,000 square feet of unimpeded floor space, with hardwood floors and high ceilings, making it the ideal venue for a variety of uses by theater and dance companies, educational institutions, individual instructors, and other community groups. Phase II funding will allow us to repair and load-test the fire escape, acquire lighting equipment and seating, upgrade electrical service, and provide all the minor repairs and purchases that will make the space function as a professional performance venue. Once renovations are complete, the ballroom will become a cultural, social, and educational center for its members and the community, and its location in the heart of the Arts District will make it a hub of activity for a variety of performances and celebrations.

This space has fired the imagination of Greater Portland’s arts community. We are already receiving booking inquiries for a number of exciting events, including First Friday performances by Acorn’s Naked Shakespeare Ensemble as well as other classes, lectures, and, of course, ballroom dances. With your help, we can make the Mechanics’ Hall ballroom a venue to last the ages.

WHAT YOUR DONATION BUYS

$35 – one padded armchair for the Ballroom

$50 – extension cord for the lighting system

$100 – one theater light for the Ballroom

$300 – a curtain panel for the windows in the Ballroom

$500- lighting “boom” for hanging lighting instruments

$1,000 – wireless dimmer pack for controlling lighting

$2,500 – theatrical drapes for back wall

RISKS AND CHALLENGES
Restoring an historic space always brings hidden surprises, from realizing that we don't have enough bathrooms (which we are working on) to discovering that the wiring is too old to be easily upgraded to a level that will support a full complement of theater lights.  Not to mention how to install a lighting grid in a room with an historic ceiling.  Acorn is well positioned to meet these challenges, all of which we encountered and overcame when we partnered with the Friends of St. Lawrence in 2000/01 to renovate the Parish Hall of the old St. Lawrence Church into the St. Lawrence Arts Center.

We also are already discovering that some of the requirements that users of the space have are not as easily met with the current inventory of equipment in the space.  For instance, we have no podium for lectures.  In order to address these needs, we have formed an ad-hoc committee with representatives from many community groups to help MCMA create rental policies that work for all different types of users, as well as prioritizing the acquisition of new inventory based on the users' needs.

story:
Hi friends!

My birthday is on June 7th and this year I will not be needing any gifts! 

Instead, I would like to raise £1000 to help my very talented actor friend, Valentin (no, not all Bulgarians are named Valentin/a).
He only has one year left in the Royal Central School of Speech and Drama and he needs funds for his rent and monthly expenses. 
I know £1000 will not get him far, but it's something and an easy achievable goal :)
Everyone who donates £50 or more will receive an invitation to a very special, delicious, candlelit dinner in my backyard garden :)
So please, wish me happy birthday by clicking the donate button!

story:
The great sensations are the ones that arrive independently of age. I consider myself an fortunate person because since I was 3 years old I found that sensation that would move me for the rest of my life.

My name is Femke Paloma Ramírez Rentería I am 16 years old and my biggest wish is to do what I most love: dancing. 

Throughout my artistic life I have been trained in 3 disciplines wich are: Jazz, Flamenco and Ballet.  On this last one I have had the honour to receive some awards such as distinctions for my grades in the exams applied by the Royal Academy of London. Also I have had the opportunity to participate in two contests which were: “Attitude International Dance Contest” where I won a silver medal, and participating as a competitor in the 12th National Junior & Senior Ballet Contest.

My current goal is to audition during the first 2016 trimester in the best dance schools in Europe to be accepted in one of them and making this determine the future of my career.

This is not just about a huge physical effort, strenuous training sessions and dedication… It’s also necessary to count on the economical support which will allow me to cover the expenses related to transportation, lodging and meals in those countries I’ll be auditioning for about 25 days long.

I’ve created this campaign with the purpose of collecting the money needed to make this project come true.  I’ve always been a person who looks forward to improving and learning as much as I can every single day, who fights for what she wants.

Now, the moment to ask for your help is here, so I can achieve my goal… Any donation that you can share with me will be highly appreciated and gratefully received.

Thanks for being part of my story.
