story:
WOMEN'S SHOWCASE 2016: 

Gathering for an evening of sharing, we aim to create a space that celebrates the accomplishments of female artists, specifically movement makers.  This festival will showcase performances by female choreographers and performance artists, as well as feature female visual artists, researchers, and musicians. 

In addition to highlighting the work of female artists of various mediums, the festival hopes to further strengthen the performing arts community in Charlotte by bringing artists together and creating a dialogue between the audience and performers concerning work that is being made through the female lens.

With your contribution, we are inviting you to be a part of this festival!

What We Need:

At last years Women's Showcase, we asked our artists for $40 each for the chance to perform. After the success of the show, we were able to pay the artists back their investment tripled! This year, we hope to forgo this fee to the artist and allow them to solely focus on creating.

We are raising funds to allow our artists the space to create without worrying about having to pay to perform.
Our costs to bring this festival to the community include:
  • space rental
  • theatre staff
  • advertisement
  • stipends for traveling artists
  • payment to videographers/photographers
In return, you the contributor will get recognized as a supporter of the festival, PLUS we have some awesome perks for Lady Fest VIPs!

Mission:

Women's Showcase seeks to draw the public’s eye to the important work of female artists by facilitating a cross-disciplinary festival that features the women leaders of our arts community.

Challenges:

Though female dancers and female choreographers may out number male dancers/choreographers, we have found from personal experience elsewhere and  in Charlotte, that men receive the majority of the awards, grants, support, opportunities, leadership roles and recognition.

While we do not aim to discredit or exclude the accomplishments of our male partners, we desire to draw attention to the voices of the women in our field and give them the opportunity to share their own stories.

    Other Ways You Can Help:

    Come see the show! We would appreciate your support and would love to see you there. If you want to see more festivals like this happen, share this page with your friends!

story:
*Performances will be held on the final 2 weekends of January, 2016 at The Stone Church (210 Main St.) in Brattleboro, VT

Bringing to light and life a dark & fascinating tale

We are Shakespeare Stage, a theater company based in Southern Vermont and the upper Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts. We're the cast & creative team for a new, innovative, and action-packed immersive production of William Shakespeare's Macbeth, and we need your help!

The Stone Church, a historic location in downtown Brattleboro, Vermont, is slowly becoming the landscape of our dark & haunting vision for Scotland. A former Unitarian Church, the Church is the perfect venue to brew up something wicked, wild, and exhilarating. 

But in order for us to realize our vision of installing a fully realized and magically chilling Dunsinane within these old stone walls, we are asking for your assistance!

-We need to install some basic lighting fixtures.

-We need to fulfill our goal of providing a set and costume that evoke a uniquely stylized vision for an apocalyptic medieval fantasy.

-We need battle-safe weapons and props in order to bring to life the bloody conflicts that define this tale of a dark King of Scotland.

-And of course, we need to pay rent to the good people who run The Stone Church.

About the production:

Shakespeare Stage's Tragedy of Macbeth is:

Directed by Julian Findlay

Produced & Designed by Coralie & Cameron Cobane

Original music by Travis Wilmot

Executive Producer Catherine Stewart

Starring:

as Macbeth – Julian Findlay

as Lady Macbeth – Michelle Page

as Banquo – Mike Sola

as Macduff – Jesse Cross-Nickerson

as the Weird Sisters – Dawn Berné-Allen, Kate Jurdi, and Victoria Maille de Aguilera

as Duncan – Michael J. Bird

as Malcolm – Tom Duke 

as Ross – Kerstin Becker

as Lennox – Laura Rainbow Stakiwicz

as Angus – Max Peyton

in a number of roles – Alec Dandelions 

as Donalbain – Sean Auth

as the porter –  Cameron Cobane

as Seyton – Ian Bigelow

as Fléance – Guin Roy

Our Goal

In order to bring to our region the quality evocation of Macbeth it deserves, we seek to raise $2,200. This goes to into the cost of set, costumes, props, makeup, lighting, sound, and fight equipment. This project is a serious undertaking that will pay off with your help! 

If you are unable to donate money, here are some other helpful things you can do for our production:

  • Spread the word about our campaign and our production! 

  • Email info.shakespearestage@gmail.com to join our mailing list to be updated about opportunities to help hands-on, as well as for other updates about tickets and more.

We thank you kindly for your support.

You can donate here online, or you can email info.shakespearestage@gmail.com for other ways to help fund our project.

*Performances will be held on the final 2 weekends of January, 2016 at The Stone Church (210 Main St.) in Brattleboro, VTBringing to light and life a dark & fascinating taleWe are Shakespeare Stage, a theater company based in Southern Vermont and the upper Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts. We're the cast & creative team for a new, innovative, and action-packed immersive production of William Shakespeare's Macbeth, and we need your help!The Stone Church, a historic location in downtown Brattleboro, Vermont, is slowly becoming the landscape of our dark & haunting vision for Scotland. A former Unitarian Church, the Church is the perfect venue to brew up something wicked, wild, and exhilarating. But in order for us to realize our vision of installing a fully realized and magically chilling Dunsinane within these old stone walls, we are asking for your assistance!-We need to install some basic lighting fixtures.-We need to fulfill our goal of providing a set and costume that evoke a uniquely stylized vision for an apocalyptic medieval fantasy.-We need battle-safe weapons and props in order to bring to life the bloody conflicts that define this tale of a dark King of Scotland.-And of course, we need to pay rent to the good people who run The Stone Church.About the production:Shakespeare Stage's Tragedy of Macbeth is:Directed by Julian FindlayProduced & Designed by Coralie & Cameron CobaneOriginal music by Travis WilmotExecutive Producer Catherine StewartStarring:as Macbeth – Julian Findlayas Lady Macbeth – Michelle Pageas Banquo – Mike Solaas Macduff – Jesse Cross-Nickersonas the Weird Sisters – Dawn Berné-Allen, Kate Jurdi, and Victoria Maille de Aguileraas Duncan – Michael J. Birdas Malcolm – Tom Duke as Ross – Kerstin Beckeras Lennox – Laura Rainbow Stakiwiczas Angus – Max Peytonin a number of roles – Alec Dandelions as Donalbain – Sean Authas the porter –  Cameron Cobaneas Seyton – Ian Bigelowas Fléance – Guin RoyOur GoalIn order to bring to our region the quality evocation of Macbeth it deserves, we seek to raise $2,200. This goes to into the cost of set, costumes, props, makeup, lighting, sound, and fight equipment. This project is a serious undertaking that will pay off with your help! If you are unable to donate money, here are some other helpful things you can do for our production:
Spread the word about our campaign and our production! 
Email info.shakespearestage@gmail.com to join our mailing list to be updated about opportunities to help hands-on, as well as for other updates about tickets and more.
We thank you kindly for your support.You can donate here online, or you can email info.shakespearestage@gmail.com for other ways to help fund our project.

story:
Our Story

The Mop & Bucket Improv Company has been bringing improvisational theatre to the Capital Region for over 20 years. We’re known here as the “The Mother Ship” of improv; we’ve taught and developed hundreds of performers, some of whom are now running other great new improv troupes of their own.

Now our big dream is happening: We’re buying an empty firehouse and turning it into our own theatre in Schenectady, NY. It’s a huge project for us, and we’re putting a lot of our own dough on the line to make it happen. We’ve got conventional funding, plus a grant from Schenectady’s Metroplex Development Authority, and we are 99% fully funded.


The new theater is awesome because it will provide:

  • New jobs and growth for downtown Schenectady
  • Expansion of Mopco programs for adults and youth
  • A new performance venue for aspiring improvisers, young actors, and even filmmakers!
  • Continued development of our own ensemble
  • 2nd floor offices for Koppett, our corporate training wing.

What We Need & What You Get

Here’s the thing: Renovation projects tend to go over budget, and this one is no different. We discovered a couple of sections of the first floor which need to be replaced. It’s a $12,000 fix we didn’t expect.  And floors, well, they’re nice to have, ‘cause they’re a place to put your feet. Would you help us cover the cost?

Perks are listed along the side.

How will Mopco benefit Schenectady?

How will Mopco benefit Schenectady?

Employment: This year, we hired a second full-time employee. When we purchase 10 N. Jay Street, we will hire a third. Additionally, we will hire several part-time employees, and increase our hiring of contract employees. Providing employment is one way we are helping the local economy flourish.

Enhancing walkability: 10 N. Jay Street will serve as a critical enhancement to the burgeoning lower Union Street/Little Italy area. It will also provide an additional destination for patrons to eateries along Jay, State, and Union Streets. An inviting and walkable arts and entertainment area in downtown Schenectady, a long-held goal of city planners, is happening! 

Blight transformation: 10 N. Jay Street is a historically important building. Mopco plans to renovate it from its current state of blight into an attractive asset. 10 N. Jay is currently on the tax rolls as a storage facility, at a fraction of its actual value. The building is at a critical point: it must be renovated soon. Saving it will be untenable if it is left to further decline. Mopco is dedicated to bringing the building back to its original status as a focal point for N. Jay Street.

Community enrichment: We will use 10 N. Jay Street. for a mixture of purposes:

  • Office
  • Entertainment space
  • Classes, activities for adults and youth

All of which will enliven the immediate neighborhood during the day and night, and bring a diverse mix of people to downtown.

Short-term construction employment: This project will supply short-term employment to Schenectady construction contractors. The development team includes AKW, Re4orm, Arket Electric, Pinnacle Roofing, D&E Technologies, with more to come…

With your help, we can continue our investment in Schenectady. We plan to be a valuable part of the burgeoning downtown scene, taking a blighted building in a critical area and returning it to its highest and best use.

Risks & Challenges

The risk...? Everything is a risk -- it's unscripted. Welcome to improv. But why spend your life hiding behind the risks and challenges, when you can grab the person's hand next to you and jump off that cliff together?  


Other Ways You Can Help

We absolutely understand that sometimes, making a donation just isn't feasible. We want you to know that is more than okay!  We'd love for you to just send us some positive juju, warm thoughts, fuzzy vibes, and share our Indiegogo page! AND, once we’re up and running, we’ll be happy to barter ticket-taking and similar duties for free seats at the shows, so be in touch!

story:
Short Summary

This is our second year producing the only free outdoor Shakespeare event in the Atlanta area. After last year's successful run of A Midsummer Night's Dream, we have built an enthusiastic audience ready for this year's production of Romeo and Juliet. Thanks to our partnership with the Newnan Cultural Arts Commission and support from generous sponsors we have been able to cover half of our budget, but we need your help to reach the rest of our funding goal. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds to pay stipends to our actors and to cover the cost of sets, props, costumes, sound and lighting equipment, and the printing of our posters and programs. Most importantly, your support will help make this a FREE EVENT for the public! We believe that everyone should have access to high-quality theatre, and your contribution will help bring professional theatre to the West Georgia region.

Newnan Shakes is a 501(c)(3) Non-Profit, and your contribution will be tax deductible. 

Meet The Creative Team

Carrie Smith Lewis (Director/Adapter)-Carrie Smith Lewis is a professional actor, director, and teacher from Kingsport, Tennessee. Her directing credits include Morning After Grace, The Road to Appomattox, True West, Macbeth, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Julius Caesar, and Cinderella. She is currently an associate member of the Resident Acting Company at the Barter Theatre in Abingdon, Virginia, where she frequently serves as text coach for the company’s Shakespeare productions. She has worked regionally with the Texas Shakespeare Festival, Georgia Shakespeare, North Carolina Stage Company, and Immediate Theatre Project. She has also served on the faculties of East Tennessee State University and Emory & Henry University, where she recently directed an all-female production of Macbeth. 

James Hendley (Artistic Director/Actor)-James is the co-founder and artistic director of Newnan Shakespeare in the Park. He is very excited to bring Shakespeare to Greenville Street Park for a second year in a row! Originally from Newnan, James earned his BFA in Musical Theatre from Western Carolina University in 2015. Some of his favorite past roles include Romeo in Romeo and Juliet (North Carolina Stage Company), Tom Sawyer in Huck and Tom and the Mighty Mississippi (Virginia Repertory Theatre), and Haemon in Antigone (Barter Players).

Madeline Sain (Managing Director/Actor)-Madeline is the Managing Director of Newnan Shakespeare in the Park. She received her B.A. in Performance from LaGrange College before studying at the Stella Adler Conservatory in New York. She recently finished assistant directing Charlie and the Chocolate Factory for Brooks Elementary and could have been seen in the first production of Flies at Well at the Wadsworth Auditorium. Some her favorite past credits include Arsinoe from Misanthrope, Haley from Bad Dates, and Stage Manager in The Actor's Nightmare.

Shaan Sharma (Set Designer/Actor)- Shaan graduated in 2015 from The College of William & Mary with a double major in Physics and Theatre. This year he will also be seen as Guildenstern in Hamlet and the Duke of Venice in Othello with the Nebraska Shakespeare Festival, as well as going on the Barter Player Encore tour with their production of Frosty. Other recent roles include Pip in Great Expectations (Barter Theatre), Johnse in Sally McCoy (Barter Theatre), Silvio in Servant of Two Masters (Colonial Williamsburg) and Demetrius in A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Virginia Shakespeare Festival).

Angie Fisher (Actor)- Angie Fisher is an actor and singer/songwriter from Southern Illinois. Over the past few years she has been traveling all over the United States on two separate tours with The Barter Players, as the Dyanne u/s on the National Tour of “Million Dollar Quartet”, and all up and down the state of Illinois doing “Twelfth Night” with Stone Soup Shakespeare. She is so happy to reunited with some pals she’s been on tour with in the past to do “Romeo and Juliet” this summer. If you want to hear some of her original tunes, check out her collab album with her dear friend Amy Myers, titled “Prairie State” on Spotify!

Morgan Haney (Actor)- Morgan Haney is happy to be working with Newnan Shakes for the first time! She has spent the last year in Dallas, TX, and her recent projects there include A Midsummer Night's Dream (Puck), Junie B in Jingle Bells, Batman Smells (Junie B. Jones), The Producers, and The Wizard of Oz. Before her time in Texas, she worked with Barter Theatre on The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe (Lucy), Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (Galiena), and Billy, Goat, Gruff.

Marissa Marcus (Actor)- As of May this year, Marissa is an Emory & Henry College graduate with a BFA in Acting and BA in Psychology. Some favorite undergraduate roles include Pam (The Violet Sisters), Osip (The Government Inspector), Waitress/Kit/Shona (Top Girls), and the titular role in Macbeth which was also directed by Carrie Smith Lewis. She has also had the great privilege of serving as a Barter Player in the Summer of 2018.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's cool! There are lots of ways you can help:

  • Spread the word. Share our campaign and our mission with friends, family, and people you haven't spoken to since high school via social media.

  • Check out and share our website via social media: newnanshakes.com

  • Interested in volunteering? Send us an email at newnanshakes@gmail.com 

  • Finally, if you are in Newnan August 9 and 10, pack a picnic and come see us!

story:
What Are We Up To?

We are extremely proud to be producing and starring in the West Coast Premier of the Pulitzer Prize nominated play, THE GOD GAME, by Suzanne Bradbeer.  Giovanna Sardelli is our award winning director who has graced such stages as the Mark Taper Forum, The Geffen Playhouse, etc.  We are delighted to be working with such powerhouse women!

At its heart, THE GOD GAME is a nuanced, yet high stakes drama about a couple and their best friend confronting deep, personal divisions within the context of faith and politics…(can you relate?)...It's also very funny. 

Tom, the Junior Republican Senator from Vermont, and his “steadfastly-faith’d” wife Lisa are celebrating their 20th wedding anniversary when they are surprised by their estranged, yet long-time friend Matt, who arrives ‘out of the blue’ with some news that is about to shake their world to its very core.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $65,000.  We will be opening in the Spring of 2020 and in order to do so we are inviting you to join our campaign!  Your generous donations will go toward every aspect of the project: the theatre, contracts, set, designers, marketing, rights, director, and the list goes on.

* And the best part is, with your help, we choose to pay it forward.  All our profits will go toward benefitting humanity & our environment, specifically through ACLU.org & NRDC.org *

Come be an Honorary Rascal.  Below we have created some extra special incentives to get you even more excited about donating!

 

Who Are We?

As actors who have worked many years in this business and collectively we agreed something was missing...the "Play!" The recurring message was to Play! 

We decided to create our OWN unique piece of art; work that sends a personal message, work that bring us back to the basics. Of Truth, Of PLAY!

3 Little Rascals Productions' main mission is to provoke and inspire change through the arts. As an ever-evolving creative collective, our hope is to produce work that not only challenges our audiences but ignites deep thought, mindful growth, and compassionate conversation long after you leave the theatre. If we are truly listening, we are learning. Knowledge is freedom. Freedom is Play.

 

The Impact 

At this point in history we must remember how vital ART is!  We cordially invite you to take part in our all too important game.  The Future Is NOW!  Come play...

Our production costs will be close to $75,000 so every dollar counts! The contributions from this campaign will go toward the following items, just to name a few:

Theatre: $18,000 - $25,000

Set Design & Build: $10,000

Equity Wage Hold Minimum: $9,000

Creative Team & Rights: $15,000-$20,000

Production Staff: $3,000

Equipment Rental: $2,000

Marketing: $5,000

Non-For-Profit Legal Fees: $2,000

 

Corporate Donations

If you are a business or corporation, we are offering ad space in our program in exchange for your generous donation.  If you or anyone you know might be interested, please email 3littlerascalsproductions@gmail.com to inquire.  We look forward to hearing from you!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every donation and 'Shout Out' help!  Even if you can't give us $10K, we still love you and we STILL NEED YOU! We will HAPPILY deem you an official TGG ADVOCATE! What does this mean?  As a special member of our TGG Advocates’ team, we kindly ask that you SHARE this email with all your friends, POST on all your social media platforms, & DIRECT any & all traffic to our Indiegogo page! THANK YOU SO MUCH for still wanting to be a part of our cause!  Here’s some verbiage to get you started:  

“Hey Friends & Family, my friends are producing and starring in the West Coast Premier of the Pulitzer Prize nominated play called THE GOD GAME in the Spring of 2020! They are working with formidable director Giovanna Sardelli (Mark Taper, Geffen Playhouse, etc) & with esteemed Pulitzer Prize nominated playwright Suzanne Bradbeer (The God Game, Confederates, etc).  This is an IMPORTANT show and definitely NOT to be missed! In order to make all of this happen they need our help!  Here is the link to their Indiegogo campaign - 

https://igg.me/at/3littlerascalsproductions/x/1...   

Remember, every little bit helps & they are offering some EXCITING perks in exchange for our support.  THANK YOU SO MUCH!"

story:
Dear Ms. Kitt

 

After learning of her mother's death, a young woman returns home to discover she's inherited more than she expected. Dear Ms. Kitt is Chantel's first one-act play and she is working with a team in New York to bring this personal story to life.

Of course we are Canadians, and in addition to the challenges that come with producing indie theatre we face the obstacle of our dollar not being at par, or near the US dollar. Therefore every dollar contributed to our campaign is 135% more appreciated. 

In earnest, this is a great opportunity to broadcast a black, female, Canadian's work to a new audience. Our goal is to share this play as much as possible, and use this chance as a stepping stone. New York, New York.

 

Your Contribution

We will be using the funding for:

  •  Rehearsal Space ($20USD/hr)
  • Set, Props and Costumes 
  • Compensating the Artists
  • Filling Seats at the Performances

 

Hard-Bitten Productions

Be sure to check out our website, and social media for more info on the production!

Think. Laugh. Feel Harder.
story_txt:
Dear Ms. Kitt
 
After learning of her mother's death, a young woman returns home to discover she's inherited more than she expected. Dear Ms. Kitt is Chantel's first one-act play and she is working with a team in New York to bring this personal story to life.
Of course we are Canadians, and in addition to the challenges that come with producing indie theatre we face the obstacle of our dollar not being at par, or near the US dollar. Therefore every dollar contributed to our campaign is 135% more appreciated. 
In earnest, this is a great opportunity to broadcast a black, female, Canadian's work to a new audience. Our goal is to share this play as much as possible, and use this chance as a stepping stone. New York, New York.

 
Your Contribution
We will be using the funding for:

 Rehearsal Space ($20USD/hr)
Set, Props and Costumes 
Compensating the Artists
Filling Seats at the Performances


 
Hard-Bitten Productions
Be sure to check out our website, and social media for more info on the production!

Think. Laugh. Feel Harder.

story:
What is Burnt Toast?

Burnt Toast is the debut play written by Guy Hodgkinson.

There are six characters:

Quick Pol: a young woman, Saxilby local, faster than some people, a daughter

Average Alfred: a young man, Saxilby local, respectably in the middle, a boyfriend

Mrs. Shelly Distant: a woman, a newcomer, a mother

Wannabe Penelope: a young woman, Saxilby local, an ambitious ‘voyeur’ with foreign fancies 

Speaks Spanish Hernandez: A God of sorts, an immigrant, a Landlord, a brother

Sort of Spanish Miguel: Also a God of sorts, an immigrant, a Landlord, a brother

Play Synopsis:

Burnt Toast is the hilarious and touching story of six people in Saxilby, England, what they’ll do for love, in whatever form it comes. Burnt Toast marks a celebration, a fifteen year anniversary. Unknowns can be scary, our potential can be scary, it is sometimes better to settle for what we have, close the doors and let the day roll on, but there are people who can change our lives. Burnt Toast is an exploration into the unknown, and what we’ll do for love. 

Saxilby. Fifteen years later. Burnt toast. Boring sex. Viennetta. Knife roulette. We will do anything for the people that we love, even if it means eating burnt toast.

Why do we think this play is important now?

The UK, and the world is in a pretty strange situation right now, and people can feel trapped and dissatisfied in all walks of life, anywhere. This has led to a strange presence of many ‘known-unknowns’ and many ‘unknown-unknowns’ it can feel paralysing, but our resilience is a beautiful thing. Burnt Toast takes a trip to a small town in England, looking at where isolation can lead to, resulting in an absurd, often charming place. As a company we are fascinated by the power that ‘unknown-unknowns’ are having over the world at the moment, and in a warm look at that Burnt Toast is an emotional response to this feeling.

The play looks to explore complexities of relationships; be it simple interactions within a neighbourhood, unrequited familial love, vanilla sex kind of relationship love, or the sort that results in Burnt Toast. 

This play celebrates people, places and the vulnerabilities we pick up along the way.

Where and when can I come and see it?

London

Theatre 503 July 22nd & 23rd 7pm 

"Arguably the most important Theatre in Britain today" The Gaurdian

A link to tickets will be available soon.

Edinburgh

https://www.edfringe.com

Assembly Front Room 17:05, 3rd-26th August

https://www.assemblyfestival.com/whats-on/burnt-toast

Where is your funding going?

We have been given the green light on this play, and it’s a joy. But all this comes with a need to pull together funding to make the project the best it possibly can be. :PLACE Productions is a collective that makes a promise to the people that it works with, to pay them EQUITY rates for their work, which we believe to be an important step in making professional quality work. 

Here is a breakdown of the rates of pay that we are going to be paying our creatives and where your support will be going:

Production Costs

Actors & Director: for one week of work, an agreement between artists and Producer of 40+ hours work: £180-£250pw/pp

Cast and Crew for one weeks work(based on 7 people in cast and crew) = £1,260-£1,750

*Expenses: £15 pd/pp=£105pw/pp=£420pm/pp TOTAL=£2,940*

Edinburgh Fringe Festival Total payment agreed with artists and Producer= £5,040-£7,000

Accommodation in Edinburgh for August: £3,000

Venue: £2,592

TOTAL (Including expenses)=£13,572-£15,530

TOTAL (excluding expenses)=10,632-£12,592

*The expenses payment is to be discussed with cast and crew as is a large expense when payment is already being made, may be cut*

Just as a note on this, the ambition is to also rehearse this show for two-three weeks prior to heading up to Edinburgh, making sure that we are growing on the work that we will be doing at Soho Theatre, tightening up the creative journey of the play. 

The ambition is for these two weeks to be paid, which will add:

Two weeks rehearsal process=£2,520-£3,500

If I pay a certain amount of money where might that go?

So there are specifics. Not for everything but here is a list of where  some money would go.

£60-Theatre 503 Preview deposit

£70-Theatre 503 price/show

£140-Sponsorship of London Previews

£150-Food shop for Cast & Crew in Edinburgh

£180-£250-Sponsorship of an Actor for an entire week! AMAZING

£25-10 High Quality Show Posters. REALLY VITAL

£15-Expenses for an Cast/Crew for entire day! Legends

£40-4 hours work with a brilliant lighting technician name Al!

£200-A full days work with Ira Mandela Siobhan, one of the Uk’s best physical directors and actor’s at the moment. 

£1,260-£1,750-Full Sponsorship of the Cast & Crew for an entire week. Not all Heroes wear Capes. What a week it will be!!!!!!

THANK YOU SO MUCH IT MEANS THE WORLD

We have budgeted for a 30% capacity theatre throughout our run with Assembly, and we have high hopes that we will get more than 30% each night.

We are not expecting to raise £15,000 on IndieGoGo, but we wouldn't mind if we did! We've got high hopes for Burnt Toast are so thank fully to anyone who supports us! The ball is very much already rolling, train already steaming, with the support of Soho Theatre, Theatre 503 and Assembly we have got the best partners we could have wished for, we would love you to become part of that team!!!! It means the absolute world, so thank you!

Big Love & Burnt Toast

story:
Summary

The cost of bringing a show to the Fringe is a huge challenge for most theatre companies but for those of us who come from working class and/or BAME backgrounds, that mountain can be even steeper to climb. However, we truly believe in the importance of this show, the relevance and poignancy of the script and the talent of our director and performers. Showcasing this kind of work is not only crucial to creating a more diverse and representative Fringe Festival but also to ensuring that the UK is adequately reflected across the theatre industry as a whole.

story:
Summary

We are Pinecone Penguin Theatrical returning for a second show at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe after our successful production of the original musical adaptation of King Kong.

Heartwood as a show tells the story of Eleanor; a little girl dealing with a sickness, and the inner turmoil she faces as a result of feeling thoroughly “not normal”. Throughout our lives, we all encounter challenges that stir up a complex plethora of emotions. Eleanor’s trials and tribulations will resonate with all audiences, and help younger generations cope with the darker aspects of growing up and facing our own mortality.

All contributions will greatly improve the quality of our production. We have a team of extremely talented actors, makers and designers and to make our dreams a reality we will need the help of generous contributors. Any amount of help will take us one step closer to making the artistic impact we long to accomplish.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for £750 to fund the more artistic aspects of the production. The money will fund our costumes, our puppets, our set and our props. As our funds increase we will be able to show you exactly what your generous contributions have achieved.

As incentives, we have a collection of limited-edition merchandise only available through contributing to our Indiegogo plea. This includes: Promotional t-shirts, originally designed badges, signed scripts, signed posters, hand-crafted keyrings and more.
For any donation of £50 and over we will deliver the ‘Heartwood Collection’ which is a hamper of special treats and merchandise.

All funds, even if we fall short, will go straight onto the artistic team’s budget and any funds we raise on top of our goal will get us greater and greater looking creations, and maybe help us achieve some dreams we thought to be pipe-dreams.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donations you can make would be greatly appreciated, but we understand that some people are not in the position to help monetarily. Any help that can be given would be fantastic. Be it sharing our Indiegogo page, or liking us on Facebook, or following us on Twitter. Publicity is a great and generous use of your time, and we thank you heartily!

story:
My name is Lauren Beirne, I am the founder and Artistic Director of Lauren Beirne Dance Works (LBDW), an emerging, professional, non-profit, Brooklyn-based dance company. Thank you for checking out our Indiegogo campaign! 

LBDW has established itself on the festival circuit over the past two seasons. We have gained a significant amount of momentum from this and are ready to move forward by self-producing an evening-length performance. 

We have begun rehearsals on this new piece that touches on themes of social disillusionment and mob mentality, exploring innovative, wildly physical movement with new emotional depth. We are excited about the progress so far, and to continue on our upward trajectory, we are seeking to raise funds to support the remainder of the process. We need your help!

The $9,000 we are need to raise will go toward paying production costs, including:

  • Studio space rentals
  • Musical commissions
  • Costumes
  • Theatre rental
  • Stage managers
  • Lighting designers
  • Promotional/marketing materials
  • Programing and outreach
  • And most importantly, paying our incredibly talented dancers who put their blood, sweat, tears, and time into what we believe is an important artistic message

​Now more than ever, supporting the arts is vital to companies like ours. We want to create a space where people can come together and witness our created story in the hopes of inspiring impactful conversations. Knowing there are people out there like you who advocate the importance of art keeps us inspired and committed to producing new work. We could not be more thankful for every bit of help you give us on our journey!

 

Here are some rad PERKS for all of you awesome patrons!

$5-$25

Online thank you + name mention on website/ FB page

$26-$50

(the above) plus online personalized company thank you photo

$51-$99

Online thank you + name mention on website/ FB page plus personalized company VIDEO thank you

$100-$250

(the above) plus two free tickets to a LBDW show

$251-$499

(the above) plus a meet + greet with the company after a performance, including a framed company photo and a giant hug!

$500-999

(the above) plus private attendance for two to an open rehearsal/LBDW experience

$1000+

(the above) plus two free passes to our Summer Workshop OR private yoga lesson taught by LBDW company member

 

Without reaching this goal, LBDW may be able to continue rehearsals on a smaller scale but our dream of self-producing a full performance for our audiences is unattainable. No amount is too small, every dollar counts! You can also help us by sharing our campaign, enabling us to reach as many people as possible. We would not be where we are today without the support we've received up to this point and continue to be grateful to those who pledge their contributions to LBDW!

 

Thank you!

story:
Who started The Spark? And Why?

Two determined ladies came together and asked... why can't we find space to perform our work?

And thus The Spark was born. 

Those two ladies are Dillon Kenyon and Marla Schulz. Both have a wealth of experience in theatre from establishing arts programs in public schools, choreographing and directing across the nation, and being part of the administrative teams at established schools and theatres. A community of families, teachers, and artists have gathered behind The Spark in their first year, bringing their wisdom, dedication, and passion to this highly needed space.

Boulder has been blessed by a financial boom, but unfortunately that has left artists behind as they struggle to find affordable space to create, rehearse, and perform. The Spark was created to help solve these issues in our community. We provide affordable space, education, and resources to all interested in the performing arts. Help us become a space the community can rely on!

What we've done so far:

​We've come a long way since moving into an empty warehouse this past April. Not only have we successfully run several classes and workshops, but we transformed an empty space into a usable creative haven. We have opened our first two shows: 42nd Street and Fame The Musical to sold out audiences and standing ovations. In addition to this, multiple artists are using our space for rehearsals and classes adding to the creative life of Boulder. 

BEFORE

AFTER

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $20,000 to help us with:

  • Lighting equipment (we have the basics, but spend so much on rentals)
  • Completed bathrooms (we're so close!)
  • Dance studio flooring 
  • Dressing Rooms
  • Sound Equipment
  • Production budget (costumes, scenery, music, all of it!)

What you get:

  • Your name on our founder's plaque
  • Studio naming rights
  • Signed Show Poster
  • Cameo in a future show
  • Social media shout out
  • and so much more...

The Impact

The main performance space in Boulder fills up every year and then still has a waiting list. There are artists that have so much to share, but there's just no space to do it. In addition, we provide comprehensive training that connects different generations of artists, making sure that art is supported and cherished at all ages. In case you need a few more reasons to support:

  • The arts are an integral part of  successful community. By supporting theatre you are supporting the economy. It's tough to live in a place when there's no entertainment.
  • The performing arts help young adults find outlets to share frustrations, concerns, and stress in a safe and guided environment.
  • Live performance is not only a cultural tool, but an educational one.

Risks & Challenges

Starting a theatre is hard. No doubt about it. We rely on volunteers, donors, and continuous support from the community in order to thrive. Fortunately we've had an outpouring of love and help in these beginning stages. Our biggest challenge currently is construction. We've faced delays, and unexpected costs the whole way. There's a light at the end of the tunnel but the journey's not over yet.

A few things to ease your concerns:

  • Our board is filled with dedicated and experienced individuals in the theatre and business communities.
  • We have the support of the Boulder Arts Alliance, and performance community, eager to see us succeed. 
  • Creative minds find creative solutions. And we live by that every single day. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't got the dough? There are so many other ways to be part of the team:

  • Share this with anyone and everyone. Facebook, Instagram, twitter, email, Nextdoor. The more people know the more support we can get. 
  • Volunteer! We have so many opportunities for involvement. Want to usher, help build a set, organize some costumes, or hang up flyers? We've got a job for everyone. 
  • Know kids or young adults looking for theatrical training? Send them our way. We help keep things affordable with our educational programming. Not only that, but it keeps the performing arts thriving in our community.

story:
Off with her head!

Marie Antoinette was not who you think she was. She never said "let them eat cake." Under the direction of Michael Warner (If Beale St. Could Talk, House of Cards, Boardwalk Empire), Tough Kitty Productions brings you a story of revolutionary zeal, collateral damage, and one human's tragedy at the cost of a brave new world. A feminist retelling of the life and times of a villainized heroine:

  • Tough Kitty Productions is a guerrilla theatre organization committed to spotlighting the best unknown actors in the New York Theatre scene. Our bare-knuckles productions are the breeding grounds for the next generation of great theatre actors and focus on diverse casting and storytelling. 
  • This production of Marie Antoinette is a showcase and launching point not only for performing talent, but for designers, directors and craftspeople as well. 
  • With your contribution, you are becoming part of a DIY artistic revolution, a new dawn of theatre not beholden to the pursestrings of the wealthy or corporate interests. 

Our quality-over-quantity mentality and actor-driven storytelling makes this a production you won't want to miss. Are you ready to see the next generation of the American theatre?

What We Need & What You Get

We cannot achieve our goal without your support! 

  • To fully fund and ethically pay our artistic staff, designers, crew and cast, we need to raise around $10,000. 
  • Donors will have the opportunity to receive hats, shirts, totes, signed posters, and certain donors level will be able to attend a rehearsal, walk through the set and have a special talkback session with the cast and director. Get excited!
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, funds will go to paying for the rehearsal and performance spaces, purchasing design elements and paying for insurance and union fees for our performance.

Risks & Challenges

Making theatre on a professional level is an expensive proposition, and it would be easy to play it safe, but we don't want to do that. We want to shake our audience to the core and rattle their bones. With your generous help, our process will be all about taking artistic risks and pushing boundaries. This means it's never possible to know if the choices we make will pay off, but we can be bold enough to push in the right direction.

  • Kelsey Ann Wacker and Nathan Simpson are actors, writers and producers, and both graduates of The Theatre at DePaul University --one of the country's most prestigious acting schools-- who between them have almost 30 years of professional acting experience. Through years of hard work they've learned that the difficult route usually yields the best results.
  • To ensure the boldness and quality of our production we are surrounding ourselves with outstanding unknown talent. Personally and thoroughly vetted, top-notch young actors, designers and technicians have been hand-picked for our extensive network of professional colleagues.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Every single donation helps immensely, no matter how small.  And trust us, we know not all of us can contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • A like and a share goes a long, long way!
  • Word of mouth is still the biggest and best way to make sure seats are filled. Tell your friends and family about our cause!
story_txt:
Off with her head!
Marie Antoinette was not who you think she was. She never said "let them eat cake." Under the direction of Michael Warner (If Beale St. Could Talk, House of Cards, Boardwalk Empire), Tough Kitty Productions brings you a story of revolutionary zeal, collateral damage, and one human's tragedy at the cost of a brave new world. A feminist retelling of the life and times of a villainized heroine:

Tough Kitty Productions is a guerrilla theatre organization committed to spotlighting the best unknown actors in the New York Theatre scene. Our bare-knuckles productions are the breeding grounds for the next generation of great theatre actors and focus on diverse casting and storytelling. 
This production of Marie Antoinette is a showcase and launching point not only for performing talent, but for designers, directors and craftspeople as well. 
With your contribution, you are becoming part of a DIY artistic revolution, a new dawn of theatre not beholden to the pursestrings of the wealthy or corporate interests. 

Our quality-over-quantity mentality and actor-driven storytelling makes this a production you won't want to miss. Are you ready to see the next generation of the American theatre?

What We Need & What You Get
We cannot achieve our goal without your support! 

To fully fund and ethically pay our artistic staff, designers, crew and cast, we need to raise around $10,000. 
Donors will have the opportunity to receive hats, shirts, totes, signed posters, and certain donors level will be able to attend a rehearsal, walk through the set and have a special talkback session with the cast and director. Get excited!
If we do not reach our entire goal, funds will go to paying for the rehearsal and performance spaces, purchasing design elements and paying for insurance and union fees for our performance.


Risks & Challenges
Making theatre on a professional level is an expensive proposition, and it would be easy to play it safe, but we don't want to do that. We want to shake our audience to the core and rattle their bones. With your generous help, our process will be all about taking artistic risks and pushing boundaries. This means it's never possible to know if the choices we make will pay off, but we can be bold enough to push in the right direction.

Kelsey Ann Wacker and Nathan Simpson are actors, writers and producers, and both graduates of The Theatre at DePaul University --one of the country's most prestigious acting schools-- who between them have almost 30 years of professional acting experience. Through years of hard work they've learned that the difficult route usually yields the best results.

To ensure the boldness and quality of our production we are surrounding ourselves with outstanding unknown talent. Personally and thoroughly vetted, top-notch young actors, designers and technicians have been hand-picked for our extensive network of professional colleagues.  


Other Ways You Can Help
Every single donation helps immensely, no matter how small.  And trust us, we know not all of us can contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

A like and a share goes a long, long way!
Word of mouth is still the biggest and best way to make sure seats are filled. Tell your friends and family about our cause!

story:
Starting the Zombie Apocalypse

We are creating an intense, action packed street game this Halloween.

THE SITUATION: A rogue arms company has been building biological weapons in London. You are called in to investigate, but the situation spirals out of control and the streets are quickly infested with the walking dead. Your mission now is survival - dodge the infected in front of you, while outrunning those behind you. There are fellow survivors around the area who may have information that can help you find a safe place to escape. Expect the adrenaline to be high and friendships to be tested - are you sure that you can trust your friends in the apocalypse?

This event was formerly called 2.8 Hours Later and used to be one of the biggest street events in the world, with 70,000 people in 12 cities taking part over the course of 5 years. This relaunch is a fan takeover, and gives zombie enthusiasts the chance to bring back this iconic event.

The first event will run in central London for a minimum of 3 nights and 300-400 participants per night.

About the creator

I took part in 2.8 Hours Later several times as a survivor and zombie. When the business closed in 2015, I got in touch and managed to buy the rights to run the event. 

I'm incredibly excited about this event because I know how much fun it can be and I also have lots of new ideas that I want to put in to make the run even bigger and better than before. For example, I want to develop the story elements of the game, to make them more compelling and interactive. I also want to bring in new ways of using small spaces to trap players and create a heart - thumping challenge, drawing on my experience in the escape game industry. To reflect the changes I'll be making, I've renamed the event Undead Escapes.
I run a successful entertainment company in London called Agent November. The business has had over 3,000 customers and holds a Certificate of Excellence from  Trip Advisor, so I know what it takes to put on a great event.

I'm hoping to make Halloween 2016 a massive success so that I can bring the run back to other cities around the country. However I'm conscious that the previous strategy was flawed in that it expanded too quickly, so I'm absolutely focused on making sure every event is top quality.

Note: the previous directors and owners will not be involved in 2.8 Hours Later, and I was not involved in any of the decisions that led to the run being cancelled in the past. This is a new start and a whole new approach.
Nathan

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to set up a run incorporating several different venues. So we will need to pay for key things like venue hire and insurance.

We also have a shopping list of things that will make the night amazing: Actors, props, lighting, make up (lots and lots of fake blood!).

The core perk of funding us £45 or more is getting to take part in the event! You can also get a cheaper group ticket if you have some friends you want to be in a group with, plus there are some fantastic VIP tickets available if you want to be the big shot in the zombie apocalypse. 

Bear in mind that if you pledge and then volunteer to be a zombie on a different night, you will be refunded the cost of your ticket! (note that this is subject to being selected as a zombie and passing zombie school. The refund value will be £45 for individual tickets or £40 for one person from a group ticket, or lower if the original ticket was discounted).

It's going to be a unique and unforgettable experience, make sure you don't miss out!

We also have stretch goals for if we exceed our target, extra things that we want to add to the experience (like a more advanced system for showing that you have been caught by a zombie and even a room that you have to escape from while an infected scientist breaks down the door!). So  please share and retweet the campaign, the more people who get on board, the more fun it will be for everyone.

If we don't reach our entire goal, we aim to run a scaled down version of the event for fewer people, but which keeps the same level of excitement and adrenaline.

This event is strictly for over 18s only.

Other Ways You Can Help

This campaign depends on as many people as possible hearing about it.

Please share and retweet our campaign:

www.undeadescapes.co.uk

Best of all, if you know of 3 or 4 people who would be really into this, can you please send them a direct message or an email with the link? It's the personal touch that really makes these things special.

Don't forget, a ticket to the apocalypse makes a great birthday or early Christmas gift!

Nathan G.

story:
Cats? Onstage?

Cats Onstage is the theatrical extension of our filmmaking collective, The Cats About Town. Though new to the Capital Fringe Fest as an entity, Cats all hold extensive experience in the realm of theatre ("Fringe theatre" and otherwise,) and collectively, represent backgrounds in fields ranging from painting and composing, to writing and photography. 

  • The Cats are tired of hearing the same, disappointing, stories (and a lack of subsequent fruitful dialogue) every time we turn to the news, or even just Facebook. SpookyMsgPlsFWD! is our original one-act response to the frustrations we (and surely many others) have felt towards recent historical developments. 
  • We believe in the awe-inspiring powers of theatre; in its ability to distill, dissect, and help digest complex (and often "unsavory") socio-political issues. We're also tired of being tired of the news - this production, presented as part of the 2016 Capital Fringe Festival, is our way of initiating tangible change. 

 What We Need & What You Get

Very fortunately (thank you Fringe!) we have been provided with a lovely performance space in The National Museum of Women in the Arts, as well as a practical ticketing system. We are also making every effort to reduce expenditures by making use of public spaces for rehearsals, and by committing to the low-tech/no-tech nature of the Fringe Festival. That said, projects such as these still present us with a number of other costs, and help from lovely people such as yourself is vital! 

Let's break it down:

  • Fringe participation fees
  • Insurance fees
  • 7 actors - because we believe in making it ever-so-slightly more possible for our artists to afford making art!
  • Team of creators ranging from costume, sound, and web designers, to our fight choreographer
  • A minimal, and easily transportable/storable set that will allow our stage to exist as 6 different settings
  • Costuming, with which to help our 7 actors shapeshift between the 25 distinct characters they will play throughout the show
  • Props (you can't hunt down a unicorn without the proper tools...)
All of these costs add up quickly, but we strongly believe that between our own investment of funds, ticket-sales (of which we keep approx. 50%,) and your help, we can certainly make this happen - As tokens of appreciation, we've conjured up some sweet (and completely original!) goodies for those so righteous as to help us on our quest! Check out the "Perks" tab!

 The Impact

Let's get a little more in-depth.

Specifically:

  • SpookyMsgPlsFWD! grapples with intricate matters as broad as human rights, (gun) violence, and internet privacy, to ones as specific as the 2016 US election season. But at its core, SpookyMsg really aims to combat the dangerous culture of complacency/political apathy increasingly evident in American youth.  
But it's about more than the show itself. Cats Onstage believe in change at the local level. We are supporting our local arts community.
  • This is a 100% brand-new play - it's obvious to say we support the creation and development of new/original plays and other works of art. 
  • In compensating all our artists, we are directly and tangibly supporting our arts community. 
  • On a larger scale, since 2006 the Capital Fringe Festival has: provided 866 paid positions (469 to DC residents,) and "premiered over 600 new works of contemporary performance"
The Cats also want to take this opportunity as a chance to actively fight back against the greater issue of lack of representation and diversity prevalent in the arts. While we are most definitely proud to be featured as one of two "women-centric" productions being performed at the National Museum of Women in the Arts during the Festival, we can't help but consider the inherent problems found in that statement. This is only compounded by the fact that though our play features a "strong female lead," our play was not written by a woman, and may not necessarily, or appropriately, represent the female experience.

As such, our production committed to an openly gender/race-blind casting process (something which is still unfortunately not a given) and a production team comprised nearly entirely of women (all but one, in fact!)

These things need to be seen as normal.

If we're able to use the (literal and figurative) platform we've been given by Capital Fringe to change a mind, spark a dialogue, and/or even just transmute a modicum of hate in the world, into love, we will have succeeded. 

 Risks & Challenges

From the stages of conception and writing, to the first day of rehearsal, to opening night, the production of a play is no easy task. Fortunately, Capital Fringe has provided us with an amazing performance-space, equipped with sound, lighting, and projection equipment - all things which could ultimately cost several thousand dollars. But as noted, there are many other parts of this production that we will have to cover. We will have ticket-sales and a carefully planned marketing strategy to assist us, but we cannot rely solely on ticket-sales. Acquiring the funds necessary to create our props/set/costumes, and compensate our artists, as well as offset the initial Fringe participation fees, will be one of our greater challenges. 

Aside from this are the inherent risks bound to the creation of any artwork. Our experienced artists are not only accustomed to these risks, but also share an absolute love for the craft. We have been, and will continue to be, hard at work to ensure this project comes to fruition.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that making a donation is oftentimes simply not within the realm of possibility, but that doesn't mean you can't lend a hand!

  • Help us make some noise by:
    • Liking/sharing our Facebook profile and the SpookyMsgPlsFWD! event page!
    • Sharing the link to this campaign
    • Telling all your friends, family, pets, and coworkers, about us

story:
I'm Patrick Mueller, the artistic director of Control Group Productions – a dance-based intermedia performance company based in Colorado.

We've been building the Front Range performance scene since 2009 with innovation-driven, entirely singular new works and a broad-platform community development vision. We're in a wonderful moment RIGHT NOW where this vision is beginning to translate into long-term, sustainable growth. We need your help to take this strong step forward. We hope you'll get behind this awesome moment in our organization's development.

Your donation will fuel an extraordinary season of company work, outreach programs in local high schools, and curation and support of other local companies. Every little bit counts, and meeting our goal (or exceeding it!) means the ability not only to capitalize on our planned season, but also to take on new opportunities as they arise and to continue our momentum into 2017-18 and beyond.

 

OUR 2016-17 SEASON

Aug. 18-27: WHOLENESS (dances made to be viewed in the dark, creation #2) in the Galleria at Denver Performing Arts Complex
Sept. 3-4: Home:2016 – a mini-festival of works from our Artist Services program
Sept. 12-Dec. 20: Dynamic World-Making program at Jefferson County Open School
Oct. 22-Nov. 12: ALONE WITH TODD (dances made to be viewed in the dark, creation #3) at Colorado Conservatory of Dance (Broomfield), Boulder Creative Collective, and Buntport Theater (Denver)
Nov. 18-20: Premiere of commissioned new work with Open Dance Project, Houston, TX
Jan. 2017: XX by Lauren Beale, Ondine Geary, Brooke McNamara, and Kate Speer (an Artist Services program co-presentation)
Jan-May 2017: Dynamic World-Making at another school in Jefferson County
Apr/May 2017: AGGREGATE IMMATERIALITY (dances made to be viewed in the dark, creation #4) in Denver, Boulder, & Broomfield
Aug. 2017: controlled encounters with mobile architecture – a site-specific work for transit centers in Denver, Boulder, & Broomfield

 

HOW WE'RE MAKING IT HAPPEN

We've been building toward this moment of growth for 2 years. We've laid in infrastructure and strategic partnerships, new capacities and funding sources, and a whole lot of potent vision for stunning art and powerful new programming. Over the last year we've:

  • entered SCFD's Tier III;
  • stepped up our grant writing and built relationships with grantors;
  • solidified resource-sharing relationships that magnify our reach and impact;
  • commenced a new works series – dances made to be viewed in the dark – with 7 major projects currently planned;
  • initiated a new Community Engagement program at high schools in Jefferson County;
  • acquired valuable new equipment for design and production;
  • professionalized our board and administrative operations.

Now we're ready to dive in. In the last 3 months we brought in $14K in foundation and civic grants, and another $5K from a dozen generous individuals who believe deeply in what we do and wanted to seed our fall fundraising effort.

This Indiegogo campaign will get us the rest of the way to a solid budget for this huge season.

Our campaign is reaching out to all of us who love the art, and who struggle to bring more of it into our world. It's a call to our friends and colleagues, to working artists and creative businesses, to our die-hard fans and to the folks who've been looking for extraordinary, innovation-driven aesthetic experiences in Colorado and finally figured out where to look.

We're not asking for angel donors or 4-digit philanthropists in this campaign (although, of course and by all means, please donate at that level if you're so moved!). This is a call for a whole community to get behind what we're doing, in $10s and $20s and $50 increments (maybe a couple Benjamins too!), so that we can serve that community deeply and fully.

We're asking our grassroots to dig down. We're asking for your pocket change, a couple drinks or a new shirt's worth of support. We're asking you to bring whatever you can to the table, to get behind us as we advance the Colorado arts scene with innovation and vision from a community of extraordinary artists.

We hope you'll support us.

YERMA… Passion for LORCA… Made in Venezuela…


Who are we? Where are we?

We are theater people (from Venezuela )...


QUIENES SOMOS? DONDE ESTAMOS?

SOMOS GENTE DE TEATRO (DE VENEZUELA)…


What do we want? 

All of us,  in this team, are joined toghether for a great reason. The love we feel towards our craft,  and Federico Garcia Lorca's dramaturgy.

Because of this powerful  impulse,  we want to stage YERMA, one of the most representative pieces of the dramaturgy of this distinguished playwright.

QUE QUEREMOS?

ESTAMOS UNIDOS POR UNA GRAN RAZÓN: EL AMOR QUE SENTIMOS POR NUESTRO OFICIO  Y POR LA OBRA DE FEDERICO GARCÍA LORCA. POR ESO QUEREMOS LLEVAR A ESCENA YERMA.


Why staging "Yerma" in Venezuela? Why in this  moment?

We know the greatness of this piece, not much to say about it. Whenever it goes on, again and again , we can confirm the historic empathy achieved with the spectator of all time and all geographies. Hence, it has been established as a classic.

Now, why producing Yerma here and now? When we all know the profound crisis that is facing our country and how hard it is for us to do theater, and much more, do classics. It seems a crazy thing but we believe that madmen are heroic drivers of the changing world and that bad moments are great opportunities to measure our strength, creativity and will.


PORQUE MONTAR A YERMA  EN VENEZUELA?  PORQUE EN ESTOS TIEMPOS TAN CRÍTICOS?

LOCURA EN MEDIO DE LA CRISIS?  CREEMOS QUE LOS LOCOS SON HEROICOS IMPULSADORES DE LOS CAMBIOS DEL MUNDO  Y QUE LAS CRISIS SON LAS  GRANDES OPORTUNIDADES PARA MEDIR NUESTRA FUERZA, CREATIVIDAD Y VOLUNTAD.


What message has "Yerma" to the public in venezuela?

Yerma , in her magnificent obsession to be fertile , is more relevant than ever in our country, because of the great metaphor for what happens to us, because Yerma , when chasing the powerful call of nature to feel full and done , reflects the deepest longing of the current Venezuela .

Our audience will thank witnessing this work, but above all, it will be very important for them to be reflected in it, in an eclectic assembly with references and symbolisms from our Latin American culture , discovering a metaphor between the story of this classic and the deep and overwhelming desire that we have in our country to be fruitful .


QUE TRASCENDENCIA TIENE EL MENSAJE DE YERMA PARA  EL ESPECTADOR VENEZOLANO?...

YERMA, EN SU“MAGNIFICA OBSESIÓN” POR SER FECUNDA, ESTÁ MÁS VIGENTE QUE NUNCA EN NUESTRO PAÍS… ES LA GRAN METÁFORA DE LO QUE NOS PASA…


What institution is backing us up?

We feature the powerful support of the RAJATABLA Foundation, who joined this project to participate as co-producers. The RAJATABLA Foundation, founded on February 28th, 1971 by the great Argentine master Carlos Gimenez, is a mandatory reference to the Venezuelan and Latin American theater.


QUE INSTITUCIÓN NOS RESPALDA?

CONTAMOS CON EL PODEROSO RESPALDO DE LA FUNDACION RAJATABLA. 


Our team… 

One of the most important theatrical producers in the country,  William Lopez (under his leadership the famous International Festival of Theater of Caracas, in the 80s and 90s were made ) is now the president of the RAJATABLA Foundation and participates in our project as Executive producer along with Paola Herrera, young woman who belongs to the new breed of Venezuelan producers . Artistic production is in charge of the brilliant showman Jan Thomas Moro.

About our cast , we are all professional colleagues in this craft, with great professional careers as Maria Brito , Veronica Cortez, Wilfredo Cisneros, Marielena González , Asdrubal Blanco, Alid Salazar, Marxlenin Cipriani and Africa Mendez . But above all, we are loonies in love with Lorca.

The direction is from the young and talented director Jose Jesus Gonzalez, expert also in the work of the poet of Granada , and who, in previous years, has mounted several of his pieces , including The Wedding.

Also, we propose a staging with a keen aesthetic criteria . Therefore, we have Armando Zullo in the set design , David Blanco in the lighting design and Iginia Rodriguez in the costume design.

The score will be original and it will be composed by the talented Alejandro Silva and it will also have emblematic pieces of the recognized Venezuelan musician Alex Rodriguez. The master Domingo Balducci is our vocal coach. All this will add a distinctive value of our work.

NUESTRO EQUIPO…

EN ESTE GRUPO, TODOS SOMOS ARTISTAS PROFESIONALES CON RESPETABLES CARRERAS PERO, LO MÁS IMPORTANTE, ES QUE SOMOS UNOS LOCOS APASIONADOS POR  LORCA.


When and where is the season going to be? 

Our Opening Night will be in RAJATABLA theater, next November, the 2nd, 2016. Later on,  in 2017, we want to be in other theaters of the city, and also do a national tour.


Why do we need your support? 

This project is a personal initiative and we don't count with public funding. Although we have the important support of RAJATABLA Foundation for staging production, we need the money that we will get from this crowdfunding campaign to, first of all, pay to all the staff involved in the project (cast, director, producers, assistants,  musicians, stage designers, craftsmen, wardrobe designer,  technicians,  transportation, etc).We will also use this resources to pay for the intervention of the scenery, wardrobe,  and promotion (graphic design,  press,  and community manager).


PORQUE NECESITAMOS TU APOYO?

AUNQUE CONTAMOS CON UN APOYO IMPORTANTE DE PARTE DE LA FUNDACION RAJATABLA , NECESITAMOS  DINERO PARA REMUNERAR EL TRABAJO DE TODO EL PERSONAL INVOLUCRADO EN EL PROYECTO Y PARA CUMPLIR CON LOS PAGOS  RELACIONADOS CON INTERVENCIÓN DE ESCENOGRAFÍA, VESTUARIO Y  PROMOCIÓN.


Our most sincere reason...

In these times, when we see ourselves tempted to do plays to evade, only to distract,  we put our bet to do committed, confronting  theater that collaborates on elevating our and the audience's consciousness level.

Oddly,  despite our economy,  theater plays have had a big rise of popularity amongst the entertainment options in Caracas. And we're sure that there is a big audience for this genre, and the people who go to RAJATABLA theater are part of this exquisite audience.

This initiative through this crowdfunding campaign is not only to fund, but an invitation that we are making all of you to accompany us in this adventure, in this dream that we want to make come true.

Any collaboration that we can get from you will be very valuable to us.

The power of giving: This is a law of life. What goes around comes around,  in many magical ways,  multiplied in effects.


NUESTRA MAS SINCERA RAZON.

EL PODER DE DAR: ESTO ES LEY DE VIDA… AQUELLO QUE DAS REGRESA A TI, DE MUCHAS Y MÁGICAS MANERAS, MULTIPLICADO EN SUS EFECTOS.


Infinite thanks...

GRACIAS INFINITAS...
story_txt:
YERMA… Passion
for LORCA… Made in Venezuela…
Who are we? Where are we?We are theater people (from Venezuela )...
QUIENES SOMOS? DONDE ESTAMOS?SOMOS GENTE DE TEATRO (DE VENEZUELA)…
What do we want? 
All of
us,  in this team, are joined toghether for a great reason. The
love we feel towards our craft,  and
Federico Garcia Lorca's dramaturgy.
Because of this powerful 
impulse,  we want to stage YERMA,
one of the most representative pieces of the dramaturgy of this distinguished
playwright.
QUE QUEREMOS?ESTAMOS UNIDOS POR UNA
GRAN RAZÓN: EL AMOR QUE SENTIMOS POR NUESTRO OFICIO  Y POR LA OBRA DE
FEDERICO GARCÍA LORCA. POR ESO QUEREMOS LLEVAR A ESCENA YERMA.Why staging "Yerma" in Venezuela? Why in this  moment?
We know the
greatness of this piece, not much to say about it. Whenever it goes on, again
and again , we can confirm the historic empathy achieved with the spectator of
all time and all geographies. Hence, it has been established as a classic.
Now, why
producing Yerma here and now? When we all know the profound crisis that is
facing our country and how hard it is for us to do theater, and much more, do
classics. It seems a crazy thing but we believe that madmen are heroic drivers
of the changing world and that bad moments are great opportunities to measure
our strength, creativity and will.
PORQUE MONTAR A YERMA
 EN VENEZUELA?  PORQUE EN ESTOS TIEMPOS TAN CRÍTICOS?
LOCURA EN MEDIO DE LA CRISIS?
 CREEMOS QUE LOS LOCOS SON HEROICOS IMPULSADORES DE LOS CAMBIOS DEL MUNDO
 Y QUE LAS CRISIS SON LAS  GRANDES OPORTUNIDADES PARA MEDIR NUESTRA
FUERZA, CREATIVIDAD Y VOLUNTAD.
What message has "Yerma" to the public in venezuela?
Yerma , in her magnificent obsession to be fertile , is more
relevant than ever in our
country, because of the great metaphor for what happens to us, because Yerma ,
when chasing the powerful call of nature to feel full and done , reflects the
deepest longing of the current Venezuela .
Our audience will thank witnessing this work,
but above all, it will be very important for them to be reflected in it, in an
eclectic assembly with references and symbolisms from our Latin American
culture , discovering a metaphor between the story of this classic and the deep
and overwhelming desire that we have in our country to be fruitful .QUE TRASCENDENCIA TIENE EL MENSAJE DE YERMA PARA  EL ESPECTADOR VENEZOLANO?...YERMA, EN SU“MAGNIFICA OBSESIÓN” POR SER FECUNDA,
ESTÁ MÁS VIGENTE QUE NUNCA EN NUESTRO PAÍS… ES LA GRAN METÁFORA DE LO QUE NOS
PASA…
What institution is backing us up?
We feature
the powerful support of the RAJATABLA
Foundation, who joined this project to participate as co-producers. The RAJATABLA Foundation, founded on
February 28th, 1971 by the great Argentine master Carlos Gimenez, is a
mandatory reference to the Venezuelan and Latin American theater.

INSTITUCIÓN NOS RESPALDA?
CONTAMOS CON EL PODEROSO RESPALDO DE LA FUNDACION RAJATABLA. Our team…

most important theatrical producers in the country,  William Lopez (under his leadership the

the brilliant showman Jan Thomas Moro.About our

story:
This is a unique production representing the D.I.Y culture and underground rave scene, it has its own style of musical circus that we have been developing with artists from wide and varied disciplines within, dance, theatre and music. 

We are not funded or sponsored and we are self fundraising to lift this project to get to the Edinburgh fringe in 2016.


The SHOW-> <<ALICE IN WASTELAND >> 

AN UNDERGROUND MUSICAL CIRCUS SHOW

Check out our website>>  www.aliceinwasteland.co.uk

Our projects have been showcased working from the ground up at various festivals, fairs and fringe cities for the last 5 years.


PRIZES->We are offering some really TOP PRIZES  and a fun way to play a part in this crazy unraveling adventure...

plus more mad prizes>>> continue to find out>>>

WHAT WE NEED ->

We need to transport our crew and equipment all the way to STUDIO24,  -the cities premier alternative venue in Edinburgh for the fringe in August. 
&
We want to put money into upgrading our props/set/lighting and showmen's vehicles. We also need to fund a good promo film and visuals for this production..
This will help us get our show on the road for the rest of the season and further outside the UK to Amsterdam for October, and beyond!



Here is a short film from the beginning of our journey
BRIGHTON FRINGE FESTIVAL 2014


Tickets for the Edinburgh show can be found here: https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/602756-alice-in-wasteland/

story:
ABOUT US


We are Room39. Our work represents a symphony of visual imagery, body movement and music, founded on literature and storytelling. Blending together reality and the phantasmagorical, we create and unfold landscapes of complex narratives. We aim to immerse our audiences into questioning, thinking and looking at the notion of art, science and life from different angles and perspectives…


ABOUT THE PROJECT


CATS,SELFIES and THE SCATTERED MIND OF THE INCURABLE DREAMER: a theatre piece about what does it mean to be human in the age of the Internet


The story happens in the Full Moon Cafe which is both a point in time and space, hidden in the middle of the Virtual Highway.  A point where everything comes together. A point where two strangers find each other and fall apart. Their affair turns the world into a never ending labyrinth built upon inability to connect.


This  Internet verbatim tells a story of the Web: a modern symbol of duality. Internet  is bombarding us with the extreme variety of information, in times spreading fear, in times bringing hope and in times burying everything under the stream of cat videos, selfies and countless ads...  


Perhaps for the first time since humanity existed the world wide web is what brings us so close together and takes us so far apart.


The show is on at the Space Theatre from 23d to the 27th of August.

https://space.org.uk/event/cats-selfies-and-the-scattered-mind-of-the-incurable-dreamer/


WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?


The funding is mainly needed to pay the creators and the artists participating in the production. We also need it to source set and props. Our company cares about the environment and we work sustainably, therefore all the materials will be sourced responsibly.


This is a new project and it is important to us that we make it as best as we can. After the August show is finished we will keep on working on it further. We want you to know that your support is helping us to plant a seed to something that will keep on growing and developing.


The Budget Outline:


In total: 3700


Set: 500

Costumes: 200

Creators (x 2): 800

Choreographer: 300

Sound Designer: 300  

Projection and Lighting Designer: 300

Production assistant: 200

Actors( x 3 ): 900

Costume maker: 200


If entire goal is not reached we will share the available amount equally to pay the artists and to source material that we can afford.


WHO IS IT FOR?


This project aims to raise an awareness of the political, environmental and emotional instability that the world is experiencing right now. Throught this show we strive to show different perspectives and angles of the same situation, letting people find their own questions and answers. We believe that watching this show will benefit everyone who has ever felt trapped, and lost under the pressure of the information age we live in...  


A BIT ABOUT OUR PAST WORK


Room 39 has formed over a year ago and ever since we have been making exciting work together. Our first show 80 milliseconds has delved into the exploration of time and memories. Coffee.Parallax.String. told a story of an architect lost between the world of imagination and reality.


The audience feedback included following comments :


‘Mesmerising...’


‘Beautiful and arresting…stunning imagery’


You can see more of our work here:

http://annasoboleva04.wix.com/room39


RISKS AND CHALLENGES


Our main challenge aside of money is time. All of us have day time jobs with not so much time left to do what we love. And it is only because of our passion and dedication we keep on  believing in what we do and make it happen. Despite the financial and time limitations we always challenge ourselves in creating work that is visually beautiful, conceptually engaging and inspiring.


THE OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP


If you think you can offer us props, equipment or materials for set building and costumes please don’t hesitate to get in touch.


Our email is : theatreroom39@gmail.com


Also, if you have any conversations or stories that you found on the web and want to share feel free to send it our way as we are still collecting material for our script!


And even if you are not able to support us in any of these ways, but love the project, please spread the word and make sure to see it and support it!

story:
DREAM TICKET was penned by playwright Ryan Bernsten years after watching the debates between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama and asking "what if they had a history...?" Today, it's a full length new play appearing as part of the New York Fringe Festival in August. This international festival will be attended by friends, family, producers, scouts, and theatre-goers from around the world. 

Why is this important? Well, many professional Broadways shows got their start here at the New York Fringe Festival! Shows such as Urinetown and Dog Sees God got their launch with the Fringe. And, most importantly, it's a timely, fun piece of new theatre that takes a good hard look at our political system while offering big laughs.

The team is strong and passionate; DREAM TICKET is directed by Kristin Skye Hoffman (Outstanding Director, Fringe NYC 2012) and associate directed by Marylynne Anderson-Cooper (director of the Dream Ticket World Premiere at Northwestern University). 

The cast features Chris Payseur as Senator Leslie Sugarman, Amy Lee Pearsall* as Senator Becky Roberts, Toni Martin* as Patty Baxter, Olivia Jampol as Darla Finger, Erik Gullberg* as Rex Herman, Adam Hyland as Thomas Stevenson, Desiree Staples as Wanda Puffin, and Ryan Bernsten as Ty Chadwick.

Designers are Laurel Livezey and Christina Tang; Stage Management is headed by Benjamin Vigil; our producing team is led by Alex Donnelly, Margaret Gandolpho, Alex  Knezevic, Kylie Mullins, and Max Rein.

What We Need & What You Get

  • 12,000 seems like a lot for a play, we know. But when you factor in paying professional Equity actors, professional designers, professional directors, making sure we have a set, lights, advertising–well, it adds up. 
  • But, we have fun ways for you to get involved. Even the smallest donations make you a part of the show, but if you want to literally be "part of the show" check out our perks and see how your donation can make you a unique part of this world premiere new play. 
  • If we don't reach our goal, every penny will be returned to you. Easy as that.

The Impact

  • Every artist gets their start with an opportunity like this; from a playwright fresh to New York City to a team of actors new to the Fringe Festival, every penny to donate translates to the creation of something that didn't exist before, all because of your faith and generosity. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't donate, we love you anyway. If you could share this page on social media, that would make all the difference in the world. And most importantly, if you could come see the show, that would be the real gift.

story:
TITI

A new short play written & directed by Victoria Preis
Cast to be determined (3 Actors)
Costume design by Julia Feinberg
Premiering at The Secret Theatre as part of the Long Island City One Act Festival

What We Need 

As an artist myself, it is vital that I create paid work for my peers and collaborators. It is vital to me that every individual involved in this production is paid adequately for their time dedicated to this project. Funds will be used towards:

  • Stipends for Actors/Costume Designer
  • Rehearsal Space 
  • Costume & Prop Budget
  • Photographer/Videographer
  • Marketing Materials  

If we exceed our goal, all extra funds will go to increasing artistic stipends.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, consider donating/lending the following:

  • Costume pieces
  • Props
  • Space: If you have a large room we can rehearse in, let us know! 
  • Share our events on social media

 

Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!
